reviews.review: All things Ho Chi Minh!. We used an amazing guide for the day (Dai, but can't remember the name of the company...just that it was based in Boston, MA), and he shed so much light on HCM and his life. Excellent English helped! A lot to see here.

Interesting insight into Ho Chi Minh and nice hot day walk in the shade. Lovely and interesting wander around Ho Chi Minh's residences and gardens - including a collection of his cars! Be aware that it closes at 4pm sharp - you could spend anywhere between 30 minutes and a couple of hours here. Drinks available at the end - we recommend the whole coconuts (drink the water and then get them to chop it in half so you can spoon out the flesh). Unlike some other reviewers, we weren't expecting to see inside the Palace (didn't have time anyway), so were happy with our visit. Don't lean on painted walls - it comes off!

Interesting and Enlightening perspective on Ho Chi Minh. This attraction helped me understand why Ho Chi Minh is a national hero. He did not live in the palace, but in the servants quarters, then a house on stilts. It takes you through some of the history of his life. Definitely better with a guide. Also, be aware that there are times when you cannot view the bidy due to maintenance. Check first if that is something you want to do.

Don't expect to see any of the inside. We didn't expect a stand outside and look at this Presidential Palace so it was disappointing. You can admire the grand structure of the Palace from a distance and see the gardens. There are other more interesting places to see, such as where Ho Chi Minh actually lived and some of his cars.

Quite impressive from the outside.. We could only look through the fence at the building. It seemed to have beautiful gardens but we could not get too close as the Phillipines president was visiting on the day.

Interesting history about Uncle Ho.... We were looking fwd to come here, but unfortunately around this time (October) the Mausoleum is closed for public, so we could only saw the building from the front... However we got to walk around the Complex and saw the One Pillar Pagoda, the Palace and the house where Ho Chi Minh used to live in, which was a really modest house... We got lots of infos from our tour guide and it was an interesting history of Uncle Ho... Keep in mind that without a tour guide, u wouldn't be able to hear these stories...

An Interesting Experience.. The Presidential Palace was an interesting experience. It was great to learn about president Ho Chi Minh's life and the history of the country of Vietnam. I enjoyed walking around it and seeing the great architecture of that era.
not allowed inside. it is located by the side of the HCH Mossleum. You can only visit the grounds of the palace. you are not allowed to go inside. not much info in this place.

very interesting place. nice place to visit.. lots of stories to tell if your a history buff, there are some restrictions on the place and you cant get inside the real Palace, but HCH had other house which he stayed during his presidency whic is also located on the same location. the place is still used to received political/ government guest and diplomats and other dignitaries

No inside information. The palace was built by the French Indochina governor before being grabbed by Ho Chi Minh. Our guide tried to make out how HCM was a humble man of the people, but if this is how they live then sign me up! Several nice houses and gardens to walk through, but if it weren't within cooee of the mausoleum and the one pillar pagoda it wouldn't be worth going in, as you don't get to set foot anywhere near the main building.

Waste of time. Nothing to see and nothing to do! Everything is restricted access and the parts you can see are not really worth seeing. The palace looks amazing from the outside but you cant go in or anywhere near so skip it and copy the pictures from google to ar least say you drove by

Tranquility in the middle of Hanoi. We really enjoyed our trip here and t experience the life of Ho Chi Minh. A very interesting time hearing about his life as president. A definite must when visiting Hanoi

Amazing history. Impressive building which was never lived in by Ho Chi Minh who decided to live on the grounds in a simple house. Although you can't enter the Palace the surrounding view, grounds and houses are interesting

A beautiful palace never used by Ho Chi Minh. Lynn and I did an outside tour of the Ho Chi Minh Palace recently. This is definitely a palace fit for a president, but apparently Ho Chi Minh was a conservative type that was not interested in all of the finery that this palace offered. He opted instead to live in the adjacent stilt house which did not even have in suite bathrooms. This is a beautiful property with many beautiful trails through the trees. It is a great place to commune with nature.

Wish we could have seen the inside. This is the palace but the smaller buildings there we those used by Ho Chi Minh. It gave an insight as to the type of person Ho Chi Minh was - private, unassuming, thrifty. Glas we saw it
Not Open Mondays.... Was really looking forward to visiting the Palace but unfortunately no body told us it's closed on Mondays. If you go, make sure you also appropriately dressed.
Very hot weather . Nothing really really exciting, but it's a pretty place. Good place to take some photos and to take a look at how uncle Ho lived. The weather is a killer though

Beautiful Buildings. Approached this gorgeous building from the road ahead in a bicycle tuktuk... it was stunning... our driver was a one armed man and he took us all over the place - we had a fantastic couple of hours around Hanoi seeing so much.

A lovely building you cannot enter. Part of the interesting history of colonial Vietnam and the choices made by HCM to not use it as his primary residence. The rest of the grounds are beautiful and represent his presumed accessibility to the people
Ho Chi Minh's home. Out guide explained the Palace and the Summer and Winter Residences very well, and gave insights into the loved leader and his life.

Presidential Palace. We could only look at this palace from outside,as visitors are restricted inside only to officials. Worth a look and pics. Uncle Ho's tomb was also closed,so we couldn't see inside either.

Ho Chi Minh. The propaganda about Ho Chi Minh and the reverance of the tour guides comes to the fore when visiting this site. Do I really need to see his Peugeot 404 or know that hehad 3 separate residences. Someehat interesting but the propaganda gets a bit much.
Magnificient Palace. Definately a place to visit if you ever find yourself in Hanoi and provides you with a great piece of Vietnamese history.

Average . Okay.. Nothing too interesting
It would be better if more was left in its natural state like kitchen.. Basement etc

Beautiful setting. A beautiful building as you would expect for a Presidential Palace. Ho Chi Minh never lived here preferring a smaller house within the grounds.
The colour of the palace is stunning against the greenery. A lovely setting worth a visit.

In the mood. It was such an experience
Historically informative
Information inputs overload
I could recommend to other students and young adult
We enjoyed it.

Just like a Big office as rebuilt. This was one of my...waste of time visits....like walking through a big block of offices,sure the ground in front nice etc.but best spendind time elsewhere...,as no historic interest being rebuilt
So interesting. An interesting look at the place where Ho Chi Minh lived and worked. Beautiful gardens and interesting history.
Changing of the Guard. We managed to see the changing of the guard which was quite a treat. Ask your guide for the times, its worth it

Gorgeous example of restoration surgery.. It is the prettiest piece of Restored colonial architecture in the city. That in itself might be a reason to avoid it. Don't worry the sentry will let you photograph it through the gate. Enjoy the gorgeous fading colonial mansions in the vicinity nearer the lake. They must have many a duplicitous tale to tell.
Looks good. Walked by this, but did not go inside. Lovely gardens and lots of little touches. Well policed and guarded, but the officials were very polite

Nice attraction especially on a nice day. Its very interesting to see the grounds of this place and ''Uncle's Ho'' home. Beautiful gardens, lake and all buildings, just what you would expect from Presidential residence. Worth a visit.

Nice garden to walk around. It was part of our one day Hanoi sightseeing. June however, was a hot month for outdoor walk. Also, there were so many people visiting the palace. The palace was pretty the details on the building were very impressive.
So if you are looking for a nice walk in Hanoi, don't miss out. But be ready for people and heat.
Interesting Building. It is interesting to look at the building which is now used for government functions the public are unable to enter part of the grounds of the Ho Chi Minh complex.

Ho Chi Minh palace . Actually the palace was built by the then French Governor General. The building was used by Ho Chi Minh to entertain state guests and he stayed in stilt house located in the same compound. The stilt house is open to the public giving one an insight into the frugal life style of the great man. The lake and the palace grounds are well kept.
Great piece of history. Well worth the visit, you get a great feeling for how Ho Chi Minh lived and what he valued. Great to see Vietnam looking after these areas.

Full Day Tour of Hanoi. Mr Phoung was our tour guide from Buffalo Tours. What a great tour guide. The day started at 8am and finished at 5.45pm. Yes a long day - but what a way to learn about Vietnam. His passion for his country was unbelievable. Amazing tour, amazing guide.
Humble place. A fond was a kind of beauty and the mango tree was a plenty. But some places are not open to public.

Like a photo from my childhood. If you are of my vintage, 60's, you could not but remember the black and white TV footage of the helicopters landing and taking off from the roof of the old Presidential Palace in Saigon as the Vietnamese tanks broke down the gates, signaling the end of the Vietnam War, or more rightly as the locals call it, The American War,The origainal tanks are still tere, preserved for all to see in the forecourt. A walk through the old building as it has been basically preserved from those days. The old American communications centre in the basement and graphic displays of the war in video and photo. It is one of those experiences that once again we are assured of "man's inhumaity to man". Not to be missed if only as a lesson on the present as well as an historical archive. Note: Be careful, it closes for lunch at midday but reopens at 2pm. You can keep your ticket and return on the same day after luch hours.

Nice place. The place was great for history of the place. It included lots of details and very nice architecture. The temperature inside the property was not controlled and was hot and since it was crowded, you feel hot and humid. But was great place to see
Intering Hanoi. Great places to visit and very interesting and informative. Wish I had more time to to spent to aquire more knowledge of the places visited.
Day trip. We loved to see how the government lived, they had a majority of the palace opened, and took a few hours to look thru. Even the grounds were worth looking around.

Nice building, but thats it!. You cannot go in, you can only look from outside, its free, but taking pictures is hit or miss. from up close the security guard may stop you, from far its ok. Other than that, simply put, its just a building.

Historic and significant building. After walking from the mausoleum it was very surprising with its grandeur. It was partly closed as a dignitary fro France was visiting so we actually saw quite a lot of pomp and ceremony, albeit from a couple of hundred feet away.
Lovely architecture, grounds were simply beautiful

Quite impressive. The Presidential Palace is worth a visit. It comes with the Mausoleum ticket. It's not huge nor too much show off, but it shows an interesting part of history. On one side there's a small collection of cars that were given to Ho Chi Min by several people.

Admire from afar. Part of the Mausoleum tour. The palace is a wonderful example of French Colonial architecture but unfortunately must be viewed from afar. Always crowded as throngs come to honor Uncle Ho and to see where he lived and worked. Nice well maintained gardens.

Part of the Mausoleum Tour . Many other historical buildings constructed by colonial French in thi area as well as the presidential palace which can only be viewed externally. At the rear of the Mausoleum

Been here a few times...come and pay your respects. I never miss visiting Uncle Ho and his compound when I visit Hanoi. No shoulders and no knees fyi.... History at its finest. Do yourself a favor and buy a biography about the man at the adjoining museum. If you don't understand who Ho Chi Minh is, you don't understand Vietnam.

Interesting but too many people. The Presidential Palace itself is a beautiful colonial building but can not be visited.
The sights to see are Ho-Chi-Minhs last house, some of his cars, the park around it and some other exhibits.
Relatively interesting to see, but so crowded we basically queued through the whole sight.

Day Tour Recommendation. I would recommend to go with a guided day tour, as you gather much more information regarding the history and current purpose of the palace. Be prepared for large crowds and the lack of air conditioning. There are many fans but with that many people, it can get quite uncomfortable. Drinks, snacks and souvenirs available on the rooftop. Make sure you visit the basement if you are a history buff!
God, God, God. The Vietnamese people still think of this guy as a god, amazing. the grounds are pleeasant, the crowds of locals coming to worship him were amazing.....

it is what it is. the palace is not open to public but you can get photos from outside.
it is still a good place to visit as the old house is there and is an insight how he lived.

The history of the man behind Vietnam. At 75 years young, I am old enough to remember Ho Chi Minh from television. Further, going through the buildings at the Palace, brought back the horrible memories of "Agent Orange" and the horrific effect it had on people. The information is well done, authentic and if you take the time to read all the posters/pictures, you will understand the devastating things Agent Orange did to generations after people were affected.Don't miss this tour. A lot of walking, but well worth it. The Presidential grounds are vast. Live the history and "the" man.

Ho Chi Minh Presidentiall Palace. Th Presidential Palace is very interesting telling you all about the Vietnam war, it has a lot of absolutely terrible photos, you have to see to believe, shocking history
Lovey building. Lovely building, we couldn't get in to it but still none the less impressive. Lovely gardens and grounds surrounding it also.

One of the Hanoi sight could not miss. The main Hanoi sights seem less important in this old French colonial capital than absorbing the atmosphere of a city on the move. The main attractions are found around the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum complex which lies some 3km away from the Old Quarter where you’ll probably be staying. We took a cyclo from our hotel to the Mausoleum then walked back via some other city attractions which we’ve listed below. You’ll have no problem getting a cyclo in the Old quarter, or anywhere else for that matter, as they’re all over the city touting for business

Must in hanoi .... The place is very central and easy access. You can see very big yellow building. Yellow is french style and you can still see this style every corner of building. Ho chi mihn house also very close this place. You can visit the both places at same time. Half day will be suitable to spend enough time. You can see every opinion and life style of ho chi minh with these place. CheersErnur

Some history. We thought it was very nice to visit some of the buildings connected to Ho Chi Min. You get to see his palace, his stilt house, his cars and his working quarters. Very organinised. When it is very hot, take something to drink with you.

HO Chi Minh Presidential Palace. Lovely gardens surround the palace. This is on the same grounds as the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, the Museum and the House on Stilts so it makes good sense to view all four on one outing. A little market on the same site is also interesting and was bustling with people.

Interesting. This is an interesting place to visit. There is a garage showing some of Ho Chi Minh's cars and a series of buildings, a lake and his stilt house. Check out the interesting tree roots at the side of the lake.

Amazing Palace in the centre of Hanoi. The building is over whelming and just a wonderful glimpse of times past... unfortunately unable to visit on the day we where there... but still worthy of peering through the gates...

Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace Complex. The beautiful Golden Presidential Palace is used for official purposes. Ho Ch Minh himself never stayed in the palace and preferred a very modest accommodation. The complex has a museum devoted to the great leader including a tree top house where he stayed. There are also three cars of the leader gifted by Russia and France on exhibit. The whole complex is laid out in a well maintained garden with lake and variety of trees and fruits. A must visit for all tourists.
Could not access !. A fine preserved French designed building close to Ho Chi Min and West Lake . Worth a photo ! Pity the gates are locked!
good to see .. never do this in hot weather. not worth it. drive around it and it will be fine. people feel that they should see all the Ho Chi Mingh stuff but absolutely not that necessary
City tour. Visiting here was part of a city tour. It 2as quite plesant walking through the area and listening and reading about Ho Chi Mihn and his life.

Look but dont touch. You can't go in this building but you can look around Ho's living quarters and his stilted house which are on the same site. Cost 40,000 vdg to get in - visit after seeing the mausoleum.

Beautiful and tranquil grounds . Great to see behind the scenes of part of how HCM lived. Would have loved to have gone inside the presidential palace but it was closed. Little sitting garden out the back was beautiful.

Gorgeous French architecture. We wandered through the wet and soggy gardens and took a look at this amazing piece of architecture in the gardens of the Ho Chi Minh complex. Stunning sight nestled amongst the nature tropical mahoganys and native tropics plants. Must see.

Not So Humble HCM. As I walked through the elegant grounds, palace, multiple homes, numerous cars, etc. it made me laugh to hear the guide speak of HCM's insistence on a humble life style. It was obvious, as George Orwell wrote, some are more equal than others.
Beautiful Palace. The entire area being so close to where he lived and worked as well as his tomb made it a great part of our visit to Hanoi. A must see.
Well maintained historic site. Architecturally interesting set of buildings which were the seat of power for today's Vietnam. Well kept building and grounds in a park like setting.
Massive mansion..palace!. We didn't venue in the palace...not sure you could. Our guide took us to a photo point, it was in the mix along side official cars, lying in state, private rooms etc

Gives context to visiting Uncle Ho in the mauseleum. 40,000 vnd for foreigners to enter... You don't actually get to enter any buildings but you can see into some rooms that have been set out as well as into the house on stilts. Worth seeing if you have already queued to go into the mausoleum.

Definitely worth a visit. . Again this is one of the those places you should go to if you're in Hanoi (and why wouldn't you). If you want to understand the history and culture of this nation this place gives you yet another insight into it.
Beautiful history. Nice palace with many well maintained rooms. It feels like a time travel with the visit of the bunkers in the basement. Worth the visit for an hour or two maximum

Interesting place. Nice place to look around and good to get an insight into the way Ho Chi Minh lived his life. This visit gave some perspective of the high regard this man is held in by his people. Our tour guide explained a lot about the man and the way he used the buildings on this site. Many of the trees have information / name plates but I wasn't familiar with those varieties. Saw Ho Chi Minh's cars and viewed the rooms through the windows.
A Must Visit Place In hanoi. Never miss this place. My best attraction in Hanoi. A tribute to Ho Chi Minh. Who fought & revolutionised & won
Worth a visit. A must if you visit Hanoi. The presidential palace and the house where Ho Chi Minh lived and died, in a beautiful park surrounded by trees, pagodas and a small lake

A MUST DO IN VIETNAM. this is where the helicopter landed on the roof of the palace.that finished the vietnam war.it is still there today.so look out 4 it..also on the right where the tanks are still standing today..after the war finished in the mid 70's.

Only Outside !! !!. This Palace constructed by French rulers for the presidential use after got freedom from them Government allotted this palace to the Great Ho Chiminh for his residential use but he simply rejected after some months he shifted to a small house near by this palace.
Presidential palace -great from outside. Not accessible to the public at time of visit.No signage to explain why.Entrance blocked by military,Disappointed as looks like a beautiful building
Awesome landscaping. The amazing landscaping and the ground are just breath taking. The changing of the guards on the ground is for sure a tourist attraction. A must see

Interesting character . Did this as part of the mausoleum visit and was worth a couple of hours out of your day. Full history of Ho Chi Min's life in English and a sight of his final homes (and cars).
Good one. Worth to see the life of Mr.Ho Chi Minh and the french rule related architecture . Also i saw some Russian made cars , which is given by the Russian government to Ho Chi Minh.

Beautiful and interesting. Located just outside of the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, if you pay just a bit of money you can get into the Presidential Palace and see the grounds on which Ho Chi Minh actually lived and worked. If you like history you'll love imagining "Uncle Ho" walking through the grounds and sitting at the tables and in the tree house. If you like beautiful gardens, you'll like strolling through the greenery and pond. This attraction is truly for everyone.

Lovely gardens surrounding French Provincial building. We spent an hour exploring the gardens around the palace. Shade trees were handy in July heat. Small presidential home is worth a visit after queuing (of course). Locals are very friendly and take the long queues in their stride.

Interesting wander round the palace grounds. It's a pleasant garden with a few sights from Ho Chi Minh's life but nothing which is "must see". Lovely and shady on a hot day though and if you're in the area it's worth a stroll through the grounds.
one of the good places for seeing in Hanoi. I took my dad and nephews to come here when they go to Hanoi. It can be the must see in Hanoi if you do the city tours with sightseeing option

Historically interesting.... We stopped at the Ho Chi Minh palace, which is adjacent to his mausoleum and his home, during our recent visit to Hanoi. I wasn't overwhelmed by the grounds, although they were very nice, but I found the stories that our guide shared to be very, very interesting, and I walked away with a great deal of respect for the man.
Holiday in viet. Love the architecture and the house is really big and have big garden too! It's nice. Surrounded by the trees and other unique buildings
Many interesting things to see. Set aside half a day!. Lots of interesting things to see at this tourist attraction. I regret that I only afforded two hours to this site.

Visit with mausoleum. The Palace grounds are lovely- when we visited the activity was high due to a State Visit , with a lot of security- the Palace has the typical French style architecture and the House and later built Lodge Ho Chi lived in are very humble.
Civilization. Great values to visit and learn, whichever side you are in and whatever you believe in. See with your eyes and feel with your heart.
Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace Histor. Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace is near by Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and paid attraction 40k vnd , it can be optional and explore other places

History with capital letters. It is a visit needed to understand Vietnam's last century history.
Well preserved and with very nice gardens.
Mausoleum closed after midday.
historic. Beautiful old provincial French buildings in Hanoi and this is one of them. Fun to take a cyclo trip around to see the historic building sights

Palace. If you visit Father Ho's tomb you will almost certainly be taken to the palace, it's at the end of the road.
You aren't actually allowed in the palace and President Ho didn't actually stay there prefering a simpler house in the grounds.
But your in Hanoi, so it's worth a visit.
must visit. this is a must visit place. near the mausoleum so do combine this with your trip to the mausoleum. the house on stilts, the walkways, the cars

An European site in the middle of Hanoi. If you want to see a beautiful building which has European influence, you need to see this site. This place is the center of government in Vietnam and very close to the Ho Chi Mihn Mausoleum.

Lovely buildings in a great park.. Actually a beautiful building, courtesy of the French architects. Nicely surrounded by parkland, the yellow building is where Ho Chi Minh worked, but he refused to live there, instead preferring a simple two story house also in the parkland.

The grounds are pretty but small . Not a whole lot happening here. Only a very small portion of the grounds is accessible. It's probably not even worth the 2 dollar entrance fee really. But if you have nothing else to do.....

Good. Ho Chi Minh complex includes: Ho Chi Minh mausoleum, Ho Chi Minh museum, the President palace and one pillar pagoda. If you're foreigner, you have to pay 40.000 VND/ticket to go to the inside after sightseeing HCM mausoleum and 10.000 VND to go to Museum. It'really funny and you shoulda try once when you come to Hanoi
Nice grounds. The building is impressive from the outside but you can't go inside the palace. It was worth a look at the car Ho Chi Minh used in the 1950's as well as the guest house and pond.

Very Interesting. Having 1st seen Uncle Ho, we then moved on to his old palace and gardens. Interesting to see how he lived very simply with no fuss. The park is well layed out and very peaceful and when we visited there was a big group of school children who were keen to try their English with us - a nice moment
What a gorgeous building. This was such a beautiful building and another staple landmark to help you navigate the city. I wish I could have seen the inside!
Beautiful. This beutiful and suprisingly quiet area was very fun to visit. The buildings are of yellow and french colonial style. If your here during june-august, bring sun screen and a fan.
Nice. It would of been nice to have gone inside the Palace, towards the end of his life he never lived there any more

Beautiful grounds. The presidential grounds are beautifully kept and have preserved many of the features regarding Ho Chi Minh, including the various meeting rooms, the cars used by Ho Chi Minh and the House on Stilts where Ho Chi Minh lived in the presidential grounds.The grounds are free to Vietnamese people, while foreigners need to pay VND 30000 (not 20000 as advertise elsewhere)

Number 1 attraction in Hanoi. Amazing place and so much history of Vietnam. This place is very busy on the weekends , so you may have to queue, but they move quick. The Palace is a beautiful design building and the gardens are so quaint. It is a must to do in Hanoi
Nice area to learn some history. The area is all outdoors. You see the palace, Ho Chi Mihn's 54 house and his house on stilts. The park setting is beautiful.

Fascinating bit of history. The Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace is well worth seeing as part of the complex of government buildings in central Hanoi. The large colonial style building was originally the French Governor-Generals residence and after the revolution, Ho did not want to live in it although it is still used for government meetings. We could not go inside this building but had a good look at the other buildings where Ho conducted business, as well as his residence and they even have a collection of his old cars.

Fascinating . We decided not to join the frankly ginormous queue to view the man himself, it snaked on for miles. We opted to walk around the beautiful grounds, view his houses and cars.Our private guide gave a great amount of information about Ho Chi Minh.Fascinating but incredibly busy, even for 8.30am.
Just fancy rooms . We went with a tour i wouldnt recommend i didnt find it interesting you walk around big rooms thats all if havevtime to waste maybe have a look but not much history
Beautiful building. Beautiful architecture and large well jept gardens and some more history of HoChiMin. Be prepared for a lot of walking to complete toyr. The palace is not open for tourists

IMPRESSIVE. Preserved in excellent condition and giving an interesting insight into what life was like in that era. Lavishly furnished in the style of that time the very large building attracts many people but it never seems crowded as it is just so big.

Right next to Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum. The former residence of the French Governor of Indochina, this mansion sits next to HCM's mausoleum. It's pretty colonial architecture, though it's generally unexceptional. Certainly worth a photo when in the neighborhood. West Lake isn't far, either.
Quite beautiful!. It was hot as hell when we visited but the palace (which you can't enter) is still quite beautiful from the outside.

Exquisite landscape. The grounds were beautiful. Carefully manicured and well-maintained. There is a piece of history here that can't be missed. It was great to see Ho Chi Minh's humble house. We went here in the morning and quite enjoyed the brisk walk while soaking up the Hanoi atmosphere and history.
Yellow. The knowledge about the colour of the buildings and where ho chi minh resided in was mind blowing. One should visit this place after reading more about it.

Prepare to queue if you want to see Ho Chi Minh's body. Undertaken as part of a guided tour. We bypassed the mausoleum, given the anticipated queue time of several hours, however the remainder of the tour included a visit to Ho Chi Minh's simple living quarters. Quite interesting and having come to Ha Noi I guess it's one of the attractions we felt obligated to visit.

Nice architecture. Admire the French influence architecture from the exterior. Entrance inside is not allowed. What a pity. Take a walk around the French quarter to enjoy many buildings with French design.

Beautiful, Historical, and Interesting. The palace is very beautiful from the outside. We were not able to go inside, but quite frankly I am not sure that is an option for anyone!
I recommend getting a guide to tour the grounds because you miss out on a lot of the history without one. Give yourself an hour to take the tour comfortably.
Just OK. You don't get to see much and aren't allowed to go into any of the buildings. That said its only 40K for tourist and looked like it was free for the locals.

Very interesting. I saw this as part of a tour but it was very interesting to learn more about the life of Ho Chi Min and where he lived.Tip - it was over 36 degrees when I went. I skipped the mausoleum as the queue was horrendous. Try and book a spot to see the body or see if you can get in through the side to just see the Palace.
Beautiful building. Beautiful building, but can't go inside, so enjoy from afar. On the way between several attractions, so worth passing by

Ho was amazingly humble and hated ostentation.. The impressive yellow presidential Palace was built for the French Governor General of all Indo-China but Ho refused to live in it preferring a small servants bungalow at the rear. Also in the servants quarters are his cars.When elderly (But much younger than me) he suffered from the heat so an airy bungalow on stilts was constructed for him on the other side of the lake.It can be visited.

Must see with guide! . This area is fantastic - there is so much history to learn in this well looked after area. We went through here with a private guide. I highly recommend doing this as if we were to have walked through the area by ourselves we would have not understood what everything represented. It's a wonderful site and I found it very interesting to learn what had occurred here not so long ago.
Worth a Look. It only costs 40K to get in but then you don't really get to see much. There's no opportunity to go inside any of the buildings but I still enjoyed it. Took about 40 minutes.
Go on a Friday when mausoleum is shut. The grounds are quite nice as is Ho Chi Minh's house on stilts. Take a walk down Mango Road to the back of the palace to see a bronze statue of Ho at a table.

Beautiful - Too bad you can't go inside . The grounds and the buildings are incredibly well kept and make for good pictures. Seeing Ho Chi Minh's quarters and car collection help give a sense for the historical significance of the place. I just wish you could have gone inside more of the buildings.All in all - I say skip this place if you're schedule is tight. The mausoleum and other sites are worth more of your time. But if you have some free time to use then you won't be disappointed.

Good introduction to history. Series of photographs showing history of the Vietnam between 1850 - 1975. Good range of artefacts including photographs, letters, dresses, original arms and several other articles. 40,000 vnd for adults and 10,000 vnd for kids under 14. Will take about 90 minutes on two floors. ACs were not working so could be little humid inside.

Historic past. A pleasant walk through gardens to see the impressive presidential palace and home where Ho Ch Min lived - the house on stilts. You can go directly in after mausoleum and it's a must see really for Hanoi. Very interesting and expensive souvenir shops afterwards. There are long queues you go through - the palace is a beautiful colonial relic - I don't think some reviewers appreciate the significance of just seeing this and it's French colonial style - it's where the French a governor lived

You can't get anywhere near it. Once you leave the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum area, you have the option to leave, or pay extra to see the palace. If you go to see it, you will be behind a fence on an angle from the house. Only Vietnamese citizens are allowed closer. It's pretty, but in my opinion, not worth the extra money to see the side of a house.

An eye opener in culture. We visited during a time when school kids were there and for a price could have got inside but decided the wait would be long.walked along the front area where the solders made sure we did not get too close and then after a few blocks wanted to go back and were told no must go around park! Way longer and out of the way, but you don't argue with armed guards !
Day visit to Presidential Palace. Usual tourist site, good for history buff and a chance to better understand the history of Vietnam. No need more than 1 hour to complete the tour.
A must to see. We were taken to the palace by a University student from Saigon Hotpot and the tour was very interesting. It made us understand the different ruling regimes in Vietnam.

On of the most beautiful French building in Hanoi. This Palace was built by the French back in 1903 and it is the most impressive French architecture in Hanoi. Located in the Ho Chi Minh complex and together with the Mausoleum, Ho Chi Minh's houses and the nearby Foreign Affair building, the Parliament House...this make a nice combine of French architecture of Hanoi. You can only see it from the distance as this place is not opened to public.
boring. all american information, it would have been nice to see the original one but this one is so recent.
Nice. However nobody can enter, it's an impressive building in an amazing environment next to the maosoleum and museum.$2 entry fee is applied to the garden.

Interesting and surprisingly low key. One would expect a great deal of personality cult around this site to beef up the story of Ho Chi Minh. But in fact, he is presented as a simple, dedicated statesman, who resided in a small house next to the colonial governors palace, in a nice park setting. It puts him in the same category as Ghandhi and Mandela, although the politics of the three were clearly different. But all three great minds with little or no interest in indulging in luxury, pomp and excess. It is a happy visit, lots of school children, and some lovely scenery.

Follow the legend. If you are a fan of Uncle Ho, then you should see his famous 'stilt house' and surrounding gardens. Ho Chi Minh, refused to stay in the orange French built palace and instead had a traditional stilt house built next to the carp pond. His effects are still on show and a gentle walk around the fruit trees and pond allows some reflection time...on colonialism, socialism, communism or just chill out.
After the Mausoleum . You should then visit the grounds of the Presidential Estate and see where Ho Chi Minh spent much of his life. Very beautiful and tranquil
Nothing to see. you can't even go near the place. You can't take photos. They are very strict. I hope I could see more of it soon. No tour is available.

Additional sights. The Stílt House and the Presidential Palace is not must-see sights, somewhat weak in material remains. However they may nicely round up a visit to the mausoleum (if you don't mind the queue) and they are located in a nice park which offer fresh and cool air in hot weather.

Old French Colonial Headquarters. An interesting buliding to llok at but I don't think you can go in. There are houses and buildings associated with Ho Chi Minh in the grounds and give a flavour of his later life. This was very busy on the day of our visit. There is a gift shop at the end!
Worth a trip. The bunker basement is interesting wrapped up in time!Certainly need a few hours here to take in all the rooms grounds etc....
a big yawn. you only see the building from the outside. so why even bother going? park is nice, but it is a park. ok to people watch

Nice Place. The Entrance fee is for the Presidential Palace cum Ho Chi Minh's House. You cant enter the palace but can only view the exterior building. The visiting hours are quite short everyday and so there are long queue for both Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum and The Presidential Palace cum Ho Chi Minh's House everyday. They do not open on Monday and Friday. There are student groups and tour groups queueing for the two different attraction everyday. For free & easy traveller, it can be very confusing and the soldiers do not speak English and so help is limited. Some suggestion: 1) Go early before opening time 2) The 2 attractions are at the Ba Dinh square and there are two different queues for the two attraction. it is very crowded and so take note of people jumping queue 3) Bring small bags because they will do security scan 4) No bermudas and slippers allowed. Wear decent 5) forget about going on sat and sun. the queue is too long 6) If you want to visit both attraction, queue for Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum first because the queue is longer. 7) Tell the taxi driver to stop at the area for the queue because Ba Dinh square is quite big and you may have to walk a long way to the queueing area if he stop at other side of the square. 8) Tell the hotel to write the attraction in vietnamese so that you can show it to the soldiers to check which queue for which attraction.
A place of historical interest. Good to have gone there and seen the inside of the palace. Only ever seen the outside on news footage

Lovely gardens great architecture. Part of a city tour, lovely gardens and great architecture a great insight into Ho Chi Min and his life in charge of Vietnam. Where he worked and his own private house built in the grounds.
A walk past tour is all we seemed to be allowed?. This was a spectacular building and appeared to be very well maintained with no obvious access for the public.
Colonial History. Part of our visit was to pass by where Ho Chi Minh refused to take up residency. However this building is very beautiful and worth taking a look at

Interesting, do this with a tour guide. The displays are well marked and laid out beautifully and a guide is not necessary but I like in depth explanations of the places I visit. This was especially interesting because of the significance of the fall of Saigon in 1975.

More spectacular at night. I found it more spectacular at night with all it's lighting and surrounded by the locals in the parks in front. Better on a weekend when all the locals come out with their families to enjoy the parks and the family.

Lovely stroll through this site. Beautifully well maintained gardens and buildings. Our guide Hao led us through this peaceful area explaining the various structures. Ho Ci Minh did not reside in the Palace but a more humble home with the gardens. Hai explained how the tree roots curled back up and grew into more trees this was freaky! The lake was lovely but take your time and enjoy.
Historically interesting. After marching through the tomb you can go walk around the place grounds to see where Uncle Ho lived and worked. It's nice and pretty with some bit of history.

Good but busy. Was good to see the palace and the grounds of the palace however didnt quite make it down to the house on stilts as the line up was increadibly large and we had already lined up for 3 hours at the mausoleum. Tourits pay 30,000vdn for entry. Great display of artifacts but could have given this a miss. The mausoleum was a great experience despite our poor choice in timing.

Interesting but to be avoided on Sundays. Beautiful architecture built by the French. You cant enter it though which is a shame. Apparently Ho Chi Minh refused to live in the palace as he didnt want to be seen as embracing French colonialism and lived in a modest building next to it. He only used the palace to receive and entertain foreign guests. When touring the city you do get a sense of how much this humble man still means to the people today. His mausoleum is only a few mins walk away from the palace grounds.We came here on a Sunday and the place was mobbed. Our guide said that waiting for 3-4 hours to get into the mausoleum is pretty normal, so we skipped it. Even at the palace you were effectively 'flowing' with the crowd.Definitely go and visit but don't go on a Sunday!
nice piece of history. nice building and exhibits of items used by the people president the story comes alive with the guide helpful informative narration which makes the history so interesting

Presidential Palace in Hanoi. Built by the French, this beautiful building sits unoccupied, and unavailable for tours. Too bad. Great photo op; however. A short walk from the Palace is Ho Chi Minh's house, office and museum, which are interesting to see. There are gift shops for people interested in shopping.
Lovely place to visit. You could only look from the outside but near other places so worth a look.We walked round the outside before going to the museum

Home of a mysterious leader.. The official word is that Ho Chi Minh only used the palace to receive foreign dignitaries and actually lived in a very modest adjoining apartment that is left as it was when he died with a 1969 calendar still hanging on the wall. Our guide gave us a very interesting introduction to the cult of Ho. A must do visit if you are in Hanoi.
A Look From The Outside. I believe this place is a great place to visit, if only the place is open to public. Alas for that! Closed most of the time except for formal occasions of national interests.
Very interesting history. Beautiful grounds and gardens! Loved hearing how he did not live there as it was too big and he was a single man. The one post pagoda was beautiful as well!

Interesting peek at Ho Ch Minh's life. Whilst not greatly impressed by the Mausolem, the grounds and simple house where HonChi Minh lived are worth a visit. We were offered a guided tour for free by a lovely young man who was a university student keen to improve his English. His explanations and pleasant personality really made the the visit worthwhile. His friends were doing the same so if you are approached by a very presentable, university aged young person offering to give you a free guided tour don't automatically say no. He was actually the highlight of our day.
Only a building to view from the street. Walked by this building after leaving the mausoleum but you can only view, no entrance. We learned that it is only used for visiting dignitaries.

Impressive Building. i was quietly rather amazed that we could visit the Presidents Residential House, and found it to be a popular attraction, with many other tour groups there at the same time as us. Some interesting & informative photos on the walls, and some more history learnt. Good experience.
Presidential Palace. Worth a look! Plenty of stalls around the presidential palace so you can do some souvenir shopping whilst your there

Long, long lines. This was my second visit. If you want to see a notable person who looks like a wax figure, I guess this is the place to go. Ho Chi Minh did a lot for his country and therefore people line up forever to see him.
You Must Visit Here. We loved seeing where Ho Chi Minh lived. The grounds are beautiful. Even though there was a light rain our umbrellas kept us dry.

The gardens. This is a must when visiting Hanoi its is a time capsual. It clearly shows how Ho lived and it is clear that he was not one for living the high life. The house and grounds are very good as is the diplay of old motor cars that were given to Ho.
Part of the Ho Chi Min Mausoleum tour. A palace-like french made structure that only served by formal visits by Ho Chi Min. No visitors inside

Complex is very large and worth a few hours. The presidential palace is just one of the things to see (you do not go inside) in this historical site. You can see the One Pillar pagoda, Ho Chi Minh's home, house on stilts, his cars, etc. Plan on a few hours here.
Historic . Enjoyed the grounds of the presidential palace and ho chi minh house on stilts. Old cars on display etc. Didn't do the mausoleum as the queue was round the block

Lovely to have a walk around the palace, included in the day tour. The palace and the grounds were very beautiful. You were also taken to the below bunkers incase of an air raid and sometimes lived there for days. All supplies and communication bunker are still they to see how they informed the outside forces. Great trip

Large complex with lots to see. The complex includes the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, the humble house on stilts from which 'Uncle Ho' ruled Vietnam, his vehicles, the Museum and the One Pillar Pagoda which resembles a Lotus Blossom. It is a peaceful setting, apart from the tourists of course, however the Presidential Palace can only be viewed from a distance. I would definitely include it on the itinerary.
Nice way to spend a morning.. We enjoyed this Palace, walking around the grounds, very interesting, their is also a lot of other things to see in this general area.
Closed on Sundays. Don't go on Sunday everything is closed. However it was fun to walk around and take photos of everything.

Impressive colonial edifice and Ho's last residence. It's the Wandering Yank here. Mrs. Yank and I visited the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, and since this is next door, we gave it a look. The palace is handsome, but closed to the public apparently. But the "stilt house", Ho's final home, in the palace gardens is open for viewing. It's very simple - 2 rooms, still furnished as they were at his death in 1969. Expect a long line, but it moves quickly, and it's far shorter than the line for the mausoleum. There's a garage with 3 old cars, 1 Peugeot and 2 Soviet vehicles. The gardens and lake are very attractive and well-kept. If you're already at the mausoleum, you might as well check this out. The cost is minimal (40,000 VND).

Great site at the centre of Vietnamese history. This park is a large site with lots to offer. The large presidential palace, formerly the residence of the French governor in colonial times, was not open (and our understanding from the guide is that it never is). But the grounds are interesting and the paths lead inevitably to the "house on stilts", where Ho Chi Minh lived rather than in the palatial residence to which he was entitled. Adjacent to the house on stilts is a small, bunkered bedroom in which Ho died in 1969. Although the grounds tend to be crowded, especially on the weekends, everyone was moving well when we toured. It's a slight disadvantage that there is so little signage, and what little there is is only in Vietnamese. Well worth a visit as a reflection of Vietnamese history.
very impressive building. well worth looking into as it a key part of the country's history. impressive architecture. its centrally located so easy to access

Take time to visit. Gardens was really good, you can take lots of photos...Must visit to understand Ho Chi Minh' s life.. But it's so crowdy by local people and school children who were learning about Ho Chi Minh. Anyway it's great to visit at least 3-4 hours to visit.
Steeped in History. Great to see the residence of the leader and the cars gifted to him. Only disappointment was that you can't go inside the state building.
Interesting. Park which has government buildings and Ho Chi Minh's home in it. It was very crowded with local people and lots of school children who were learning about Ho Chi Minh

Uncle Ho's palace and garden secrets. Our visit to Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum and gardens had some surprises ......we arrived on a Sunday morn to vast queues. Our Audrey guide speeded us throu ( found the right queue) we bypassed the mausoleum in which the body of H C M still lies in state. Shame , but the Vietnese make a once in a life time to see their uncle Ho and many visited that Sunday! We saw his old cars , his fish pond cont. enormous carp and if patient there are some very big catfish. The palace was quite stunning , his garden house was lovely and his living quarters were verse basic. The trees were quite impressive.....His bunker was nearby in case of attack ? In all incl of queues you need 2to 2.5 hrs dep on speed of people.

Good for a quick stop, interesting history facts. If you want to learn more about Ho Chi Minh and history of his life, this is a good place to visit. Nicely conserved, 1 hour or less is enough as part of a city tour.
Interesting. The palace is part of a complex with various other sights - Ho's house on stilts, one pillar pagoda. worth walking around the site but it does get really busy
Pretty park . A small park with a variety of interesting artefacts including Ho Chi Mien's cars and houses. House not open to public pretty gardens.
Great. Make sure u have the tour guide with you, or get private tour guide for the day to enjoy the history and heritage, nice place and great graden

Meh. Another place you could skip. Better to spend the time somewhere else. Just a palace in a small park. There are several buildings and a garage with three cars that Ho Chi Minh used to use, and a house where he uses to live, but that's pretty much it.

Interesting but closed when we went. There were notices up stating no photos allowed and we couldn't go in which was a shame since having read before on trip advisor we could . Still interesting to see all the same

nice building where ho chi Min never lived. it is part of the ticket one buys to see the houses in which Ho Chi Minh really lived.
it is located in the botanica gardens
it is quiet there!
It's Good To Be King. Beautiful architecture, prisine grounds, lovely area. The area around palace is a photographers paradise! The "lake" and house on stilts was extremely easy to the eye.
Interesting. It's a must see. You get a pretty good tour the the whole place.It was the top rated to its time but now it looks old and a little shabby.I guess that we are spoiled and expect more.

Interesting. If you are into the history of Vietnam, in particular Ho Chi Minh, then you will find this particularly interesting, otherwise, it is an attractive site with interesting buildings in peaceful surroundings. 30 minutes to an hour is all that will be needed.
Very Interesting. The grounds are exquisite with many plants and flowers. Ho's House on Stilts is perfectly preserved and shows a time in his life.
Impressive Building. This building and surrounds form an ideal place to visit. Many photo opportunities and a taste of culture from days past.
Palace . We had a guided tour of the palace organized by our place of accommodation. Our guide walked us through all rooms his English excellent. So glad we did the tour.

Very insightful. For people who love to explore another country's historical sites, this is highly recommended if you ever visit Ho Chi Minh. It is an educational place where we can further explore Vietnam's history.

From the grand to the humble. The original Palace (in photo), was the French Governorial Residence. Ho Chi Minh decided this was far too grand, and had a small two story pavilion built in the grounds. This he lived in, and occasionally received foreign dignitaries. The contrast is clear and pointed and the pavilion is worth seeing on its own. The grounds too, are worth walking around, well-maintained and calm gardens and fish pools. Be careful you're not run down by soldiers practising their parades!

Vietnam trip . This is a great half day activitie for yourself and others.
A great way to help understand Ho Chi Minh, his home and humble way of life and life style. Nice walk through the gardens and grounds.

Palace is Closed to Visitors. When you come out of the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum you end up at the entrance to the grounds of this palace. The area is nice for a stroll. Watch out for the granite pavers if it is raining - they can be very slippery.
Very colorful gardens. I was impressed with this French palace and the tree house where Ho Chi Minh lived. The gardens and lake were very pretty and enjoyable.

Nice from a distance. . Only able to view from a distance. Seen after the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum.
Nice French architecture.
Apparently now government use.
Worth a look.

An oasis of calm. The palace was built by the French and was set in lovely grounds.
Ho Chi Minh had a wooden house built within the grounds where he lived very frugally inkeeping with his communist belief. There was a lovely lake with very tame fish and some very old and majestic trees.

Sanctuary in the heart of Hanoi. Away from the scooter horns and traffic you will find the peaceful setting of the presidential palace grounds. For a few dollars you can stroll the grounds, just be sure to stay on the paths for if you stray, a guard will quickly be at your side. The site is interesting and worth a visit but it is hard or at least when I was there it was hard to get too close to anything. The palace was barricaded, you couldn't enter the stilt house... Still interesting, just was hoping for a more intimate experience.

Interesting learning how Uncle Ho lived. the Presidential Palace in the picture was built during the French occupation. You get too see the outside of this only (not inside) straight after visiting next door Mausoleum. The guide then explains Uncle Ho thought this too opulent so had a much smaller single level house built next door (which you can peer into the windows of and see his study and other rooms from the outside) and then moved to other side of lake to a stilted house, much more traditional Vietnamese countryside dwelling - although this was purpose built. You join a line and file past the rooms on the upper floor of this stilted pavilion. Interesting seeing the Vietnamese reaction to all this. If visiting Hanoi it's going to be on your list of things to do - but it's not a 'wow' just interesting.
Well worth viewing from a distance when in the area. Allow a minimum time to see this place - it is very interesting. We made our arrangements with Hanoi Transfer Service on our private one day tour.

Well worth a visit. If you have any interest in the modern history of Vietnam you need to visit this. It combines well with the superb War Remnants Museum nearby. Ideally you need a good guide although it is possible to learn from the display charts.
Interesting how he is remembered. This was not one of my favorite places though they have done a good job of organization for Ho Chi Minh's memory.
Interesting. Interesting to see how this revered and respected leader lived. This is worth the time to visit. It is a quick self guided tour and interesting.

Most of the place not permitted for visitors. The palace looked decent from outside. But you don't get to see that exactly. You are allowed to visit the quarters where Ho Chi Minh stayed and did fishing. And few of the cars presented to him by various countries. Otherwise not much of a place as most of the part was inaccessible to outsiders. I don't know why they charge $2 for that place.
A lavish building for state occasions. It's beautiful architecture but the man himself lived far more simply. It's worth a quick peek but the mausoleum, and his stilt house are far more compelling.
HCM Palace. Going out of HCM Museleoum after having greated uncle Ho, you have to go to the Palace (walking distance) The garden is beautiful and the house were HCM lived is very cute!

Tour of the HCMC Presudential Palace. Beautiful building originally built by the French government. Toured the different function rooms of the president and First Lady. Also viewed the presidential barrack room in case of any attacks to the palace. It was there where a citizen waved the Vietnamese flag thus declaring the independence of Vietnam.

Ho Chi Minh's Vestiage. A very interesting tour, loved the way the guide referred to Ho Chi Minh as Uncle Ho (although the first few times I did think he was saying alcohol and could not understand the link - silly me).It is incredible the importance and respect the local people hold to this man, he was very humble and it was good to learn more about him.TIP: unless you are in an organised tour expect a long wait as the lines were extremely long

An official building. The Presidential Palace is located within the Ho Chi Minh complex and is the most opulent building in Hanoi. The Beaux-Arts style building was constructed in 1906 for the Governor General of Indochina. It is also a historical site now used for official receptions but is not open for viewing inside.

Very interesting. Part of a day tour and packed with information about the man and the country. If you have taken the trouble to travel as a tourist to Hanoi then I'm not sure how you could miss this iconic site.

Uncle Ho's oasis. It is impressive to see how modest and unassuming Ho Chi Minh's personal rooms were. The luxury jetzt had was the beautiful park he lived in with the big fishpond. The visitors are carrfully and cleverly guided along the paths so that even higher numbers do not really disturb the overall peaceful impression.
Classic French Architecture - Unable to Visit (internally). From a personal perspective and when time is 'tight' this is one site which can be missed as it offers only 'same old, same old'.

Fascinating to see how he lived. You don't see inside the palace as it is not open for viewing, you do however see the other three houses that Ho Chi Minh lived. Interesting to see that he was a simple man with simple needs.

Interesting day out. Found this good to begin with and all quite interesting but the tour did go on a little longer than expected and started to loose interest a little bit. Definitely worth a visit and look around.

very disorganized presentation. We went to this museum to find out more history regarding Ho Chi Minh. The interior space is attractive and spacious, but I found the layout and way the history was presented disjointed and hard to follow. Normally you will find that there will be a chronological order to the presentation, but this was not the case here. There was very little presented regarding the North and South Vietnam division, and frankly it seems to gloss over this significant historical factor. If you do decide to see this museum, keep in mind that it is closed on Friday and Monday and it closes from 11 to 1:30 (rather odd).

Pity we couldn't see from the inside. Beautiful old elegant French era building that even the yellow paint couldn't detract from. Unfortunately you don't get to go inside which would have made it a lot more interesting.It is included in the park and surrounds of the mausoleum.

Really historic site and stories to go with it. The presidential museum was not lived in by Hoi Chi Minh as he preferred a simple life so lived in a small wooden building in the ground. No wonder he is still loved by the Vietnamese

Nice attraction to add to a day tour.. Great place for photos and to learn a bit about the History of Vietnam. Better to do it with a tour guide. I can get very busy over there so good to try to get there early and get out before it gets too busy.
Good place for history lovers. This is a good place if you want to know more about ho chi minh and how he lived. You can even see his cars and his dinning room.

Very grand historical site.... Visited the site with friends with a day trip and guide (although you can visit without a guide but prior reading up on the grounds might be required to appreciate it fully). Located close to the mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh the site is very well maintained and impressive and is still in use today by the communist party as such it is very well guarded (therefore I would not recommend criticising communism or anything related to it for obvious reasons). We were even lucky enough to see a ceremony on the grounds were exceptional communist party members were presented with medals. The grounds held peaceful gardens, Koi carp pond, palace and a collection of vintage cars. Also the site helped reveal Ho Chi Minh's modesty and how he humbly wished to better Vietnam. Although depending on the weather I would recommend taking: Sun Screen, Water, Camera, Hat or Umbrella and some bread to feed the impressively large Koi carp.
Interesting.. We went here as part of our tour. My husband and I went into the mausoleum to see Ho Chi Min's body. Very solemn. A great piece of history.
Can view outside only. A lovely building from the outside, it's a pity you can't visit inside. However, it's great to visit as part of the whole complex and makes for a nice photo!

VERY INTERESTING!. Interesting to see & learn about President Ho Chi Minh in this beautifully preserved area. One gets to see the Presidential Palace, beautiful gardens, vintage cars used to serve the President, and his house on stilts which reflects the simplicity, modesty, gentleness and dedication he showed towards the people of Vietnam.

Beautiful. This place is adjacent to the Mausoleum and there is an entrance fee. The exterior is beautiful and the walk around the gardens is pleasant and recommended. Though this is the imperial palace, Ho Chi Minh is said to have stayed in a small room outside of the palace since he was a simple person. No need to make a separate trip, do it along with the visit to the Mausoleum.

Beautiful area. We came here as a part of our city tour and it was our most favorite part. I got to know more about the President of Vietnam. And his house was a beautiful place with a nice gardens and the lake with many fish. Simple architecture, very peaceful and serene. Even have to be in a long line, it's well worth the wait.

Impressive building. Impressive building but you can't go in, or even get that close. There are some nice gardens and the simple retreat Hoi Chi Min lived but the volume of people means you're in a more or less permanent queue.

The worst experience in Vietnam . This is a nasty place to visit. There is little to see and it is mostly closed - it closes for three hours in the middle of the day, ffs. This was an unpleasant experience and a waste of half a day. We are trying not to let it spoil our impression of Vietnam, however. Here is a list of issues, in no particular order: - The entrance is unfathomably difficult to find.  - It is closed for half the day and no one seemed to know the opening times.  - The guards are unfriendly.  - The mausoleum is ugly.  - There are no signposts and the site is huge so you end up walking in circles a lot - The museum is worse than useless: just a load of communist propaganda trying to justify the regime.  - The one pillar pagoda is deeply unimpressive.  - The botanical garden entrance is not at all close and is hard to find, despite being next door. And it is the worst botanical garden I've been to.  - There is an unnecessary dress code (long trousers). A waste of time - half a day of my life that I won't get back.
Really interesting to see . I thought the Ho Chi Minh complex was fascinating to see and learn about. It offered a unique perspective on Vietnamese history and one of their favorite leaders
Outside of Palace. Could only see it passing by, don't think you can go inside.Grounds are lovely lots of blossoming trees.

a must see place in Hanoi. the presidential palace, botanical garden, Ho chi Minh resident , fish pond and one pillar pagoda, a great complex in hanoi. we love it and highly recommend to any traveller

Must see...very well maintained. . Presidential palace was built between 1900 and 1906 to house the then french governor. post independence in 1954, president Ho chi Minh decided not to stay in such palatial building and decided to build a Vietnam style house adjacent to presidential palace. I am told that palace is used as president's office. You can see the palace from a close distance only. Entire area is kept neatly with flowers. Behind the palace is the stilt that ho Minh built for his stay. He stayed there from 1958 till death in 69. Very simple place with almost basic setting that shows the humbleness of the man. Place is well maintained. Three cars are there which president received. One of them as I remember was from Russia. Ho chi Minh mausoleum is also there but I couldn't go inside.Good place and a must see in hanoi. There are time restrictions here and hence need to check with guide before going.

Good insight of the life and times of Ho Chi Minh. The father of modern day Vietnam was a humble man who looked to communism to overcome the oppression of the French in Indochina from the late 19th and first half of the 20th century. Not needing wealth and glamour he lived in a 2 room house on stilts that was built specially for him to pass his time whilst creating the foundation for the future

Just In Passing. Didn't have allot to do with this due to a very large official meeting on going so the area was swamped with Army & Police at the time. Certainly an area you feel not to do anything untoward in.
IT WAS CLOSED. The main building was close, so we visit the small house near the lake. THERE HO TSI MING speed his last days of his life. The garden was Beautiful. Nice place for photos.

Slice of Paradise. The grounds are absolutely stunning! It was such a surprisingly beautiful place and a much needed escape from the bustling city. Lovely pond with koi fish, lush manicured greenery, the palace itself is breath taking. The stilt house is lovely in its own right. Can't recommend this place more! Also- Don't miss the little side road - Mango Drive.
Stately. A great exhibit & tribute to Ho Chi Minh. Beautiful grounds & interesting history well laid out for the public.

The building stands out. The visit to the palace site, as a complement of the mausoleum, is nice if you want to go deeper in the adoration of this person. The palace itself cannot be visited. The colonial architecture is elegant and the color stands out. You cannot even stop in front of it...
Palace. Ho Chi Min never lived in the palace he had a modern house in the grounds with bomb shelter and guards in situ
Anotehr "need to see" in Hanoi. Interesting building by dint of its history. Lovely grounds, many trees, including a mango grove behind it. A necessary parrt of understanding Vietnam's history.
A fascinating building. The palace is for viewing only and is not open to the public. It is a beautiful building and can be seen along with a visit to the Mausoleum.
Beautiful place. This place is worth seeing. Very Beautiful. A lot of history and interesting details. A must see when in Saigon
Good place for a visit, close to the Mausoleum. Even though it was pouring rain we enjoyed our visit here to see how Ho Chi Minh lived. You cannot go inside the Palace as it is now offices

Beautiful Building . The building is gorgeous surrounded with beautiful landscaping is most impressive. Interestingly Ho Chi Minh never lived here as he was a man of the people and thought the place was too pretentious for him to occupy

Nice walk in the garden but do not expect something spectacular . The palace in the same complex as the Mausoleum, but you have to pay a fee to enter. You can actually walk just in the garden. It is nice, well maintained but nothing extraordinary. You can spend there an hour or half, but this is all. Anyway as there aren't that many things to be seen in Hanoi, it is a good stop of your trip.
A beautiful Palace with Gorgeous grounds!. Built by the French - beautiful chateau! The grounds are well laid out - gives a feeling of peace and serenity. A must see!

Skip or just drive by. It is a beautiful building but that is about all that can be said about it. Perhaps if we had been on a tour which explained much about it, I would have been more impressed. There are better ways to spend your time in Hanoi.
Beautiful building and park. When visiting Hanoi, to get the whole history and french memories, you must visit this very beautiful building in Hanoi city-

Nice Grounds, but nothing special. Did a tour of the grounds but not able to tour the "palace". Is set up as a guest and office facility. The grounds are nice and well kept. Ho Chi Minh's tree house is interesting, and sets a picture to be considered. Not really impressed, but one has to consider where you are

a portion of colonial architecture. The complex ofPresidential palce represents the french style. It is a great area composed by the Palace garden pagoda and other portion of houses for people working in very good taken and valorized.It takes some minutes to walk around or an hour visiting all due to the que.It is not possible to see inside the palace buta pagoda and garden are interesting and also gift shop is nice. .

Nice grounds and good walking tour. Interesting to see palace and also home where Ho Chi Minh lived. Also has mausoleum where Ho Chi Minh's body is kept. Can not go into palace or home so it's mostly a tour from the outside. Nice pond with koi on the grounds.
Interesting to visit. This is one of the tour essentials. lots of groups and visitors. But if you wend your way through its interesting.
Presidential Palace in Ho Chi Minh City. This was probably an obligatory spot to bring tour groups. Turns out the building was not a government facility, but now used for private group meetings.
OK. A very nice complex of buildings and reasonably interesting to look at and into. It really just needs a walk around, though, of about half an hour.
Impressive building. You won't be allowed inside though so get on a tour to hear about the past. Worth a look ad part of a wider tour.

Beautiful Grounds. Much revered by the Vietnamese, Ho Chi Minh is portrayed as a simple man, not wanting to live in the lavish quarters on the grounds. You learn about his wanting to live simply despite the beautiful palace and grounds. Enjoyed walikng through with our guide, who explained "Uncle Ho's" life, how he lived, and how he treated his people.
a nice walk. It was hot and we were tired. The grounds are well cared for and the people friendly. Bring your own water and time to visit.
Exquisite & Maintained grounds . The buildings are classic French architecture, so lovely old cars and huge fish in the pond as well as Ho Chi Minh's modest alongside his palace.
Very busy but quite good.. It was rather mobbed when we visited the palace. Good insight into how Go Chi Minh lived, and worth the hassle.
Historical and very interesting. Very interesting for those interested in Vietnam war history. Most of the major policy decisions were taken here. It the residence and ofice of the President

Worth to try.. I don't really know about him but this it was a good visiting.
You can pay once and look around all the places includes a museum. Also a good garden.
Worth to try out!
Pretty cool. A must-visit if in Hanoi for a Few days. It can get pretty packed around the site, so prepare yourself for large, slow-moving crowds
Pleasant gardens. This is a well maintained part of the city with Palace centre stage in some lovely gardens. Hard to miss this area if you're visiting Hanoi and certainly worth some time.

Lots to see and important recent history. Get to understand more of the country's recent history with visits to the French colonial palace and Ho Chi Minh's office and houses in the grounds. All outside only but worth doing.

Pretty. Scenic but only worth visiting as part of the wider complex. You can't enter any of the buildings and Ho Chi Minh's furniture and cars aren't really that interesting. It's cheap though and the lake and trees are pretty.
Beautiful Monument. We din't visit the presidential palace because there is just some hours of the day to visit but it's a beautiful monument that you can see from the road.
Uncle Ho.... Ho Chi Minh's palace is very nice and peaceful place. It's nice to see how much he is liked by public. Go early because it can be incredibly crowded.
Nice place. I liked seeing the small house Ho Chi Min lived in better than the palace. But it is a place worth visiting to see the grounds with the pretty houses and beautiful lake.

Stunning Palace . I was pleasantly surprised with the presidential palace. Architecturally it has been well maintained. The building has becomes living memory of the past and how Vietnam has made it today. I admire Ho Chi Minh for the legacy he has provided Vietnam.Tip : allow a good amount of time to explore, a tour guide is advisable , camera , sunhat , sunscreen
Magnificient Building. Its a French colonial building built in 1906 for French Governor, though general public is not allowed to go inside, we took a round in the beautiful garden.
learn about HCM. Nice tour and history of HCM including his mausoleum, residence and office all within a short walk.The mausoleum has limited hours so check before goingh

Interesting Place. The impressive palace was built by the French during colonial times, but Ho Chi Minh himself preferred to sleep in a much more modest building in the beautiful grounds. You can't enter the buildings, but a visit helps build a portrait of the enigmatic Ho Chi Minh. (One has to bear in mind at all times that there is a significant amount of propaganda and iconography at work, especially in the north of the country.)

I tersting place to gain some history of Vietnam. The tour was very interesting and grounds very well kept. However, the toilets were disgusting, so be prepared to take your own toilet paper and hand wipes!!
Nice place. Nice ground to walk around and see how he lived or didn't live since he slept in the places built behind the main building.
It's nice.... You cannot go I', so only a pic from the outside will have to do. It stands out with its bright yellow colour paint. Nice building in general

Extremely interesting. As part of a day tour we went to see the tomb of Ho Chi Minh. That was a great experience and then we got to tour the grounds and see the various houses where he lived. Found some great art in the little shop on the way out.

French structure. Only busted the outside but the history given by our tour guides filled 6 minutes as it went form it's use as the governors residence to Ho Chi Ming refusing to live in it and current day's role as a formal state reception venue but current leaders honouring Ho Chi Ming's sample if not using it as a residence.
Nice walking tour. This was an interesting tour because we had a guide--not sure if this is available without pre-arranging. It is pretty but not sure it is worthwhile without guide

Beautiful building. Located right by the masoleum this is a beautiful example of French colonial architecture at its best. Used primarily for functions and special occasions now, as uncle Ho never stayed here.

Interesting and lots to see. Interesting place to learn about Ho Chi Minh, see how he lived, his car collection, museum etc. Well worth the 40,000VND entrance fee. Not normally a fan of this sort of thing, but it was decent. Probably better with a guide though.

Worth a visit . It's an interesting attraction and worth a visit if you're in Hanoi and have some free time
It's in the same area as the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, so it's killing two birds with one stone, as the saying goes
Historical Interest. An enjoyable tourist attraction and of historical interest. Loved seeing how it was left , just the same as during Ho Chi Minh's reign.

A historical place for you to understand Vietnam. I visited this morning. Before going there, I learnt some history about Ho Chi Minh. It helped the visit more interesting. The place is originally a French Governor house with a big garden (park?) for the governor (Ho) to live and work there. It is in French's style and well maintained. It is worthwhile to visit there if you are in Hanoi.

The Palace and Home. Never knew that despite the Presidential Palace, Ho Chi Minh preferred to make just an ordinary house in the complex as a home. I think this is what impressed me about this palace. Also I learn few more things about plants and certainly a bit more history of Vietnam.
Históricas place, mandatory for visiting.. Tvery interesting place , is a museum, the Ho Chi Minh 's house. The garden is beautiful. We really suggest to visit this museum.

Interesting but the Mausoleum and Museum were better. After we visited the Mausoleum we really wanted to go to the Ho Chi Minh Museum but it seemed that the only way to get there was to go through the Presidential Palace site which was a separate small entrance fee. There was a sign pointing to the museum but on attempting to follow it a guard made it clear that we must not go that way. It sort of felt like they were forcing you to do the entire complex when we wanted to skip this part.In the Presidential Palace complex we saw the garage of his cars and the small stilted house where he slept and worked. It was interesting but didn't contain any information that we didn't get elsewhere.
