It was also very busy and the pathways are narrow so you can't skip parts of this either as you just have to shuffle along with the crowds through the designated pathway. i stopped to wait for my husband who had been caught behind another group and a guard used his megaphone to blast a sound in my direction and waved me along.
A grat building to see. A great buolding is definitely worth a visit if you are within the area also visiting the other sites in close proximity
Beautiful Buildings and Gardens . A nice area to walk around in before or after a visit to the masoleum and museum. Very peaceful and serene.
Information Journey. This was a part of our tour. We came here after we went to the Mausoleum. We learned a lot about Ho Chi Minh and it was very informational, fun and interesting.

$2 - ok.... If you did bring a big bag when visiting the mausoleum then the shortcut trough the palace is worth it. Seems like a hidden way to charge tourists for visiting the HCM mausoleum. You will never get inside the palace but the walk trough the garden is quite nice.And there is also free good advice to all kids out there - stay off the grass :)

Interesting walk. Intersting walk around the grounds of the Presidential palace which stands as a memory of the colonial times of the French in Indochina. Didn't get to see inside the actual building but the gardens are very nice to stroll around. whant you do get to see however is Ho Chi Minh's stilt house which he ordered to be built in the grounds near the lakes when he assumed the role of President in 1954. The story goes that he considered the palace too grand for him and that one act, of living in a typical humble workers house really brings to life the nature and the charisma of the leader of the nationalist movement. Its a lovely setting and worth the few dollars entrance fee. Good cafe, shops and amenties availiable.
nice walk among history. lovely place to visit not very early in the morning to avoid the crowd visiting the mausoleum which is opposite the main entrance. great walk in the gardens.
Beautiful place . Very beautiful and could have spent more time there.Very interesting to learn more about Ho Chi Minh and his achievements.
Beautiful building. Just saw this Palace from the outside and it is beautiful, built by the French. Only negative is the awful, color cream would have made it elegant.

Witness to regime change. The Presidential Palace, official home to successive South Vietnamese governments from 1954-1975, is best remembered as the site of triumphant North Vietnamese Army tanks breaking through the gates in the spring of 1975. A large building with an interior in moderate disrepair, worth only a cursory visit when already in the area.
Historical location. You can see the presidential old cars. Walk around the old ho chi minh house. Able to see the room where important meeting were held.

Beautiful location with great history. I enjoyed visiting these historical grounds, including the houses where Ho Chi Minh stayed while serving as leader of the country. A guide is essential to fully comprehend each of the locations and the historical signficance, including the bomb bunker, place he died, etc.
well preserved French architecture. As part of the day tour makes for a nice walk and impressive that it is preserved well. not really a history buff but loooks nice

Since your already there........ As a stand alone site, going to see this place by itself would be mostly for school children, devoted locals and history buffs. However since you get to see it after visiting the mausoleum, and if your smart, before the Ho Chi Minh museum, then it is worthwhile your time in understanding this figure so revered by the Vietnamese.

One of the must see sites in Ha Noi. This complex of buildings and temples is right next to the Bac Ho Mausoleum. There is considerable time outside in the heat so be prepared. Really loved the very simple and austere living quarters of Bac Ho during the time of the Viet Nam/ American War. The Presidential Palace was viewed only from a distance: no interior access when we were there. Gardens surrounding this area are really lovely and look like a local favorite. Leads to the One Pillar Pagoda. Takes about an hour or so. There is a fee.
Fascinating relic. Intersting to see all the historical relics of Ho Chi Minh. Obviously venerated by Vietnamese even today. Watch out for the cannibal carp..they will have your finger off!

Not worth a visit. After visiting the Museum of Ethnology earlier in the day this was a huge let down. We only visited as the mausoleum was closed. The most positive thing I can say is that the grounds were well kept.There is very little information provided so you are not going to learn anything about Ho Chi Minh himself.You cannot go inside the palace or any other buildings. You can look at the cars given to Ho Chi Minh which are behind glass and through windows into his main residence (which was not the palace). A lot of the grounds are closed off and you will be whistled at or yelled at by the many guards if you step out of line!I'd save your money and go elsewhere.

Nice gardens and interesting history. Not a lot here really, when you get down to it, but it is a historical spot in a nice area. It's all quite well-kept and the propaganda is worth reading. An interesting hour out of you Hanoi day.

Serene Palace. What a lovely site to explore Ho Chi Minh's way of life for 15 years. It was so simple and peaceful walking around the pond, gardens, living quarters and orchard. You could sense his modesty and humbleness for life by visiting this complex.
Might as well see it. If you're already there for the mausoleum you might as well check out the car collection and private quarters of Ho Chi Minh. I wouldn't call it a must see.

the presidential palace. located in the same huge complex as the mausoleum, the outside facade in yellow coloured stone is very eye catching. hidden by trees from some places, visitors are not allowed to go inside. it provides for a good photo opportunity.

Interesting to visit . You need to queue to see this. Visitors can only view the outside. This was not Ho Chi Minhs actual residence as he lived in the more modest building next door. Good French architecture with a bit of Vietnamese. Worth visiting.

Go early for a better experience. Didn't manage to get into the Mausoleum because of the super long queues that would have taken 2 hours. Schoolkids get priority. Quite a lot of history to the place and I learnt quite a bit about Ho Chi Minh. Thought it quite sad that according to the guide, Ho Chi Minh's wish was to be cremated but his body is pumped with chemicals in order to be put on display :( So go early if you want to beat the crowds.

Really not much too see unless you have a deep fascination with the history. Really not much too see unless you have a deep fascination with the history. The guide shows you the house from a distance and shares some insights. Really not worth it

Visit if convenient. If you have a reasonable amount of time in hanoi, and have walked around the old quarter, hen a good walk around this area will take you past the palace, the mausoleum, the one pagoda etc
Interesting Insight. Learnt a bit about the history of vietnam. Interesting insight seeing the cars used back then as well as where Ho Chi Minh lived.

Beautiful but can't go in.. Really beautiful building that sadly is closed to the public completely.The colors and design are really amazing and it is a shame that it is impossible to even get closer.
past splendor. the building is a museum now but the site of many treaties and negotiation's many fine materials used

Recommended, Interesting. This site shows the simple, frugal housing and office for Ho Chi Minh. The grand yellow French buildings were used by the French and Ho lived them for 4 years before moving into the more modest house. It is a stilt house across the lake from the grand house where he ate his meals. His personal bunker is next to the stilt house. It is very crowded - kept in lines by uniformed guards. Paid about 40 000 VND to enter the grounds where the Presidential Palace was located, after the visit to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Take some photos. You can't enter the grand palace. Interesting to see for historical reasons. Recommended.

Asian Tourist trap. I understand that the government wants to uphold the cult of Ho Chi Minh for legitimacy reasons. They did a good job at showing his workplace, his cars, etc. But the historical and cultural value of this attraction is very low. Ho Chi Minh was a simple guy and did not want to be honoured this way. He even wanted to be cremated. He'd frown at the tourist shops on the site. Don't go. A waste of 40k VND.

Worth including on your city walk tour of Hanoi. Beautiful French style buildling - very impressive architecture and design and very regal. We couldn't go in, but just walked by and appreciated its beauty.

Nothing much. Theres really nothing much.Entrance tix cost 30k or 40k vnd (dollar value not expensive). There were a few exhibits but i only remember this place as - a park. A pity the yellow building is not for visiting.
Hanoi. Interesting view back in time, with references to several historical important periods in time for them

A must see. This has to be seen on a visit to Hanoi. 7 million people go there every year. It only takes a few minutes to walk around the tomb but the rest of the complex is also interesting...the Ho Chi Minh house, Presidential Palace etc.
Interesting. We only had an opportunity to visit the grounds as the Palace was off limits. We received a lot of information about the grounds
very interesting. Excellent place of interest, highly recommended. Would suggest a local guide to assist with interesting points of the tour.

Good to see but not necessary. Paid about 40 000 VND to enter the grounds where the Presidential Palace was located, after the visit to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. Palace was very quaint and charming, and is good to visit because you can walk around the palace grounds and take some photos. But not a must-see because you can only admire it from afar, and you can't enter the palace. Downside of the trip was that there were many schoolchildren (many schools decided to bring their students on an excursion on the same day of my visit), so it was very noisy and crowded - which can't be helped.
WORTH THE TRIP. Very good tour. Worth doing a tour so you can hear about the history of the Palace and all the rooms and what they were used for. Recommended.
nice. you can't go inside the palace, but all the park, and all the different buildings are really nice to see!! you learn a lot too!

The Presidential Palace where Ho Chi Minh Never Lived!. The Presidential Palace is a building where Ho Chi Minh never lived! It is an architecturally impressive French-era building which Ho Chi Minh preferred to use for meeting and entertaining dignitaries and important foreign guests.

Nice place to visit. The presedential palace is worth the money and time.
It's quite interesting to walk around in the gardens.
Time : Take 1 to 2 hours to visit the palace
Review of Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace. This information on this at site hardly any. Further, you cannot go near the premise. You look from afar.
Intresting . The diffrence between cultures in countries is really interesting and I enjoy it . The history and special structures in each city can be wonderful ofcourse if you are interested in...

A beautiful, natural setting -- worth an hour or so. The Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace is set in a beautiful, natural setting and well worth the 40,000 VND price of admission and an hour or so of your time.I traveled alone, not with a guided tour and appreciated the site at face value, augmented with some reading on the site and Minh himself from Wikipedia as I wove through the gardens, pond and buildings on the property. A must see in Hanoi and conveniently located adjacent to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum.
Must see. This is most interesting historically and politically. It is also a beautiful garden and lake complex you can stroll in. Well worth the visit

Fascinating insight into Ho's life. Interesting French colonial buildings and the gardens where Ho walked and lived. Cars on display that were given by the Soviet Union as well as his trusty Peugeot .. good cafe area to sit and refresh!
Walked past it.. No way to get in. . Certainly an interesting old palace to look at but we just walked past it and see if from afar as it is not open to the public.
Presidential Palace tour. Nice place to visit and learn about Vietnamese history from knowledgeable tour guides at the location. A must visit while in Hanoi.
Inspiring. Interesting place which shows and explains the way Ho Chi Min lived and passed away during the Viet Nam war.

Guided tour essential. We were taken around the complex with a private guide who gave us all the background to the three houses on the site and the Buddhist temple. Don't walk around without a guide or you'll miss a lot.
Enjoy it, clean and beautifull. Walkable distance from benh tanh market, this place surrounded this amazing view and historical building, one of the best spot to take picture in ho chi minh

For the History Buff in You. Just like the Hanoi Hilton and Ho Chi Minh monument this is a Must Do on any tourist's list. Allow about 2 hours time to fully understand and appreciate the significance of this palace in the country's history and politics.

Magnificient Building. It's a magnificient building constructed by french architecture, Auguste Henri Vildieu, the official French architect for French Indochina. Like most French Colonial architecture, the palace is pointedly European.ted in Hanoi. You will be amazing when you look the building. Plan your day to visit this building, because it closed on monday.

Interesting . Fascinating place to visit
The bunkers below were fascinating
Not too many people
Not wheelchair friendly
...........

If you are into the history of Vietnam then it is a must. We visited this venue with two university students who explained everything that we saw, and of course being able to tap into them about this area was invaluable. The Presidential Palace is only the office of the President and Vice President, they continue the tradition of Ho Chi Minh by neithe rof them living there, although it is here that foreign dignitaries are met on official visits. In the immediate area are all matters to do with Ho Chi Minh, e.g. where he was housed, the cars he used, and where he was cared for in his last days; all very poignant. It is an interesting place to go but better with a guide to give you the background to what you are looking at.

Interesting and important piece of Viet Nam history. The Presidential Palace area includes several important buildings relevant to Ho Chi Minh's role in Viet Nam's history. In addition to the Presidential Palace, his office and living quarters in House No.54 (from 1954-58), and the house on stilts where he lived from 1958-69. Also on the grounds are beautiful gardens that HCM planted and cared for himself. Additionally, the masses of Vietnamese visitors stands as a tribute to their continued devotion to their beloved leader.

Part Of Vietnamese History. The building is very french in its style and is one that has plenty of history behind it. Not allowed inside we had to be satisfied with admiring the architecture and admire we did.
Alright place to visit. Only allow to see the place from the outside. Nice french architecture building. It was crowded during our August visit but it was a nice walk.

HISTORICAL PLACE. It is a must to visit. Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is seldom open (only 2 hour 2-3 days a week so hard to catch the opening time but to visit his home to see how he lived is very interesting.

Historical building. The presidential palace is a splendid building depicting typical french architecture.Unfortunately visitors are not allowed inside.The surrounding garden and water pools are well kept and maintained.Cool and serene atmosphere.Guided tour to the old house of Ho Chi Minh ,office,bunker and the presidential vintage cars were most fascinating

Fascinating insight. A visit to the offices and houses inhabited by the great man serves to remind you of the very simple and frugal existence practised by Ho Chi Minh. The initial yellow and grand French buildings were lived in for only 4 years before he decided to live in a more ethnic building. His people dutifully built a house on stilts across the lake where he continued to be served his meals which were prepared and cooked from the French house. Do not miss the personal bunker situated right next to his ethnic house, accessed through his guard's building. The green low building next to the house on stilts was built for his medical team. An interesting visit if you can stand crowds - kept in orderly queues by uniformed guards!

HCM Presidential Palace. The building itself is not open to the public but visitors can walk around the garden and see President Ho Chi Minh's house-on-stilts and the famous Uncle Ho Fishpond that are also within the premises. The attraction is part of the Ha Noi City Tour and visitors will realise why the Vietnamese love President HCM so much.

Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace. The complex is very nice with all buildings built in yellow. He lived a simple life with nothing lavish. It is a nice insight. There are a lot of souvenir shops, food and drinks also sold in the complex. Worth a visit.

Lovely view. You can only see this from the outside. It is a nice building but not so much to do here. It is on the way into the sights so you will see it if you go to the One Pillar Pagoda and the rest.
Simply beautiful. It was a beautiful day when we visited here and truly enjoyable and our guide was so knowledgable where all questions were answered .
Too small.. You aren't shown much. Go, look at pictures on the Internet, you won't see more in real life site. You can't enter any of the building, you're basically glimpsing inside through doors.

Nice walk in the park. The palace itself isn't open to the public but there's lots to see on the grounds including Ho Chi Minh's living quarters and stilt house, nice gardens and a little lake. They do close the gates at 11 for a 2 hour lunch so plan your trip accordingly. Entrance fee is 25,000 VND. Outside the gates, there are several souvenir stands, a little temple and the Ho Chi Minh museum and mausoleum. You could easily spend hours in this peaceful setting. Apparently there are botanical gardens in the area too, but I couldn't find the access.

Wonderful visit. A beautiful yellowish- orange colour building. President Ho Chi Minh palace or the place he lived his last few years. Cross the gate to see the garage with 3 old cars and then cross the garden through Mango road to approach the building. Many rooms with simple furniture. A nice lake with many fishes. Few shops, juice stalls and my favourite sugarcane juice with a nice sugarcane girls.

It was ok. A beautiful building - but only available to view from an awkward side angle. It would have been great to see from the inside or at least the front. The whole park is a bit of a gimmick - you basically are only allowed to walk around a lake.. I would not have walked all the way there if I knew this in advance - with that said the entrance fee is like 2 USD so maybe its worth it? Not on my top ten list.

Worth checking out this place, its very serene. You aren't able to go inside the Presidential palace as its only for state visits, but you can see the building in all its splendour from outside. But you are able to visit Ho Chi Mihn's stilt house, and the house that he lived in. Its just behind the mausoleum.

Very Interesting . It was a very interesting place to visit. When everyone filed past Ho Chi Mihns body in total silence you could feel the respect this man still gains. Even after death. The grounds are beautiful and the architecture of the palace is awesome.

Father of Vietnam - Ho Chi Minh. This is a location which involves a lot of walking, take a hat for the sun and water for drinking. Well preserved and historical information about Ho Chi Minh, he appeared to be a humble man of the people who battles many years for an independent Vietnam to be rejoined. He did not live to see his vision come together.

Nothing much to see really. Ho Chi Minh didn't live in this palace, he lived in stilt house on the other side of the pond, next to it you can find the mango tree path. Plan before you enter as there are lots of 'one way street' for eg you should visit the mango tree trial before the stilt house, since the stilt house path leads only to the exit.

Visit Hero of the People President Ho Chi Minh. 1. Q in line at entrance (a few)2. Security checks3, Orderly move in line 4. Ladies short wear knee length skirts - mark of respect - no shorts please5. wonderful to step onto the grounds of the past

Beautiful garden was worth seeing. This garden is right beside the mausoleum and has a small charge to see it. Great for photos , was worth seeing especially as the mausuleum was over in a flash after quite a long queu. This made the visit worth the time.

A bit dissapointed.. i paid for nothing!. We only able to visit the outer part of the house.. only paid entrance fee to walk around the garden and lake.. felt like my money was being wasted.. definitely wont be coming again.. enough seeing only from the outside

Tranquil Escape. Come here just at the end of the day, just before closing. Most of the crowds will have left, and you can tackle it at your own pace. Definitely compares drastically to the reality of Hanoi and is an eye opening experience in both experiencing Ho Chi Minhs life and the grandiose luxury he lived in.
Nice. Could not go in but a very beautiful building with nice surroundings. It was nice to just wander around outside and the history is also very interesting.
Very attractive building. The palace is a very attractive French colonial building. The area around the building is kept very neat and clean. We were on an organised tour and didn't go inside.
Gorgeous. Really nice place to visit and wander around, it's a beautiful building and the grounds are very nice as well

Ho Chin Minh Mausoleum. This is the starting place to tour the city. Closes at 11 am , not certain why. So tourists who arrive after 11 am by any flight would be shown only the building and will not get a chance to see the embalmed body. The queue is about 1 km long but it moves . So it will take about one hour from the time you join the queue until you exit. Do not skip this as everywhere you will see Ho Chin Minh `s photos, especially near schools.
Presidential Palace. Though unable to enter the Palace, it is still a very impressive building, dating to the French occupation, I believe.
Beautiful. This is a must visit site. Beautiful buildings and surrounds. Well kept gardens and lake and an easy walk around the different areas - Ho Chi Mins house and his card

Interesting area... This was an interesting area, though Ho Chi Minh never lived in the Presidential Palace, but we toured the two modest places he did live..very interesting..and the area was beautiful..
sight seeing. The museum is well maintained. Although there is not much to see the place well designed to attract tourists.

A simple life. Although the 'Mango Palace' was available for Ho Chi Minh to use, he choose much simpler quarters. In the grounds of the site you can see where he lived and worked, cars given to him by the Soviets and New Caledonia (!), as well as beautiful gardens. Having a guide would be useful, as there are many aspects that were pointed out to us that we would have missed without our guide. For example, the bougainvillea was planted as it is the 'mother's plant'. Just a little tidbit that intrigued us.Regardless of your political views, it is an amazing site to visit.
Opulence. We loved all the statuaries..not all the rooms were opened for viewing. I would have loved to have seen more rooms with an escort.

A Place to Walk by.... You can only look at it from the outside. This french Building is well kept, but only used for ceremonies and State Guests. As you walk by when visiting the Mausoleum and HCM's house where he actually lived and worked (very humble Place!), it is OK. We could not get any information, how it really looks from the inside...

A worthwhile stroll. The Palace was part of our city tour and was a short walk from Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum. We only got to view form the outside but still it was as impressive building. Part of the tour took us through gardens of the Palace and some sites fro Ho Chi Minh's years as President.

Very Interesting History and Beautiful Gardens. During our stay in Hanoi we spent a couple of hours visiting the Presidential Palace and Gardens. The palace is right next to the mausoleum which was closed when we visited but anyway I am not sure I would have wanted to queue in scorching heat for a few hours just to see Uncle Ho's body.The Presidential Palace itself is a beautiful building, however you cannot go inside it. But you can walk around the extensive gardens and see the little house that Ho Chi Minh chose to live in, shunning the luxury of the place. The house is preserved exactly as it was in Ho's time with old furniture and pones etc and you can get a very good feel of what it was like as he was leading his country from there. You can also see the vintage cars that he was given as gifts. The Gardens themselves are also lovely, with lakes and some very interesting trees and plants. Though it was a very hot day the gardens are quite cool and you can see why Ho chose to spend so much of his time here.Overall I would say that this a definite must see if you visit Hanoi.

Must See. This is one of those must-see locations you have to see when visiting Hanoi. It provides and interesting explanation of Ho Chi Minh’s life and accurately reflects the admiration/adoration many Vietnamese feel towards this man.
Insight. We took this palace in during our walking tour. There is a lot of history around the place. Interesting chance to see where Ho Chi Minh spent his last days. Was busy when I was there
INTERESTING HISTORICALLY. I am not a fan of politics past or present but since this was one of the recommended sights I visited it out of respect to my host.

Very impressive. I had just left the mosoleum area and wandered into this building. I didn't think you could get into it because of security presence. The building is extremely impressive and I do recommend going in if possible.
Pretty gardens.. We visited because the mausoleum was closed. Nice gardens but crowded and not a lot to see. Only really see from the side as access restricted.
Very beautiful place! Next to mausoleum.. Sometimes missed by tourists but it's just next to the mausoleum and it's very beautiful and interesting. A must and in my Hanoi top three.

Very Nice Site. We got to see French Colonial architecture all painted a mustard yellow. Very nice. We also walked around the gardens of the compound, saw the Presidential Palace, Ho Chi Minh's stilt house and his cars. Beautiful peaceful place. Well worth the trip. We saw Minh's Mausoleum from the outside. Inside was closed. But I don't think we missed much.
Looks grand.. You are not allowed inside so take the picture from afar and shove off! :) There are nearby attractions like Ho's more modest accomodations, cars, lake etc.

nice to see. when I was there it was not open to the public, not sure if it ever is as it is still used, any building in Vietnam that is pained the golden colour is a government building and usually you cannot get in

Beautiful site with great insights. While you can't go inside of the Presidential Palace, walking the grounds is quite interesting. I noticed a few tour groups, with guides providing great insights. We didn't do any prior research and chose to self-navigate. In hindsight, we should've read up!Highlights include the coy fish pond, Stilt House (where Ho Chi Minh resided), and the Presidential Palace from afar. Entrance fee is VND$30k, easily worth it.
Elegant. Right at the heart of the city, and very easily accessible. The maintenance of the place is simply awesome.

Ho Chi Minh's Home & Park Area. So much to see in the surrounding area including the resting place of Ho in his mausoleum and the French Governors residence he never used. Beautiful building colourful, a pond full of carp and garden well looked after around his house specially built to make Ho feel he was with this people. A must to visit whilst in Hanoi.

Beautiful Architecture and Grounds. Nestled amongst the green trees and beautiful grounds stands the grand Presidential Palace. Unfortunately it is closed to the public but people can get a good view of this building built in the early 1900s through the surrounding trees. HCM was never comfortable living in this luxurious setting, preferring to live in his famous stilt house also on the site, but the Palace is used for official receptions. The rest of the site including substantial grounds, pond, vintage cars and the stilt house is definitely worth the visit to this site.

grand. HCM is like a god in this country despite he had passed on. government has to spend lots of resources to look after museums, palaces, memorial halls etc which named after him. this is just another typical example.
Okay point of interest. The contrast between the mausoleum and the modest HCM garden home is striking. Quiet moment in this city. Little Lotus temple okay for the infertiles

Grand and very yellow. Grand palace with a bright yellow paint would look better in white , grounds very pretty and peaceful, could not go inside but saw the other more basic wooden accommodation, and office
Must see. This is a must see to believe it. You can't bring cameras, cell phones into the historical site. There's people guiding you to view Ho Chi Minh.
Beautiful building. Can only see this building from outside. No access inside. It is very nice and very european looking. We walked in front of the building and were able to take pictures.

Well maintained French architecture. The sign says "no photograph" but everyone does. this impressive building from the French era is no longer the Presidential Palance and is used for formal State functions

An emotional visit: Mr Hochiminh President seemed to live forever with Vietnamese peolpe. Ho Chi Minh loved to fish, every morning was approaching the Lake and was eating the fish. To do so, Ho Chi Minh City first gave palmas and then, gave bread crumbs and other food to the fish in the pond.The fish pond if we attend palms, waiting for food. That is the reason why you will find groups of tourists clapping along the lake, and some clever salesman, selling bags of breadcrumbs to tourists.

Beautiful. Bright yellow, gaurded and well maintained palace surrounded by pretty gardens and smaller houses/quarters. The palace is conveniently located next to the mausoleum, so you should definitely drop by after checking out the mausoleum. We had to stand pretty far away from the palace. The experience would have been a lot better if we were allowed to go inside. The entrance fee is very cheap and costs around VND 20,000-25,000.

Stunning Grounds. The gardens on the grounds are worth it on their own. I'm not normally someone to rave about something such as well kept grounds but it was beautiful. There is a lot of security around so we did feel like we were being very closely watched.

Come to Vietnam, let's go to Historical Museum. You know, Vietnam used to win both French and Americans therefore, our history is rich; that's why I strongly recommend you to visit this museum. The ticket is less than $1. But the knowledge and what you learn from this museum is very useful to understand our history as well as culture.

Bringing history to life.. The grounds which contained the Palace included various buildings of interest, gardens and connecting paths. With the descriptions, one could get a feel for what life was like during Ho Chi Minh's influence in uplifting his people.

Very beautiful building. The buildings that belong to government are very well maintained with a lot of security staff around the ground's outside. They aren't to friendly and not very helpful when asking what the buildings are and there use.
cheap. very cheap only 1 usd but I did not like those places very socialist stylealso cannot get inside like other palaces, only see it from the outside
Ho Chi Minh Palace. Very interesting to see and although not a long visit gives a flavour of Ho Chi Minhs commitment to the basics of communism.
Nice gardens. Nice to have a walk in it gardens, has a small house where you can see how they lived back then. Near the mausoleum.

Well maintained, good cultural experience. It was good to see the way he lived. the houses and surrounding area was pretty well maintained. There are a lot of Vietnamese tourists as well and you can see how much Vietnamese people love and respect him.

A very regal residence, lovely gardens. Presidetial Palace is a very impressive building set behind intricate gates and surrounded by guards. I got too close to the gates to take a pix and was asked to move back.Entry to the grounds is a very reasonable 25 vnd. Acess to certain parts of the grounds is restricted as is going off the path, Guards blow whistles to move you back on track.Definitely worth the nominal entrance fee to meander around the lovely gardens. You can also walk through the house on stilts as well as see into where Ho Chin Minh had meetings etc.The Ho Chi Min mausoleum and museum is very near by as well as the single pillar pagoda so lots to see in this part of town
Nice buildings surrounded by well maintained greenery.. Not really impressive but a nice contrast to the mausoleum nearby. If you are around for the mausoleum I would have a look, too.

Nice place for a wonder. When we visited the mausoleum was closed, but the walk around the grounds including the presidential palace and the various buildings Ho Chi Minh lived in was interesting. The grounds were well kept, and the area around the Mausoleum has plenty going on its a good meeting place.
wonderful place. Wonderful monument . U must keep up time or else u cannot access this place. Very scenic and lots of trees . U can also feed the fishes in the pond in the campus.

It is a must see part of Vietnamese History & HO CHI MIN. This is where Ho Chi Min lived from late late 1954 to 1969.The Mausoleum is located in the centre of Ba Dinh Square, which is where Ho Chi Minh, Chairman of the Communist Party of Vietnam from 1951 until his death in 1969, read the Declaration of Independence in September 1945.There is a dress code and code of conduct for those wanting to visit the Mausoleum which is strictly enforced by staff and guards.No shorts or miniskirts are allowed and visitors must be silent. Smoking, drinking, eating, photography and handphones are also not permitted anywhere inside the mausoleum.

Holiday in Vietnam & Cambodia with friends. We visited in a large group with our tour guide.Very interesting place where the Vietnam war was finished by the arrival of the Northern army into Hanoi.Lots of beautiful rooms to see + the basement bunkers.

Closed. The day we visited the museum sadly it was closed ,We were not able to go to the Mausoleum as Ho Chi Minh had gone to Russia for a vacation,But still the mausoleum and surrounding area is a very impressive site to walk around

A knowledgeable visit. Nice to see how Ho Chi Minh lived a simple life. There is a beautiful lake in the middle of the complex which he would often visit to catch a break from his routine activities. Was good to learn more about him.

Great if you are interested in Ho Chi Minh's life. If you are interested in the life of Ho Chi Minh, this site is an excellent place to see the humble life he lived and worked in this living museum. He never lived in the palace itself, but in a couple of small houses nearby, the second one being a stilt house. If, however, you are not interested in Uncle Ho, it may not be for you, although it does have the One Pillar pagoda which is well worth seeing.
Interesting. Little bit of an eye opener into the life of ho chi minh, realise how little we know of the man himself. Stunning gardens

Home of revered statesman. This large campus of buildings was built for Ho Chi Minh, Vietnamese Statesman and President. His body lies in state in the mausoleum. The stilt house where he lived, meeting rooms, and other aspects of his life, including a bomb shelter, are on display.
Day visit. Another great place to visit while you are there , but try to avoid lunch time from 12-2 pm as they close for lunch .
Nice historical place. Nice historical place to visit but when it's summer it's too hot! Wearing shorts or sleeveless are not allowed inside too

great place, great guide. Our guide from hanoikids gave fantastic explanations of all the sites to see in this complex. One must not DIY this place as all you will see are physical objects without really appreciating its historical context. Like why the building is in that color? Or when president ho chi minh was alive, the palace was used more to greet the children, or how he used the three cars on display, with one car he never rode in, or the reason why the house on stilts did not have any toilet. And there were a lot others the guide mentioned that provided a complete and colorful commentary of the whole place.Also walking around the shades provided by the big century old trees is a contrast to the searing heat walking around the open area in front of the mausoleum.
A must visit!. Aside from the clean surroundings, the place itself is a landmark one must visit when in Hanoi aside from the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum beside it.

An interesting and historically relevant place to visit. Very interesting view of life before the North won the war. Gives a feel for the excesses at the time and a view of history by going to the basement and seeing the old equipment.
Visit by group. You will pass the Maseoleum & enter the gate to the Palace ground to enjoy the Palace building gold outlook, vintage cars & garden bonsai. A good visit if in Hanoi.

Nice french style house and gardens. The Palace and its surrounding area are well worth a visit. We could not get in but all the features together make this worthy of a visit.It does cross over with other reviews. We were not able to go inside.

A Piece of History. An interesting insight into Vietnamese history where East meets West from the Presidential Palace to the house on stilts. Ho Chi Min did not live in the palace but rather in the gardener's cottage to symbolize his communism. Two cars given to Uncle Ho from Russia in 1954 and 1955 are on display as well as one given to him in 1964 from the Vietnamese residents of French New Caledonia. The walk around the lake is also very pleasant.
interesting complex. So much to see at this sight , from Ho Chi Minh`s Mausoleum and his stilt house to the One Pillar Pagoda,it is easy to spend the morning there.
Interesting. Been here twice and really enjoy walking around. Well established and maintained gardens. Worth to take the time to visit

Relaxing place to see. Came here around 10am and was done by 12pm. It was very peaceful and good to see the history of the president. There is also a temple you can see, no shorts. Many other visitors in this area.

Vietnam visit. The Presidential place is a good place to be visited by tourist, although it was not open at the time of our visit but we could see the Vietnam's Parliament house and statue of Ho Chi Minh and watching the change of guards was a good experience.

Beautiful setting. A beautiful setting for a spectacular French colonial building. We went with a guide who was able to explain all about Ho Chi Minh's life, which made it much more interesting than going on our own. The gardens and water features make this a beautiful site. Very interesting to see the actual house where he lived for 4 years, after refusing to move into the palace, and the mountain house on stilts that he had built to remind him of his home in the mountains.

East Meets West. The place gives you a small insight into the history; the place is clean and tranquil. There seems a strange paradox, when you are walking out, that they are selling all this tat, and stuff with his face on. Capitalism and communism hand in hand
Refurbishment. Sadly closed the day we arrived for 2 month refurbishment. Did however go to Ho Ch Minh Mausoleum. Very very interesting.
Interesting piece of history. Definitely worth a visit beautiful gardens and history of Vietnam. This will give you an insite into Ho Chi Minh and what he meant to Vietnam and its people
Worth a visit !. This place carry a lot of history about Uncle Ho, from the cars he used to the rooms he used during his presidency.
Opulance from a gone by era. The presidential Palace demonstrates the opulence desired by the French who occupied Vietnam for a century. The palace and the gardens are worth seeing. An eye opener

Grand Palace and gardens. A must see in Hanoi. You can see the mummified body of President Ho Chi Minh here. Lovely presidential palace with gardens and ponds. Lots of memorabilia which was used by president Ho Chi Minh, including his home, cars etc. Must see when in Hanoi

Yeah, you gotta go!. If for no other reason it is the seat of their government and the grounds are nice. You get a little bit of history, but mostly you can take in the sites and rub elbows with many local people. We were fortunate enough to meet a Presidential guard (the ones in the white uniforms) that spoke English and took a liking to our daughter, what a nice young man. He gave us some insight only garnered by the locals.
President house, vietnam. Father of Vietnam is still Ho chi minh. One man how he did a difficult job to make the country independent

Interesting. While in Hanoi we did a guided day tour which included the Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace Historical Site. Our Guide told that the Presidential Place was originally built for the Indochina General Governor. He said Ho Chi Minh was offered to live in the Place but he declined saying it was to opulent, and he wanted to live more like the people, hence the Stilt house was built.The Presidential Palace is not open for the public, but you can walk around the grounds and view the Gardens, The Stilt House and cars that were given to Ho Chi Minh.
interesting piece of history.. was great to wander around palatial grounds, history is always fascinating. very grand for the time and some old cars to see, beautiful gardens as you wander around.
Disappointing!. Once again, we were not allowed inside, only able to walk around the outside. Apparently, it is never open to the public. Very disappointing!

Take a tour into the father of the Vietnamese revolution. Right next to Ho Chi Minh mausoleum, one can find the palace where he was supposed to live (he declined, with the argument that it was too luxurious), the smaller house where he in did lived, with a few cars and some items of his daily life. An interesting visit.
Beautifull and peacefull. Beautiful palace, with a strong yellow collor. On the back of the Palace a beautifull lake and the real place where lived... peacefull despite the huge numbers of visitors.
Historic. This was also on our guided walking tour. The architecture and surrounding areas were kept immaculate. Very informative tour.
Beautiful Building. Beautiful building from the outside and right next to Ho Chi Minh mausoleum. Good photo opportunity of a beautiful building.
Historical site. This site is a must for visitors to Ha noi. Very interested to learn about the history and culture of the country.

Impressive. Only looked from the outside and didn't want to get too close or appear too interested as there were guards around and wasn't sure of what we could do but it was an impressive building and well kept

Peaceful oasis. Another area worth exploring when you go to Ba dinh square and see ho chi Minh's mausoleum - the gardens and presidential palace area and specifically uncle ho's actual residence - you can see why he didn't want to live in the big palace. Enjoy the gardens too and the beautiful embassy buildings in the streets nearby. Also take in the Ho Chi Minh musuem nearby.
Beautiful grounds. a wonderful place, beautiful and peaceful, to escape the craziness of the city, great for walking around, and relaxing.

A worthwhile sight. This place is obviously a museum nowadays, but it certainly shows a great deal history for this leader and country with a rich history. You can see everything from the meeting rooms to the living rooms to the bunker-esque basements. It really is a White House of the East.

Worth a visit. Excellent grounds to walk around, steeped in Ho Chi Minh history. Well worth a look around with guide to explain the history. Beautiful architecture in this lavish looking building, although we couldn't go inside. Ho chi mines residence was very very basic, it seems he was a simple man with simple tastes

Walking through . We visited the day before their national day 2/9 and queued up at 750am. It took about 30 mins in the queue for a walk through the mausoleum. We then went through the gardens palace and museum. It was a but if an issue getting out as there were a lot of roads closed with no access points. But well worth the trip.
Presidential Palace Ho Chi Minh. enjoyed this glimpse into the life of Ho Chi Minh, learning what kind of man he was, looking at the home he lived in, very good attraction

very well kept.It was impressive sight and Father Ho deserves such a respect.. It was a great pity that you cannot visit inside. I was not sure that because it was a Sunday so that we cannot visit or because we were foreigners.

nice. good to be there. i am happy to hear the history of ho chi minh.. and how he fought for his people.. and. won the war.. i also wish that the people of BIAFRA LAND IN WEST AFRICA will also get there freedom from the hands of USA AND UK

The Yellow Palace. The Presidentual palace in Ho Chi Minh is called also a yellow palace when i heard it from the local. Maybe no need to have tour guide in this area from palace to one pillar pagoda to museum and flag tower and other nearby historical places.

Unique experience with the propaganda filled tour.. Interesting to see the grounds and hear the tour guides talk about Ho Chi Minh. It was kind of fascinating. Not much to really see except the grounds and some buildings that you can't go inside. Not really worth a stop but if you have the time sure.

Colonial magnificence. Leftover from French colonial times, this is a truly magnificent building. Set amongst lush gardens, it is impossible to miss an give a stark contrast to the simple accommodation favoured by Ho Cho Minh.
A must see. I enjoyed our guided tour of Ho Chi Minh's garden and simple houses. It was great to learn more about the man who is so loved in Viet Nam and who shaped its recent history.
Interesting. Interesting day visit to the presidential palace and getting involve with all the important histories in mind.

Nice Park and you learn a bit about Ho Chi Minh. You can walk around the park and if you avoid groups it is somehow quite in opposite to the rest of the city. So you can calm down and have a look on Ho Chi Minhs Garden House, his cars and teh palace.
So if you are around Ho's Mausoleum it is worth to come around.

Private. The building is visible from the gate.
There are guards at the entrance, impossible to approach and photograph it. Nice Palace.
Amazing place. This is another must see, such spectacular history here and you can see everything that has gone on in. Viet Nam since before the war.

Simple building with rich history. Originally the home of the French Governor General, it's most famous occupant was Ho Chi Minh. While the main house itself is closed to visitors, there are a number of historic sites. Be sure to download an audio guide to get the most out of this place.
la foule. crowdy . So many people walking here but for us nothing especial. So we crossed it. The pagoda special is just behind

Dont miss it. This will give you real insight into a different time of Vietnam, and shouldn't be missed if you want to understand the people a little more etc. You can see a loyt but note if you want to HCM himself you need to arrive early am.
Ho Chi Minh complex. Great place to go with a guide to give you all the necessary information, beautiful gardens but busy.

The palace grounds, includes HCM's house on stilts, located behind the Mausoleum! Truly worth visiting!. Behind Ho Chi Minh’s Mausoleum is a humble stilt house, where Ho lived intermittently from 1958 to 1969. The house is an interpretation of a traditional rural dwelling, and has been preserved just as Ho left it. It’s set in a well-tended garden next to a carp-filled pond. There is a display of ‘Ho Chi Minh’s automobiles he used during his life.In stark contrast to the understated stilt house is the imposing Presidential Palace, a beautifully restored colonial building constructed in 1906 as the Palace of the Governor General of Indochina. It is now used for official receptions and isn’t open to the public.Worth visiting!

Basic Intro to Ho Chi Minh - but limited options. Not a lot to see - the main house is closed (well, at least it was on the Monday that we went)... leaving just some parts of the grounds to wander through. That said, the outside of the house is very impressive - and some of the buildings in the grounds serve as a good introduction to the life and times Ho Chi Minh
Definitely a must if you visit Hanoi. The grounds are meticulously cared for, and you can see HO Chi Minh's residence where he lived and worked.
Big place, but few parts available to visit.. . We liked this so much, but we feel as if there's much more to visit... In any case it's nice to visit and quite cheap (25k dongs)

A quick history lesson. Very insightful tour. Learn why the Vietnamese hold their founding father in such high regards. Ho Chi Minh's life work on display here with detailed explanation on how he fought for the independence of his country. And of course, the complex is air-conditioned. What's not to like. Time well spent!

Interesting - but that's about it. Interest look at the residence of Ho Chi Minh. He was an interesting chap. There isn't an awful lot to do but its worth a wander around the impressive gardens and have a look at how he lived. Unfortunately you can't go into the main palace but can the other houses.

Visit to Ho Chi Minh Complex. A must do in Hanoi. The old French Governirs mansion, Ho Chi Minh's modest accommodation, HCM's cars, the Mausoleum etc are both great history and an insight into modern Vietnam's origins.

Tranquil. We visited the grounds of the palace and stilt house of Ho Chi Minh. We arrived at 11 am. Apparently that was the time they close the grounds , so we only managed to spend about 15 mins walking around. Better go earlier so you can get more time. As it was closing the place was quiet , feeling of tranquility as compared to the noisy blaring horns n hustle n bustle of life outside.

Part of half day city tour. We visited here as part of the buffalo half day city tour of Hanoi, but, the area was cordoned off so we could only see the outside.
It was an old French colonial building.

Palace and site of Ho Chi Minhs house. Visited here recently after visiting Ho Chi Minhs Musoleum with a tour guide.The Palace isnt open to the public but a lovely example of a french provincial building. Proceeded through the site where beautiful gardens,lake and houses built by the french in the 19th century.Within the grounds is the stilt house where Ho Chi Minh lived and worked. Lovely surroundings but the crowds were huge as it was a weekend, one of only two days of the week that the Musoleum is open to the public.Small entrance fee,wheelchair accessible apart from Ho,s house.Gift shop's, and snack bars on site. We both enjoyed the site and best visited in conjunction with the Musoleum. (If you find this review helpful please tick the box tks )
Must see when in Hanoi. Really nice to see how Ho Chi Minh has lived. A must see when you visit Hanoi. Especially the houses he lived in. Not the Palace.
Ok. This place is ok maybe better with a guide kinda got ushered here after visiting Ho Chi Mins body next door.... Nice gardens was really busy too

Fascinating. A huge plot of land with beautiful landscapes. There's nothing much to see inside except for meeting rooms and more meeting rooms (just that with different furniture & deco) It's basically where the president used to stay. Can finish walking around inside in 15 minutes..

Mostly closed due to preparations for Vietnam independence day. We paid a lot for a half day Hanoi tour through our hotel, but they neglected to tell us that the Ho Chi Minh resendence would be closed. Our guide seemed to be suprised.
If you love history, this is a good one. Don't wear sleeveless or else the guards won't let you in. It's gonna be hot, so wear something casual, not adviced to wear heels as walking is expected

Presidential palace. 25.000 vnd to enter which is about 1.50 nzdollarSee the palace. House on Stilts. Very busy all the time. Be mindful lots of school trips are planned for this palace.You maybe behind a long queue of children
pres palace. very nice my older son liked the historical tanks in front and seeing a part of history was pretty cool even if it is not a happy part of history still very cool

Well worth a visit. While I was intrigued by the experience of visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum I found walking through the presidential palace grounds and visiting the house Ho lived in much more interesting. We were lucky our tour guide was with us to add more detail and colour to what we were seeing. You can see the rooms Ho lived in initially as president (which apparently were tradesmen's quarters on the palace grounds) see the cars he used which were gifted by other countries for his use, and most interesting the longhouse he lived most in. I found it very interesting to learn there is no kitchen in his house as he often ate with staff in another building. The site is a popular with Vietnamese so very crowded and unfortunately pressure to keep moving when I would liked to spent more time looking at the house. The grounds are very pleasant to walk through.
Beautiful peace of architecture. Beautiful building displaying great character. I could not go in but from outside it looks stunning. Definitely a must see in Hanoi.
Must see. There are long lines here, so get in line early. It is a must see for Hanoi. Very interesting place and palace of the former president, Ho Chi minh.
Great. You can enter just after visiting the ho chi ming but as a visitor you must pay a fee but its worth it just beautiful gardens and you get to see were ho chi ming lived ..great

Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum worth the trip. Very sombre experience, shows the respect the Vietnamese people have for their leader Very well organized and even though the line was long, we were through in a reasonable amount of time.

Vietnamese history. Interesting to see where the Vietnamese leader lived. Tours can be taken daily. The best thing was visiting the mausoleum and seeing the body of Ho Chi Minh. It's kinda weird seeing this person who's been dead since 1969 still preserved.
Must see when in Hanoi. Well presented view of Ho Chi Minh and worth a visit. The gardens are beautiful. Not able to go into the Palace. Would have liked to have seen the inside
Good. Well worth the visit to see where this famous man resided and some Vietnamese history. A nice walk through the gardens is also nice.
A good history lesson. Not sure I wanted to see someone who has been dead so long but, the grounds and history of the places was very worth the visit
Peacful place. A peaceful interlude in the middle of a bustling city, an escape from the crowds and good place to relax and enjoy a respite from the heat

Outstanding architecture. We have been here twice now and we are astounded that such a wondeful place is still standing after the ten years of bombing during the 1965-1973 war .It is a great monument to the legacy of Ho Chi Mihn..the building itself is quite magnificent and is surrounded by unique garden and minutes lawns..also around the area there is plenty of street food being peddled , in itself worth the trip to the palace ..it is history ..
Fascinating . Well worth the visit. Enjoyed seeing the elegant building and gardens. Seeing his simple and minimalistic living quarters, reception room and office.

Beautiful. Lots of history in this place which is not surprising considering what Viet Nam went through.
Don't forget to look at the vintage cars on view.
Uncle Ho. Fascinating place to visit. Must see Uncle Ho's home. The grounds are a nice respite from the noise and bustle of Hanoi

Interesting visit. We visited early in the morning. The palace is a beautiful place. We also visited the Mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh. That was a somber experience and interesting to learn how much the Vietnamese people think of him. There was also a museum which we enjoyed more for the air con than the exhibits.
Didn't see much.. This site was not open for the public to walk around the grounds and explore you can only view from a far.

Impressive. A very nice building in a good state of repair, painted yellow as are
All 'government' buildings in Vietnam. It is a great example of the turbulent history and the different types of buildings left by invaders throughout Vietnam
Lots of walking.. Keep this in mind if you have older visitors. Long walk from entrance. Very interesting. A must see if you come to Hanoi.

Very interesting. This building has many interesting rooms. They are in the same shape that they were in in 1975 at the end of the war. There is all sorts of interesting reads on the plaques in front of the rooms.
Closed. The day we were in Hanoi many places were closed. We walked a long way to get here and it was still interesting to see from afar. Would have been interesting to have gone inside... Next time!

Nice. Presidential palace is worth a visit to take a photo from the outside and next door is the Mausoleum. Both are on some kind of walking way from the Pagoda on way to the Temple of Literature. Nice place to visit if planned on route.

Historical Site to Experience. We had to stand in line for about 20 minutes to enter the mausoleum. Absolute quiet is demanded from the guards, even as you wait in the line outside. It is very interesting seeing the entire site surrounding the mausoleum - a view into how Ho Chi Minh lived.
A must do!. Absolutely breathtaking and full of history, a must whilst in Hanoi as well as the mausoleum of HCM and his embalmed body, what a site, absolutely not to miss.

a great place to visit.. I enjoyed seeing how they lived, entertained and made very important decisions from this building. The bunkers were vere interesting. The gardens are beautiful . certain areas could do with a coat of paint, but otherwise everything is in top shape and the furniture that the politicians used is beautiful!

Beautiful.. This is a superb French Colonial architecturally designed building, the grounds are very well maintained, the concept of his peaceful days in this is place is gratifying.
This is a must see in Hanoi, get there early and not on weekends.

The surroundings where Ho Chi Min used to live and work. This site comprises the Presidential Palace, a simple house on stilts, a museum, gardens, and cars used by the President during his 15 year stay before his death in 1969. It's located close to Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum. There's also pagoda nearby.The imposing yellow-painted Presidential Palace (originally built by the French colonisers) is not open to the public and is these days apparently used occasionally to greet foreign dignitaries. Understandably HCM didn't stay in it. Instead he had a simple timber house on stilts built in the grounds (it is claimed) which served as his living and working quarters. The house has just two rooms with personal effects on display (desk, bed, clock etc.) and, strangely, no toilet. The house is set in a large botanical garden filled with mango trees and a large pond full of carp. There is also an orchard and pergola.There are other buildings close to the stilt house and probably where HCM spent most of his time, and a little safer and hidden during the war time I'd imagine. We saw a dining room with a table set and a study. Next to these were three cars claimed to have been used by the President. Within the same complex but closer to the mausoleum is the One Pillar Pagoda representing a lotus flower. It's an interesting building, but not the original 1049 construction (that was destroyed by the retreating French in 1954 - why, oh why I ask - what strategic value was there?). Fortunately it was rebuilt almost straight away.All in all, it is an interesting place to visit, and I can understand why it is revered by most Vietnamese. You get a sense of the history it is capturing and the pinnacle upon which Ho Chi Minh is placed in Vietnam.
Leave with regrets. The Ho Chi Minh mausoleum was closed the day we were there i.e. 10Jul15 @10am & the tour guide is not aware 8-(Luckily, we get to see the guard shift changing parade.

Do with a proper tour guide. We first arrived at the site on a Tuesday having checked opening hours to find the place deserted with nothing open. We then booked as part of a City Tour. A fairly rushed itinerary took us to the museum, although hardly anything is in English it is a great example of Vietnamese propaganda about its leaders and influence, which was in itself an interesting perspective. Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum was a conveyer belt walk through, highly guarded and requiring you to cover shoulders and knees. The grounds are nice but disappointingly foreigners aren't allowed the visit the palace slightly further away from museum areas and our tour guide did not take us there so unfortunately we missed the stilt house and a lot of the history. Information on the site and visit without a proper tour guide isn't advised.

What an honor to see Ho Chi Minh. We always want to see Ho Chi Minh. His mausoleum was beautiful and the secure was very high too. We have a chance to know more about his life and his career. Worth to visit!

A ritual visit if you visit hanoi. The Ho Chi Minh mausoleum needs to be visited early in the morning to avoid the queues. We arrived at about 8.30 and had to wait about 20 minutes to file past his body. Interesting to see the reverence and pomp that surrounds this site. I would not bother with the museum as it is a bit of a let down.

A must see in Hanoi. A visit to the Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace Historical Site is a must for first time visitors to Hanoi. Seeing how the man lived is an inspiration and helps understand the love and devotion the people of liberated Vietnam have for this historical figure.

Very Humble but beautiful lodgings!. Amazing to see how simply Ho Chi Minh lived after his retirement. A guide tour of the Palace is definitely worth it. Beautiful grounds & kept very well.
And while there, also visit the HCM Mausoleum, which is absolutely beautiful. Though check before going as each year the mausoleum undergoes maintenance.

A must see. This is really the history of Vietnam. A very please 2-3 hours looking at the architecture the living conditions and Ho's style of living, getting around and philosophy. Get a guide. It is much more fun an has a greater impact. Some long waits so plan on some 2 to 3 hours.

History lesson on the life of Uncle Ho. Brilliant to come here to know the man and his legacy. There's always available on-site multi-language tours available to join.
Can be quite crowded on weekends, went on a Thursday.

Definitely worth visiting. Our tour guide took us here after visiting Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum. An amazing experience to see how this leader lived and how he shaped the grounds of his home. Very humbling. Beautifully looked after house & grounds.
Very formal. Very controlled tour - no talking and marching in double file. Did get visitors thru Mausoleum very efficiently.

Ho Chi Minh's Legacy. A well preserved site of the late Ho Chi Minh. Very interesting to see how he lived, where he lived and how he lived his daily life. Our guide was brilliant in explaining the etiquette for our visit.

Ho Ci Minh retirement museum area and Palace.. Amazing building but also amazing to see how simply Ho Chi Minh lived when he retired from active service to his country. Definately worth having a guide to explain everything you are seeing. He is a greatly revered man and treated almost like a god.

A Historical Place Worth Visiting But.... We went on a stinking hot Sunday morning. The queue was very long and tiring. We wanted to go to HCM mausoleum actually. You had to pay some entrance fees to go to this site. Otherwise, you had to go straight to One-pillar pagoda.

Interesting but spent too long here. Interesting history but too long spent here on the half day tour.great photos later showed the defining act of the Vietnam war when tanks crashed through the gates
Interesting line-ups. We went on a stinking hot Sunday morning and really enjoyed hanging out with every day Vietnamese people waiting to see their president.

Worth a visit. Allow a couple of hours to explore the stunning gardens and grounds, compare the magnificence of the Presidential Palace with Ho Chi Minh's austere accommodations within the gardens and close by.

If you're not interested in Ho Chi Minh, give it a miss. Having watched a documentary on youtube about Ho Chi Minh before we went, we both found it quite interesting. The museum part lacks any kind of narrative (seemingly the standard for Vietnamese museums) and plenty of stuff is missing an English translation but it was still worth a walk around. The palace section is a nice stroll around. The mausoleum was probably the highlight (if you like looking at creepy dead bodies, I suppose). If you're just in Vietnam for the party scene you might wanna give this place a miss, I'd say it would only entertain if you really are interested in the county's history...

Getting to know Ho Chi Minh. The big yellow building is the Presidential Palace. It was the residence of the Governor General of Indochina but is now used for official receptions to welcome visiting heads of states from other countries. It is not opened to the public. After viewing this place, we proceeded to the stilt house of Ho Chi Minh. We can see that he led a simple life and he always remembered the ethnic people who sheltered him when he escaped from the French, by having his house built on stilts just like the house of the ethnic people. We also saw the cars he used. We also saw his workroom and meeting room.. We also saw the Cypress tree's roots along the fishpond. .
What a place. This place is unbelievable. We spent a good few hours having a look around the palace very impressive.
Splendour. The stunning botanical gardens. The austerity of Ho Chi Minhs mausoleum. Changing of the guard impressive. Tangible history.

Interesting quick visit. Less than £1 to enter as a foreigner, and I had an enjoyable stroll through the complex. Didn't take me ages. The presidential palace is a most stunning building. Worth a visit along with HCM's mausoleum.

Boring. This is free for Vietnamese but anyone foreign-looking is pulled aside and told to buy a ticket. You basically get the roam the grounds and see the outsides of various buildings used by Ho Chi Minh. There are also drink stalls and rather raggedy souvenir shops. Perhaps this is an attraction best left to history buffs.

A must do. This is a place you really have to visit in Hanoi, given its importance in the history of the nation. We were there on a rainy day, but it did not detract from the sense of significance it holds. A must do.
Lovely grounds. Seeing the embalmed Ho Chi Minh was somewhat surreal but the grounds were lovely. The stilt house in particular.
Long Distance Photo Op. Apparently the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum is only open on selected dates/times. Most often, you must stand behind a yellow line on the street and shoot long distance photos.

Tranquil setting. This is a nice site to get a snapshot of Ho Chi Minh. His stilted house is here, his cars, etc. The site is in a nice park-like setting and not overrun by tour groups. Even in the midday sun, there is a nice amount of shade because of all the trees. I suggest getting to the site later in the day, as it was nearly empty when we visited and does not take longer than an hour or so.
So much to see!!. Wow this place is amazing and so much to see. They obviously lived it up in style and it is amazing to see. Very hot inside though.

It is very peaceful and worth historic place to visit!. The place is about 10 minutes walking distance from the First Eden Hotel.It is a very ambient area and a really good place to get to know about President Ho Chi Minh. I like this place very much. I would recommend it to all visitors to the city.
Relaxed atmosphere. The number of people was just too much but the gardens were comforting and a cool haven during the hot weather.

Recommended. Just to put more perspective on the life of the man who was at the center of the struggle for national liberation. The Presidential Palace as well as the humbler buildings where Ho Chi Minh chose is a small window into what this leader was like.

Right next to the mausoleum. I'd just come out of the mausoleum and I was following the crowd when I was told I needed to pay more if I wanted to walk through some gates. I didn't know what I was paying for but they wanted such a pittance and I love tourist sites so I paid up and walked in. It turned out to be the Presidential Palace, Ho Chi Minh's stilt house, his car garage and a pond. All stuff I'd wanted to see. You get a leaflet telling you a little about each place but a guide/tour would have been better. You can't go in the Presidential Palace. I think it’s used by the government. When you leave this area you end up by the Ho Chi Minh Museum.

Confusing. I think we must have gone the wrong way because at every turn there was an officer with finger in the trigger of the machine gun next to signs that said no entrance We couldn't get into this place so went into the museum of history I thin, it was quite interesting but there was a lot of artistic pieces along with some good depictions of parts of history particularly anything to do with uncle ho.

The great leader. The palace precinct tells the story of the revered Uncle Ho who reunified Vietnam after 1000 years of occupation by foriegn forces. He refused to live in the palace preferring an austere bungalow in the grounds. Set in beautiful gardens the site is a fitting monument to the memory of such a significant character in Vietnamese history.
Awesome. It was awesome to see the body of Ho Chi Minh. What I dislike is why are they strict with pictures and videos. Why are they strict with the size of bags,
Interesting. A must place to visit. It tells you the new history of Hanoi and MrHo Chi Minh, But for someone who is not a Vietnamese its not important to see the mausolem (tomb)

French architecture at its best. When we were there, visitors can only walk past the side of this building and take a photo. For a Communist country that is supposed to share everything, a front view of this building is not included in the sharing. Only the ruling elite and invited guests get to see the inside? Plenty of other attractions only minutes away. Take the photo and think about how good a selfie front view would look in your holiday snaps.

a must see , historical, enlightening, steeped in history. the area covers the mausoleum, the palace, the old house on stilts where Ho Chi minh stayed . showed the simplcity of his ways with nice tree covered grounds
Busy place. This was a very busy and interesting place very popular with the Vietnamese visitors as their leader lived there. Worth a visit
Unrban adventures tour. Uncle Ho was a humble man, despite his incredible effort in ridding Vietnam of the french and the Americans. Funny seeing the old cars he was given.

Well-preserved.. The wisdom & simplicity of the great HCM is preserved in the display of his houses & his choices. Visitors are lead to admire him as a person & leader, & hence a greater understanding of Vietnam.

interesting. Well worth the crowds. Seems we picked time of number of school groups but was fun to see the children's reactions to some of sites. Think fish are the winners.Sorry palace not open but silt house and other areas very informative and help to understand the man and his beliefs.Since popular with school groups bit heavy on souvenir shops.

Loved the place.....great lesson of simplicity.. I found the visit to the Presidential place and the house where President Ho Chi Minh very interesting. The place closes at 12.00pm, so make sure you arrive well in advance if you want to make the most of the visit.The fee charged for foreign tourist is very modest.
Hidden world. Behind the gates is like another world. With the palace and the house on stilts. The grounds are beautiful with lakes and paths that lead you through this wonderful place.

closed at 11:00 AM!! ridiculous!. Not sure whether it is the HCM house (old house) or presidential palace, but the one I went is just beside the HCM mausoleum. The mausoleum is fantastic, gave me goose bumps and eerier feelings to see how they can preserved president HCM body perfectly! The President seems like resting/sleeping peacefully.What i want to comment here is during my visit to the presidential (old house) where when i just walked in and strolling over the house area, trying to read and learn about HCM history, furniture, etc. suddenly me and my family were chased away/OUT from that area just because it's their lunch time, what?? Seriously, lunch time at 11:00 a.m??And how can a tourist spot can be closed for lunch time?? What???We paid 20K VD just to enter the HCM old house, yes it's very little money but it's NOT free!! But the mausoleum is free.At the end of my trip, especially at the HCM Square I can say I learned NOTHING!It seems that this place is 'NOT READY' to 'share' their history stories to the tourist yet. I was very disappointed during my whole visit. I was waiting to come to this place months and months before, and what I expect from this place maybe little higher than what they can give, probably. But, lunch time at tourist stop? hmm..Hopefully they will improved.My advice, just come very early, meaning 08:00 AM you have to be there at the Square already.

House where Ho Chi Minh lived in the palace grounds. This is the official palace, gardens and grounds in which Ho Ch Minh chose to live very simply In a small house, without the luxury and trappings of office that was available. The buildings include the presidents bunker and bomb shelter and garages with official and bullet proof cars!..its a remarkably peaceful place to escape the bustle and traffic of Hanoi. Take your time and enjoy, encourage your guide to tell you about Uncle Ho !

Do It! An interesting historical experience.. This was a great experience. Very interesting. I never thought I'd file past Ho Chi Minh's body (and never felt the need to, until we were there). The Palace grounds were also well worth a visit. All in all a very interesting, historical, experience.
Beautiful Palace. This Palace is next to the HCM Mauseliem. It's beautiful. While HCM chose to stay in a house built on stilts, this is truly a French masterpiece.

Beautiful from the outside!. Unfortunately the palace was closed for maintenance on the afternoon we visited, so we were unable to see Ho Chi Minh's preserved body. However even from the outside it is a beautiful building and well worth seeing.

Beautiful building, interesting history. With its dated decor and preserved structures, it provides an interesting window into the Saigon government in the 60s. Lot's of history! Can visit the rooftop, have a drink and enjoy the view of HCM.

Interesting Site. See where Uncle Ho lived, the cars he had. Very humble person it would seem who lived in austere surroundings rather than the Presidential residence. We enjoyed our time wandering around this site.

Joined enormous queue to see Ho Chi Minh. Interesting to see the reverence with which Ho Chi Minh is held by the people of Vietnam and provides context to then visiting the rest of the complex. Terribly hot day when we were there but the queues all covered to provide shade.

A glimpse into the life of Ho Chi Minh. This is a beautifully maintained historical park where you can see the home he lived in as well as artifacts of the nation's war. It is very popular with Vietnamese tourists.

Very pretty area. Our tour group wandered through here and it's quite a pretty area.
The palace itself is a beautiful example of the French colonial architecture throughout Hanoi. There are also several other historical buildings nearby.
There was food and beverages available for purchase at various intervals too.
Awesome place. Worth a visit. love the fact that he chose to live in the engineers house instead of the palace. He must have been loved. See his house and cars.

History!. We didn't see Ho Chi Minh this time as my husband had seen him 18 years ago. The line is much shorter if you are with a guide. The vendors on the property are kind and generous. Feel free to support them.

An insight into the esteem in which the man is held. We did not like the length of queue which was formed to enter the mausoleum to view the corpse of the great leader - therefore for the few minutes inside we did not take in this element. We were on a Virgin Holiday tour and therefore we were accompanied by our guide ( personal service as we were the only couple on the tour ) and all the ticketing and entry protocols were dealt with efficiently and seamlessly for us, eliminating any queuing by ourselves. Our courier was excellent , informative and friendly and I am sure gave us insights into the history of Vietnam , the ideals of Ho Chi Minh , and some of the events of the War which we could not have gained otherwise.

Well organized visit. The Mausoleum is only open until 11 so need to arrive early and be prepared to queue. No bags, cameras or phones. No hats or sunglasses in Mausoleum. Staff a bit austere! Museum interesting but all in Vietnamese on ground floor. Go upstairs and be prepared for lunchtime closures

Very interesting. Worth a visit if in the area to provide an insight into the conditions prisoners experienced whilst inmates in the prison. Not expensive at 30,000 VND a person and you can either walk through quickly or take your time to read the information - but it's worthwhile paying for an English information pamphlet at 20,000VND.

It's a beautiful palace and the museum is amazing.. The palace is very worth seeing just for its cultural and historical significance to the country of vietnam, but the museum is amazing. While you will find bits and pieces of propaganda, the architecture of the building and of the individual sections is amazing. Totally worth seeing.
Good on Uncle Ho. All intersting. Unfortunately the Presidential Palace was closed on the day we went. The house where Ho Chi Minh lived during their 'struggle for independence' was worth visiting.
