Must-see when visiting Hanoi. Must-see when visiting Hanoi, I found it useful to understand Vietnam and the people. Curious exposition.

Stunning palace in picturesque setting. After visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, we paid a small amount to visit the old Presidential Palace. The majestic French colonial yellow building was stunning. We couldn’t go inside, but it was lovely to see from the outside and its surrounding gardens were very picturesque. Ho Chi Minh had no family and the palace is so large that he chose instead to live in other residences on the property. You can visit these: house number 54 where he lived and worked since 1954, including a selection of cars he received as gifts from Russia, and his house on stilts. It was nice to walk around and look at the well planned and laid out gardens. The topiary trees were very decorative and impressive. The huge central lake with Koi fish was also very scenic. This complex is also home to the One Pillar Pagoda.The complex is well worth visiting.

The Palace was closed. So we walked around the gardens, saw the house on stilts supposedly where Ho Chi Minh stayed (no air conditioning). It took a total of 15 minutes to see. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum is nearby but that was closed too. It's pretty but have a back up plan.

Historical place worth checking out. This presidential Palace is enormous and it is located quite near the Public park. In the evening you can see many People jogging or relaxing around the park. And you can admire the Palace from the outside.

Gained historical insight. We had a very knowledgeable tour guide who obviously admired Ho Chih Minh ('Uncle Ho', he said). He was very detailed in explaining every piece of history that was displayed and it was a very good history lesson for my teenage son! The French architecture is well preserved and the palace ground is beautifully tree-lined (the Mango Lane) and well-kept. The tour guide's little stories about Ho Chih Minh gave us insights about his humble personality despite the great works he had done to the country. An insightful visit, indeed.

Walking the Ho Chi Minh palace site. Walking the grounds was very nice. Couldn't get into the palace the day of our visit, apparently due to construction, but still enjoyed seeing the grounds and where he spent his private times. Soldiers guarding the grounds and palace had to be at least 6' tall.

Hightlight. Our guide was amazing told us the history of what occurred ,how things progressed and what is happening today. The buildings were amazing and I can't describe what it was like to walk around these century year old buildings. The people were friendly and it was like stepping back in time A MUST SEE.
history. great to see where every one has seen pictures of hard to think it was a long time back when the troops won over the west

Beautiful palace. Bad luck again i guess, when i tried to visit i wasnt allowed to enter the property. Maybe the president was at the palace, dont have any idea. You cant even take a picture of the palace, the guards will tell you not to go to close or take picture. It looks very nice and the gardens are well maintained ofcourse. In the back of the palace there are the botanical gardens which i could visit.
Very Informative. We had a tour guide take us through and she was very knowledgeable and informative, it's very impressive and well worth the visit if your touring the sights.

Bit weird but worth it. Watch out for the weekend, the queues get very long, but, they do move quite quickly.Be aware that you need to hand in your bags, but keep your camera; then they will take your camera (no photos allowed), the camera you can then get back straight after. And then collect bag after that.Seeing the preserved body of Ho Chi Minh was slightly strange but I'm glad I joined the line and waited for about 40 mins to see him.the surrounding bits are well worth seeing also.do try and avoid weekends if you can
Very interesting. Was great to hear about the history of Ho Chi Mihn but would have been better if you could go inside.

Huge queues!. This is a very important site for Vietnamese people, so they flock here in droves We only saw this from the outside as the queue was nearly one mile long! As it was 36 degrees C and my husband is disabled and there was nowhere to rest we had to give up. I am sure there are times when it is less busy so it might be wise to find out when that might be. However from the outside it looked worth seeing!

Fabulous introduction to Ho Chi Minh. Not knowing much about Vietnam's "Uncle Ho", a visit to the historical site was very enjoyable. I really enjoyed the residential area, including the large lake and homes.

Worth a look. I was cold so perhaps not the best time to go sight seeing but found this interesting all the same. Our guide was very knowledgable. I left with a better understanding of why the people revere Ho Chi Minh. Was also interesting architecture.

A lovely experience. Loved the gorgeous grounds surrounding the palace and house where Ho Chi Minh stayed. A very peaceful place. the palace is stunning, french in style and the gardens offered a bit of quiet from the activity of the city.

Ho Chi Minh Vestige number 54. In the grounds of the presidential palace is Ho Chi Minhs Vestige where he chose to live (he never slept in the actual palace that was built for him.)There are a few of the cars that Ho Chi Minh used and that were given to him during his time of leadership, and the original one bedroom timber frame house he lived in has been beautifully maintained. The gardens and small lake are stunning and so quiet and peaceful.There is also a visitors quarters and a bomb shelter that Ho Chi Minh would retire to if the bell was sounded. If the current President is on the grounds you will need to pass thru security to enter the grounds so its easier if you are just travelling with a backpack. There is food beverages souvenirs and toilets all available on the grounds.As always have a guide with you, there is so much more to the experience if you have a guide that can explain all the little things the history and the folklore about this man.
Reflective. It was so interesting to gain an historical context to Vietnam. The awe in which Ho Chi Min is held is quite phenomenal. This in fact contradicts the apparent humbleness of the man.

Presidential Palace. Nice view, but you can't go inside or even into the grounds, I couldnt even get close to the gate to take a photo through the bars as a local guard told be it is forbidden... The photo here is about as close as you can get.
Fascinating visit. We enjoyed our surrounds and were really fascinated by the history of Ho Chi Minh. We had no idea and our guide was full of information.

A good half day trip with the Mausoleum. We went at the weekend so a lot of locals but very well organized so no problem. Well worth visiting and combine this with the HCM Museum, which has lots of educational photos and the Mausoleum which was interesting. But don't forget they close for a 2 hour lunch break and the Mausoleum is only in the morning. A nice little air conditioned coffee shop at the basement of the museum.

DEFINITELY WORTH THE COUPLE OF DOLLARS FOR ADMISSION. This Palace / Museum is fascinating for anyone who likes historyWHAT IS THEREWar time Tanks and Planes on siteWar Time communications equipmentWell preserved palaceTime capsule to the 1960's English Signs and Tour Guides (heard lots of other language guides around us) VERY FASCINATING definitely worth the couple of hours

Special place for locals. Queues and more queues......We did not go inside as queues far too long so our Tour Guide directed us around outside and through gardens to his very plain house where he lived.All very interestingHo Chi Minh is highly revered by Vietnamese and you must respect that for those with memories of warDefinetly worth seeing

Well worth a visit!. A bit of a trek from the Old Quarter but well worth it. No need to book a guide or onto a tour we just paid the small entrance fee and walked around. It's a nice eye opener to Vietnamse culture and to the life of Ho Chi Minh. It's also a great escape from the street sellers and small roads of the Old Quarter! Would definitely recommend a visit!
History abounds. The tour of the grounds and gardens of the Presidential Palace give a snap shot into the History of Modern Day Hanoi. Do not miss the antique cars keep in the garage

Well worth a visit. Just a short walk from the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, the Palace was well worth it. We did it with a private English speaking guide and van which is the best way to see most if not all attractions throughout Vietnam.You don't actually get to walk inside the Palace, but the walk around the gardens and lake are very picturesque.When you arrive at the lake, clap your hands loudly and the huge fish come to the surface.
Respect. Simplicity in the heart of great complexity - respect for the past - curiosity how reconciliation was achieved - vision

Impressive!. We had a great afternoon traipsing round this Palace. The North Vietnamese dramatic gate break tank was there. The state rooms were authentic and showed very clearly how American it all was. Well worth a visit.

Historical. Four hour tour, one of which was devoted to the indoctrination speech. Great historical interest although some facilities were closed. Devoid of atmosphere. Guide knew his history but needed to forego the embellishments and stick to facts.

Impressive. Great place to visit, stretches for quite a distance. Can see the house on stilts built for Ho Chi Minh, various cars etc. Unable to see preserved body as not open to the public, only on certain days.

Couldn't go into this palace itself, but excellent places just nearby :). The Presidential Palace itself is off-limits to the public; but the nearby Mausoleum, the house that HCM lived in the 1950's with an attached garage (with like three cars inside), his house-on-stilts that he lived in the 1960's with a big lake in front, and the HCM Museum are all open to the public. And after you're done with the "HCM area" there's also One Pillar Pagoda nearby which apparently is a very famous temple of Vietnam although it's just a tiny building on a pillar in the middle of a small pond.All the above mentioned places together will take about four hours so it's enough time to do them all in one morning, but I'm not sure about the line for the Mausoleum as it was closed due to a renovation or something when I visited back in September, 2014, but it shouldn't be too bad if you arrive early in the morning like at 7 or 7 30 am when they open.About a 40-minute walk from the Hanoi train station (Ga Hanoi) on Le Duan then turning left onto Dien Bien Phu, just be sure to stay on Dien Bien Phu when you get past Lenin Park and get to like the fork with the big Flag Tower on the right because going that way will take you to the Thang Long Citadel instead of the mausoleum, museum and palace, so be sure to keep walking on Dien Bien Phu as the road bears left from that fork.

Presidential palace. can't beat for history both old and recent. we didn't bother with 1 hour line to see HCM Mausoleum, but patrolled outside and visited president's palace (though that's the wrong word for it.)

wow. this place is very vast. the building inside of it is amazing. it's dedicated to ho chi minh. and it's open in the morning. if you want to go to this place, i think its good to go in the morning. there a lake near the ho chi minh presidential palace. some people believe that the root in the lake is a buddha root. and it's amazes me, because the root is quite weird. this historical place is recommended for someone that's interested in vietnam history
very impressive. good history lesson on this tour ,and nice to see how the other people did live and get through there days ...u can see it all here
Hugh Garden！. We have enjoyed this place very much! Great garden and landscape, very well maintained. A great place to visit learning more about Ho Chi Minh and his life stories...

Ummmmm. This place was a ok.... It was quite a little scam ish if you can say we walk through the mausoleum and when we came out we was walking with the crowds until we was charged in the queue 25000d to go round the palace which we didn't even know we was entering the better but was locals went free or should I say none westerners which we wasn't bothered however it was very blatant and unsettling

It's just ok. Nice building. However, there's really nothing much to see. Dong25,000 to enter. You can get into the main building. You will simply walk around the palace and see displays from a glass window from the exterior.

Graceful gardens and architecture. This site is well worth a visit - you don't have to see Uncle Ho in his mausoleum as you can also visit his base during the war and walk through beautiful gardens. It's also interesting to see the thousands of Vietnamese paying homage and seeing beautiful women in their customary dress out of respect for their hero of the revolution.

An insight into the man. You'll get to talk to this place after the walk through into the HCM Mausoleum. You would have already placed your belongings at the very entrance.Worth to check out to know the man. First, you'll see his old house. A simple man with limited amount of possession, by choice. You do see his cars which were all gifts by the Americans and Russians. Second, you'll then proceed to the lake house (or stilt house) where you can to see similar type of setup. It usually consist of a room to sleep, a place to conduct meeting, a place to dine, and a place to read / lay back to think (with a writing table & many books). You'll also observe the strong influence of both Lenin and Marxism in almost all the rooms. Third, is the presidential palace which we are not allowed to enter. It looks very grand on the outside.I left with three questions in mind. One, how much of the preservation is true to the man, or it is kept the way the people want to see him as? Two, which all the books all over in different places, what is he wants a book from somewhere and forget where he placed it? It'll be quite a bummer to try to find that book. Three, the modern generation seem to have forgot or lost the ability to tell the difference between a "Need" and a "Want".Guards are very focused on their job. They'll make sure everyone, especially the local, kept to the regulations. They are more forgiving to foreigners.Go in the morning to avoid the warm weather and huge crowd. There are many places to sit and chill, and gift shops to buy things. I'd buy their local perfumes because it smells not bad. But I'm still going to many other ASEAN countries so decided to only take pictures and bring back memories. :)
Interesting place.... Long line. Make sure you wear long pants and covered shoulders. It was a neat experience to see the preserved body of Ho Chi Minh. You have to walk by it pretty quickly though.
Really interesting place to visit. Of important historical interest, nice gardens- certainly not glamorous and a bit commercial. Very interesting to see the homes where Ho Chi Minh lived.
Great insight into history. Was a great trip back into the history of the wars. Great to see that has been kept well and worth a visit.
Cannot Enter just take a pic fron outside the gate. Yellow Building that known as presidential palace , we cannot enter just can take pictures from outside the gate only

Worth seeing - very interesting. We had a guide as part of our holiday package show us through the site. It is very interesting and a beautiful place. We were given a better understanding of the history through that time and the life lead by Ho Chi Minh. Definitely worth a visit.

OK, but nothing special. I think you would have to be a HO Chi Minh fan club member to say this was mind-blowing, but still worth a visit. There are a few artefacts that are of interest and pleasant lake. Please be warned that the guards on duty near the Presidential Palace can be very confronting. They have big problems with you being in the wrong place, but are not too cleaver in signposting the fact adequately.
Great history. To actually see the work area and planning process against foreign troops is historically significant. The personal items gives one a picture of the man himself.

Hot and Wet rember the spray jacket and thongs if its that time of year. Closed when I was there only allow outside grounds but I must before mausoleum just remember DON'T walk on the grass or some nice little man will point a big GUN at you
Beautiful grounds, must do in Hanoi. Seeing both the mausoleum and the adjacent Presidential Palace Historic Site was surreal and important to understanding Vietnam's history and world view.

Historical interest. The site is of historic interest but the palace is not open only the smaller buildings in the ground. The site served to show that Ho Chi Minh liked to live a simple life and I found this interesting, if you have a real interest in HCM then this is a must visit site for you. For the people of Vietnam this is an important site to visit, like the HCM mausoleum, for the general traveller it is worth a visit for an hour or two.

Ho Chi Minh home. I wished the Presidential Palace was open for visits by the tourist. It looks like a great building.The whole park of complex is very well maintained, gardens are impeccable. You have to see the to houses where he actually lived.

Well worth the time.. I did queue up for Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum. I had friends tell me it was not worth the time, but for the cultural experience I thought it was worth the time. It took about an hour, so allow plenty of time when going to this site.
Weird rules. The grounds are nice but there are very strange walking around regulations which make the experience quite limited and short. Packed out too

A little underwhelming. There's not much to say. I'm glad I went, but I wouldn't plan on spending too much time there. It's kind of relaxing around the pond, and if you're a hand's on history buff you can kind of get a sense of how Ho Chi Minh used the grounds.

Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace. We visited the palace with our Guide "Sonny" an ex South Vietnamese Air Force. When we arrived at the gates my mind went back to the last days of the war and a tank crashing trough the gates of the Palace, and here I was in person. I was pleased as we went through the palace that it had remained in the form that it was at the wars end. Our guides commentary was brilliant and we covered every room and floor of the palace and he explained what each room contained and what it was used for. I would recommend using a guide as the commentary brings the place alive as it once was.

Caged Peacock. I visited the Presidential Palace last year. The palace itself is off-limits to visitors but visitors can see and walk through his simple wooden house. The garden was vast, quiet and serene, As I was leaving this place, I witnessed the saddest sight I have ever seen in a place this beautiful. It was a caged peacock with not even enough room to spread its wings. Picture this, that you are only able to stand in one spot which is the center of a hemisphere and turn in circles. If you move a centimeter or two away from the tallest point, you will not be able to stand anymore. I have written to the embassy to no avail. I have contacted AnimalsAsia.org and they have tried contacting the palace with no success. For many days after my visit and for the rest of my time in Vietnam, I could not get that peacock and the sadness that engulfed me out of my system.

Nice gardens. Another place of Hanoi's history, nice gardens and surrounding buildings, can get very crowded as is popular with locals. Do not bother waiting in line to see mausoleum, the line is endless.

Important Historical Site. The French Colonial Presidential Palace was thought too grand to live in by Ho Chi Minh, so he had a traditional Vietnamese stilt house with only two simple upper rooms built for himself just a few steps away. Here he lived in Spartan simplicity, tending his gardens and feeding the carp in the nearby garden pond. Everything is exactly as he left it, and on display are his motor vehicles, his typewriter, and even his electric alarm clock. The site was mobbed with mostly Vietnamese citizens paying their respect to this important figure of 20th century history. Some reviewers complained of propaganda, but I think I felt national pride more than anything else. I felt a hushed silence imbued with honor and respect for Ho Chi Minh.

An good insight into a humble leader. Varing from a choice of cars to wanting to live in a single room, the Palace was the uncomfortable face of the outside world he had to provide to overseas leaders. His final years were spent in a much more minimalistic environment which were more to his basic desires and beliefs.
Excellent. Very interesting and worth visiting to learn more about Ho Chi Minh. Plenty of guards every where but they are helpful as long as you only walk where you are supposed to go.
Worth seeing!. We visited this site two weeks' ago on a Monday when the Mausoleum was closed but we enjoyed looking around anyway. Worth a visit.

Presidential Palace Ho Chi Minh Hanoi. I visited on The New year ,it is a very worthwhile experience ,you can walk around at your own pace . A very beautiful setting ,with some old cars that were used to transport the President. A lake and surrounding gardens very relaxing.

Important historical site. If time allows please visit. The mausoleum is always a busy place with long lines of mostly Vietnamese visitors. Respectfulness is of utmost importance. Be mindful, properly dressed, quiet. A moving experience for myself.
Nice area. The is a must to see take the time to wait in line to see inside. Make sure you look at the house around back it has been updated but same house. As well the old car he used well worth it

communist propaganda. Be ready for a heavy dose of communist propaganda and the history of the victors. You will be immersed in a hagiography that probably would have made Ho blush. nonetheless there are interesting pictures and letters from an important 20th century historical figure and you will feel the negative impact of colonialism on the Vietnamese people.

A place not to be missed. Get up early, and enjoy your time looking around this fascinating place. Its away from the traffic and very clean and peaceful. A small entrance fee required for tourists although Vietnamese people can enter for free. Its really worth it and a lovely way to loose a few hours..

Tight Rules, Great Experience!. If you think about communism, this is a good example! Very tight rules if you want to visit. Vietnamese people come from all over the country to visit their savior. Ho Chi Minh is their God pretty much and you can feel the up tight system, rules and order in your bones as soon as you step in the foot path of the complex. They will ask you to inspect or leave your bag behind. Later they will ask you to leave your camera and phone behind if you haven't done it yet. Walk in line with 50 to a 100cm distance from the person in front of you, remove your hat, close your mouth and don't stair at Ho Chi Minh for too long once inside the most beautiful dark box made of Marble with the Communism and Vietnam symbols...I absolutely loved it! Advise: not for the short fuse people as you can get pushed or told off at some stage. Just relax and enjoy it for once the experience of living in a Communist stunning country with the most amazing lovely people!

Time Travels. If you're a history buff then this is the place that will take you closest to the Great Ho Chi Minh. The Presidential Palace may be viewed from the outside only. It is heavily guarded. Taking a stroll around the gardens, you see the most beautiful flowers and trees. Catch a view of his small abode where there is a display of his cars as donated by the Russians. Walking further, you come to his humble abode where he actually live as he refused to live in the Palace while his people endured the suffering. You are introduced to the simple life that this People's Man lived while he fought the brave struggle to liberate his people. This is truly a beautiful place to visit.

Given the number of people extremely well organised. The day we arrived the queue at 0900 was at least 10,000 people and snaked around the block. so if you want to avoid that organise a tour guide to help you circumvent the process. The site gardens are nicely laid out and the crowd control is first rate. A must when visiting Hanoi.They are very strict on what you can take into the mausoleum so leave your bag at home.

very moving..worth long lines..used private tour guide to sees Vietnam and it was worthwhile as we got in front. The idea hat we could visit his home and see how he lived and then see his body was extraordinary ..the grounds are beautiful and it felt like an honor to be there

Historical site!. The presidential palace, which wasn't open to the public, is an old French school that was converted but Ho refused to live in the luxury while the Vietnamese suffered in the south, so he moved into a simple three room house in behind. Here you can see three cars he was given as a gift from France, China and Russia. There's a picturesque pond next to the residence and on the other side is the House on Stilts. On one of his birthdays, he was given the house as a gift. Earlier in his life, he had spent time with the hill tribes in northwest Vietnam and they used to live in these types of homes, so one was built for him in 1958. In behind that was a bunker. This is part of the whole Ho Chi Minh experience as the Mausoleum is right next door and worth the visit for anyone interested in the history of the country.
Excellent. Beautiful grounds and just an easy stroll round. You can't get into the palace but it is still worth a visit
Great slice of history. Forget the palace, Ho never lived there, where he did live, round the back, shows the humility of the man.

Fascinating, but extremely busy. This museum kind of falls in your way as you exit the Mausoleum, and is free for Vietnamese, but $2.50 for foreigners. The three main areas of interest are the Presidential Palace (built for Ho Chi Minh, but where he refused to live), the humble house where he actually lived, and the recreated traditional stilt house he used as a study/meditation space. As it is right next to the mausoleum exit and is free for Vietnamese, almost all the visitors to the mausoleum also come in here, and appear to make up for the enforced quiet and solemnity of the mausoleumj by being fairly rowdy here. A nice picture of the simple life that UNcle HO pried to live

Was really interesting. We walked around with Hanoi Kids, great way to do it. We could ask all types of questions and they were informative and pleasant. No charge for the guides except u pay for their entry, lunch, dinner, transport. Nothing really. Great to wander around this site.

InterestingMuseum, creatively designed. Interesting information about Ho Chi Minh's background and his significance to his country. Fun to be among all the locals (school children, families, army personnel) visiting. Pleasant visit, nicely displayed exhibits
Presidential Palace. Day one of our trip to Vietnam very hot but the palace is so interesting that you forgot. The bunkers underneath very interesting furniture upstairs impressive. recommended.

Ho Chi Min is the religion. The eternal love of the Vietnamese people is evident at this palace and mausoleum. The revere from crowds of young and old coming to see "Uncle Ho" was quite strange but fascinating. His every item left behind cars, cups, treehouse and body can be looked at. It is assumed that you know about the man himself before you go, take a guide who can tell you every detail of Uncle Ho's life if you don't know much about him.
Say You've been to Ho Chi Minh. This is only worth a visit if you are interested in the man and/or his achievements. If you are, it's fascinating!

Critical to understand... political maketing. The government made him an icon he did not want to be, turned him into an "eternal president" to put a face on a government that does not have any, and this mausoleum makes him a father figure for millions to adore. It works. Scary and fascinating altogether, but necessary to understand a country we learned so much from.
Quite Majestic. Nice place to take photos. But its a pity we can't go in because we aren't any VVIP, you got to be a VVIP to be able to enter. Only can take photos of its majestic architecture.
Nice. It was a nice place to walk round. Very well kept. We had our guide, so found out lots of interesting things. You could only look through windows in the buildings, but that was ok
monumentalist architecure rules. mostly of interest to the local population to my mind. The buildings are communist style piles and the message is highly political.

The Yellow House. After seeing many amazing sites in Hanoi alone, the palace wasn't as awe inspiring as others but the site is more than just a palace. In addition to the palace there are other living quarters on the palace grounds and and a beautiful man-made pound. There is also a garage showcasing Ho Chi Minh's favorite antique cars. Worth a visit for sure.
Nice place to walk around. Only a dollar or two to get into the area. It was a nice place to walk around and look at the scenery. You can see into the houses and see his old cars as well.

Interesting for the history buff. Heavily guarded, there's a surprising amound of walking around the outskirts just to get into the official grounds. The ground are lovely and their is much to learn. A guide is helpful.

Quiet and picturesque. One usually combines the visit to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and the Presidential Palace. While the first is without doubt a sombre affair right from the immense structure , the formal lines and security to get inside, the visit to the Presidential Palace complex is pleasant. Though the palace is not open to public , the building is interesting and imposing enough. The entire area is very open the buildings in deep ochre complement the greenery all around. Take a leisurely walk in the complex visiting Ho Chi Minh's simple house on stilts, the underground shelter next to it. Stroll around the lake taking in the wonderful trees and bird-life. It's just a nice feeling, the simplicity of it all in the midst of nature.
Lovely to walk through. A great place to visit after the mausoleum. The house on stilts that Ho Chi Minh lived in is very sparse and worth viewing.

Interesting. It was interesting to see where Ho Chi Minh spent his later years, very simple and beautiful area to walk around, a guide to talk you through everything is probably a good idea although we didn,t have one.

Left as it was when HO Chi Minh ruled the country-- original and simple. Lines of school children and an organized march as you tour HO Chi Minh's home. He is still venerated by the public and you see young and old touring the palace. It does not have a palace feel but a beautiful garden, very simple home and it certainly is not palace like in any way. Don't miss going as it gives you a feel for the country and it's simplicity but also it determination.Also great Ho Chi Minh pitch in the museum shop--great take away memories.

Visit after the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. After visiting the mausoleum, the next part of the route is a brief walk past the presidential palace (though you can only look from the outside), a building housing his former offices, and then the stilt house. A few practical details: 1) get your camera back before you enter this gate, 2) know that the traffic stream is unidirectional, so you can't really turn around or return to take another path, and 3) that you can't actually go into the presidential palace

Just A Quick Look.. A revered figure for many this glimpse into his austere lifestyle is eye opening. Crowds of tourists come here to see Ho Chi in state and then wander out into the grounds to see the palace and his wooden house. Part of the history and an important Vietnamese hero so worth a visit.

It's History. I found this site fascinating. It was interesting to see how Ho Chi Min actually lived. He didn't live in the big fancy palace but in a simple little house. He truly was an ideologue and lived as he said one should, simply. The gardens and pond were very pleasant to walk around. The mausoleum was a bit weird, seeing the body preserved, looked like a wax figure.
Huge site with interesting buildings. We caught a platoon of soldiers marching around the parade ground at the back of the mausoleum on the way to the One Pillar Pagoda.

One of those sites you should visit. Forgetting the "nned to see it" it is very a very pleasant place to wander through and see the simpleway of life he really wanted to lead. Nice cars - three of them. His first a big armoured glass from Russia.

Beautifully manicure gardens. So much of Vietnam appears run down too the western eye, this place has a large staff of groundskeepers and officials, they truly value its appearance. Visiting Ho Chi Minhs house and office reminds us that you done need grandeur to achieve.

Simple but elegant. ho chiming mausothis reveals to us that great people do not need grand palaces to help and recuse their nation.His bed ,his writing table .sitting chair and room all reflect his total dedication to work for his nation dedicatedly not to manifest the worldly riches.

Have a guide! engvuthy@ymail.com is amazing!. This Is a great a great site but without a guide its hard to appreciate the history and politics of the time. We hired a excellent tour guide for $20USD..6hours plus paid Taxi fares. Still a bargain compared to a tour company and we picked the sites. He was willing to add to our choices and we covered all the main attractions of Saigon....be
Impressive yet simple. A visit here gives you a peek into Ho Chi Min and his presidency. Shows you the simplicity that he lived with. You also can better appreciate life from a communist perspective.

Mausoleum and Presidential Palace. Arrive early to avoid crowds. Gardens and historical buildings interesting. Ho Chi Minh museum well worth a visit. Remember to dress appropriately for entry to Mausoleum.

Nice form the outside. Here we have propaganda central and very little about Ho Chi Minh himself who by all accounts was an extraordinary leader. The museum was awful. The mausoleum was in the style of Soviet realism (ie ugly) - and by the way Ho requested a simple cremation not this monstrosity. The house where he lived was not much. But you should visit - if nothing else to watch the pilgramageof people and to see the buildings form the outside.

incredibly organized. From the time you walk in, which is free by the way you have a clear knowledge of where you need to go. This is wonderful when language is a problem. This is a beautifully clean & well presented complex which to me shows just how much this man was revered.
Great Spectacle. Well worth a visit to see the old colonial palace and where Uncle Ho lived, worked and died. we didnt bother with his museum but did que for a short while to see him lying in state.

fascinating history. You see Ho Chi Minh himself, his homes in the complex, the pagoda on one column and the grounds. The line to see Ho is very long but moves very quickly so don't be discouraged if you see lots of people waiting. It goes very quickly.

Well worth a visit. A very moving and interesting museum which graphically shows the suffering of the Vietnamese inmates - especially by the French. The section on the treatment of US prisoners of war clearly is the Vietnamese take on this matter - it was rather at odds with the information that we "in the west" had. Take an hour to visit - you wont regret it

All good but nothing special. This was OK, we really went to see the the leader lying in state, that was odd in its self . So we payed and went round thee grounds and house as well.The problem with this is the hoards of people, you get shuffled around, not really able to Stop and take anything in, I spent more time looking at the 3 old state cars than anything else.All fine but for us it was a bit odd voyeristic experience that I was none to bothered about but interesting all the same.

A bit of history. If you like the war stories, then this takes you to the place where the South Vietnamese Goverment operated during the war and it displays the heroic end of war, when this palace was captured by the Vietkong Army.
Interesting, but not a must see.
Great place. Great place to visit gives you a real insight into how Ho Chi Minh lived as a really modest man, very interesting

Kings palace for a King. Lovely grounds, house/palace, very interesting to see how kings lived in those days. Enjoyed it. Apart from his palace there was a summer house and a temple, beautiful surroundings

Must visit. Visited Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum. Well organised and even with large crowds you are quickly through. Obviously a sober location and one the local people hold in high regard. His stilt house and surrounding area is worth a visit but a guide helps to explain what you are seeing and what the significance is.

Weird.. You can feel the influence of the 'past', with guards on duty, getting everyone to fall into line - walking two by two, slowly controlled and directed around the Palace grounds, eventually leading into the building where, in silence, and in single file, you walk past the heavily guarded embalmed body of the former president Ho Chi Minh himself! Weird. Its one of those moments you think... ok, I guess I should go to the Palace and learn about the history.. then leave wondering 'what just happened'!

the guards wont let you near. I was not impressed - you can sort of see it from a distance but there are loads of guards so it is difficult to get a good spot for a photo. And we found that there was no admittance to see the rooms of state.

Lovely grounds and buildings. I guess this will be on your list of places to visit. The buildings are grand French colonial age and the surrounding park land extremely pleasant. Lots of areas out of bounds so there is a definitive route to follow. You'll walk round along with hundreds of other tourists. It's worth a visit. His mausoleum is a stark communist style edifice - as you would expect. Try to get to the museum of Ho Chi Minh's life. In a separate building on 3 floors. Very accessible displays and also in English. This was the best bit.

Very good place to visit.... To stroll around the grounds of the Palace was a great treat, beautiful pond with trees and plants to feast your eyes. Very well presented and cared for with a good window in to how Ho Chi Minh lived.

Lovely garden. This attraction would have only 3 stars if it wasn't got the garden. The presidential palace is now used to receive heads of state, etc. and is not open to the public. It looks like a minor French chateau.The houses where Ho Chi Minh lived and worked are a visual reminder of the simplicity of the man, but nothing special, and over-run with visitors. The couple of old cars are interesting.However the garden is well thought out and maintained and it is possible to find a quiet spot to just sit and relax.

Palace grouds are beautiful. It's a pity this historic French colonial monument is not open to visitors. The gardens are beautifully kept, and offer a moment of tranquility in this otherwise bustling city.

Pretty grounds & worth the time. To be clear, contrary to what some reviews indicate, this is an entirely different attraction than the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. They are located next to one another but you can do one and not the other or do both if you choose. For this attraction, you enter the grounds of the Presidential Palace which is full of beautiful gardens and ponds, the old servants' quarters where Ho Chi Minh lived for 4 years and his stilt house where he lived until his death. There were a lot of people so not much ability to enjoy the scenery peacefully and without distraction. You basically walk with the mob through the defined paths to see the various attractions. With that said, though, I still highly recommend visiting. The deep gold and green colors were awesome for photographs and the reflections on the ponds worked well with the camera too. I suggest going with a guide to explain what you will be seeing as there are not many captions or signs to read on your own. It is all outside so be cognizant of the weather when you choose to go. Considering the lines and crowd, I'd make sure to leave at least 1-2hrs to get in and out.

History. Grounds are beautiful and peaceful. Changing go guard is precise and the military step is interesting to watch as it is so differs the to the west. Cypress tree roots are amazing, as are the grafted "two-types" in same root system, stilt house is authentic - even if a little transplanted. Palace is cement, but done in the French yellow. Tomb closed on Mondays- but people watching in the boulevard and Mango paths is always educational, PS - take your own TP for WC,
Know the History. It's interesting to see how Uncle Ho lived his life and preferred a simple accommodation built in the palace gardens.

Very busy. Very hot day and very long queue, you had to stay in line one of our party put there hands behind there back, a soldier came and made him put then at his side. Beautiful grounds, worth a visit, you can see and feel the reverence they hold Ho Chi Min in.

Old French colonial park. The grounds are beautiful and reasonably peaceful. The palace is elegant but not open to the public. Looking at the houses and artifacts ofUncle Ho lets you know how he was the savior of Vietnam (with no mention that he fought a waragainst the south as soon as the french left). All in all its a nice counterpart to the mausoleum.

Begs belief.. Whilst in Hanoi it would be chirlish not to visit the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and Presidential Palace.It is remarkable how the powers that be have spent fortunes on embalming the body of this great leader (who led the country to independence and reunification), and set it up on show for all to slowly process past in a solemn fashion. Get there early as "the body" is lowered out of sight to the lower basement where the embalming procedure is continued by qualified doctors.. Weird, when one thinks that HCM wanted only to be cremated and have his ashes scattered around his beloved Vietnam. Weirder still when you then visit the palace and gardens and realise that once again HCM didn't go for all this grandeur, so ordered the construction of a traditional Vietnamese house on stilts to be built in the palace gardens.

Respects to Ho Chi Minh. You need to arrive early as all of the Vietnamese people also queue to see the body of Ho Chi Minh. You need to have sleeves and either pants or a knee length skirt. Water bottles are not permitted inside and won't pass the scanner. It took me an hour in the queue on a Saturday morning. Afterwards you can look at some of the other buildings in the complex including the stilt house and also see the cars owned by Ho Chi Minh. It was very crowded but fills on a couple of hours.

A must although not a delight. When one is in Vietnam one should see part of the history. And Uncle Ho is a big part of that till now. See how young children and old people are lining up to see his body and see where he worked, what cars comrad politicians from other countries gave him.

Very tranquil. This place really surprised me! The tranquility and beauty of the property was amazing. To have lived back in this time and actually been able to live in a place like this would be spectacular!
A much revered hero. We went on a Sunday and were delighted that so many Vietnamese citizens were sightseeing. Everything was well maintained and the various architectural designs were of interest.

Visit Uncle Ho. I was a teenager when the war was at its height. Ho led his nation to victory over the world's mightiest military power, and now he sleeps in peace. We loved his little 'Stilt House', where he lived as President rather than in the grand palace next door, built by the French for their colonial governors. Be sure to seek it out, as the signs to it are not all that clear.
Ho Chi Minh President. it's a rest place of Ho Chi Minh president who is national hero and brought the freedom for Vietnamese people.
History. Very good tour and you must arrive early. Must see Ho Chi Minh in his casket. A guide will explain everything get one.
Interesting building. It tells lot of the current history of Vietnam.Of course lot of propaganda type of information, but easy to decipher what is factual from what is posted.

Other buidings more interesting than HCM Mausoleum. We had to queue for 30 minutes in the hot sun to shuffle past the embalmed body of HCM for about 3 minutes so didn't rate that very much. But the rest of the site is impressive. Presidential palace apparently not used by HCM but only for greeting foreign high-ranking visitors. We were told by our guide that he lived much more modestly in two houses surrounding a beautiful lake. You can also see where his bomb bunker was close to his summer house. Aim to spend a couple of hours at least to see the whole site (if you bother with the mausoleum bit).

Very Information. I thought that this would be a boring site, but to my surprised I learned a lot about the history of Vietnam and the reasons for the war. The grounds are beautiful. Prepare to spend some time here to appreciate all the buildings and gardens.
Superb gardensetting. Lots of local tourists made for some queues but well worth a visit to capture some of the life and history of Ho Chi Minh.

Two Dwellings?. Situated in a pleasant park one could only view the palace at a distance, not where Ho Chi Minh lived but a stones throw away, He didn't want the grandeur and small simple house next to a lake. Worth seeing but nothing spectacular.

A must do.. The whole complex is an important site in the history of the country and Uncle Ho's life. Lines are very long into the mausoleum. Remember closed Friday and Monday and the last people are permitted in at 11am. The gardens surrounding the mausoleum are beautiful.
Palace. Vast area with great sights. History everywhere and without a guide you might not get to see it all. Interesting way to spend a few hours in Hanoi

Beautiful grounds. The gardens and the palace were very pretty. It was a nice walk around the grounds even though it was quite crowded (I went on a Sunday). The one thing I didn't like was the caged peacocks that were in the gardens. There were two peacocks in a cage which was just wide enough to spread it's feathers. Seemed very unnecessary. Other than that an enjoyable visit

Why is it an attraction if you can't go in?. This place is not the White House where a living President resides so then why can't we go in? The house is rather large yet modest. It would be fascinating to go in and visit and see his life of luxury while his troops lived like rats in tunnels! In any case, the cars in the back/or front of the compound are interesting. Had I known I couldn't enter, I wouldn't have paid the entrance fee.

Tombs for Beloved Leaders--so much a bore!. The Presidential Palace is set in a Park but the building is not open to the public. There are other smaller buildings, the small auto collection for example, and more surrounding a small pond. Tucked back of the Ho Chi minh Tomb, it is a relief to spend time in the trees as opposed to the vast open and hot square in front of the Tomb. Nice pagoda tucked away in the area.

Peaceful oasis in a bustling city. the whole site is immaculately kept, with armies of uniformed gardeners and white uniformed guards ( who all look about 12)A useful insight into this national hero , especially useful if you are only used to the western view of him. Put us in mind of Gandhi's house in Delhi. Very simple modest way of life.

Interesting. you line up for about 20 mins then shuffle past the guards to see HCM preserved in glass. Not the most exciting but probably worth it to see as he was the most influential person in recent Vietnamese history

Beautiful!. Good destination for any holidays. I love going there for peaceful and natural. I think that the family should take the children to visit there, they should know about the history of the nation.

Nice if you have the time. This is a pleasant enough reminder of 'Uncle', but the museum is much more impressive and informative. Having said this, the Palace does show the simple lifestyle of the man that made Vietnam.

Definitely Worth a Visit. The Ho Chi Minh palace is historical site is most definitely worth a visit. The entry fee of 25,000 VND is peanuts and the great thing is that all the exhibits have English & French translations. As someone who grew up during the Vietnam War I found the exhibits most interesting. You follow a prescribed path through the building and on the way out down the stairs you will find excellent toilet facilities. On the day that we visited unfortunately the Mausoleum was closed to visitors.

Worth visiting to understand some of Vietnam's historical past.. Although this might seem a morbid site to visit, we were glad we went with our guide who gave us a good explanation of the turbulent times of this country. It helped us to understand what the country went through. Often called 'The Hanoi Hilton', it was anything but!
Impressive. A very impressive exposition of Uncle Ho. A must see when visiting Ha Noi. Also a good place to retreat from the hustle and bustle of the city.

A meaningful trip. The privilege of seeing and paying respect to Vietnam's national hero is obvious. But beyond that, we also found this to be a very well run and enjoyable sightseeing trip. Based on the number of locals and schoolchildren, this is very clearly an important site to the Vietnamese. As a tourist, it is our privilege to be a respectful visitor. Show up early, as the lines are long (but move fast) and the site is only open in the mornings.

Helps understand Vietnamese history. Despite the deification, Ho Chi Minh was a true hero to the Vietnamese people. He spent his life working for their freedom and liberty. This site together with the prison brings a better understanding of Vietnamese history in the 20th century. Having a guide through this beautiful site helps bring it to life and helps fill in the details. There are guides available at the entrance.

Long queue for visit less than 5 minutes. Perhaps because i visited on Sunday i found very long queue to enter the President site, I also have to turn around far away for queue infact i came from president house but the army ask to go to entry gate which is make us walk around the site. i just feel misty when entering the room where the Ho chi minh president was lay down and want to quit soonest. There are 4 guards in every corner of the body and another 4 in corner of the room.

An open Palace of course you must visit. The entire palace can be viewed even the private residence, The meeting rooms are elaborate and beautifully presented. The view from the balcony is awesome. A version of the historical tank is in the gardens. Do go down and see the bunker underground.
Very interesting historical site. It was a powerful experience stepping back into such a rich history and learning more about Ho Ch Minh

Where Ho was Real. The historical site is a natural addition to any visit to Ho's mausoleum, but even if you aren't into preserved bodies, it's well worth visiting. The mausoleum next door makes it clear that Ho is truly dead, just in case you were wondering. But the historical site will bring him to life in your mind. The simplicity of the few rooms in which he lived and worked and the tranquillity of the gardens surrounding them say a great deal about who he was, how much he loved his country, and the determination with which he struggled to achieve independence for his people.

Interesting " palace". not a palace but more of a home where Ho chi min lived. Very peaceful and again you stand in line to go around the grounds and his house. They also have his used cars on exhibit. Beautiful grounds and interesting trees.
Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace. Get to know Ho Chi Minh historical site of the place he stayed and worked and the surrounding environment.

Do This In Conjunction With The Mausoleum. Beautifully maintained park like grounds exhibiting the contrast of the French built palace and influence with the life and life style of Ho Chi Minh. Very informative.

Nice gardens, interesting place. Very intersting to see how Uncle Ho lived and what a modest man he was...respect! The gardens are nice and peaceful, few visitors when I was there, maybe just lucky...very reasonable entrance fee, 25.000 dong

Calm and relax place to visit and stroll through the afternoon. The park was huge and spacious. Felt very 'village' and gone back in time. Setting was nice and comfortable. Sat down for a cup of local coffee to enjoy the scene and air.

Nice atmosphere. Weather was very cooling in Feb in hanoi. Museum and palace site are interesting and there is place for u to buy drinks and snacks. A lot of locals visiting during TED holidays and lots of tourist groups too. only open 8-10:30 , so go there early and queue to go in to museum and behave properly. There are guards everywhere near and inside museum.
Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace. Excellent setting, peaceful surroundings but the guards were rushing us around and kept asking us to move on...

modesty?. the complex contains the french presidential palace as well as some small and modest houses used by Ho Chi Minh when he was the president. very simple furniture, naked walls and floor - really simple amd modest. but there are several houses like that in the complex, with a totla of many rooms used for a variety of occarions. in total all of those sum up to a medium size pallace, modest but not very small if you add the bunker as well.nice garden with a very nice fish pool with appealing reflections.very interesting place.
Good place. The prediential place was wonderful with me as its peace, its atmosphere. That place has huge of fishes.

It's near the Mausoleum so visit at same time. Popular with locals but you only looked in from a distance. The house on stilts was well presented.Have a look at the cars - from a Peugot to armoured Russian Zil.

Good if you want to learn about Ho Chi Minh . I suggest a guide so you will learn the history of Ho Chi Minh. We did not get to go inside the place but we got to tour the two homes he lived in. The gardens were beautiful.

A statesman's resting place. It is a place worth visiting to pay respect to Ho Chi Minh. Whatever difference we may have over politics and war from his ideology, he did dedicate his whole life to his country and people.
House of Ho. Informative and quite luxurious - gardens prettyThey take you around a one way route and will not let you deviate so missed the motor museum

Amazing place. A fascinating place and very interesting that Ho Chi Minh lived a simple life without frills. The lake was beautiful and particularly interesting were the roots of the trees and pomelo trees.
Presidental Palace. Worth the visit but recommend a guide to give one the historical prespective which is important. Well worth it,

Interesting part of Vietnam's history.. Worth a visit, the buildings are well maintained as are the exhibits we were allowed to see. Public are not admitted to the Presidential Palace or into the Stilt House, although you can walk around the Stilt House. The Lake is peaceful and well stocked with carp. The usual tatty gift shop at the end of the tour.

An eye opener. Good to see the relatively humble accommodation that Ho Chi Minh found to be satisfactory for the latter part of his life. Much, much smaller than the monument felt necessary to house his remains.The need to commemorate such an important man with a pretty austere looking edifice is perhaps understandable.Less understandable and unforgivable is the way in which his wish to be cremated and his ashes scattered throughout Hanoi has been ignored. What a poor reward for the greatest Vietnamese person there has been.The gardens throughout the site are very well maintained and attractive

It is worthy to visit. If you are in Hanoi, you should visit the main sites as no many people will return there. The Presidential Palace was never used by Ho Chi Min who lived by the pond in a very simple house, later in the stilt house and finally in other place like a bunker where he died. All 3 houses are located by the Presidential Palace use for diplomatic receptions or meetings. The botanical garden around these places is nice. You can't visit the Presidential Palace inside though.

Don@t go on a monday. We would have loved to go inside here but a word of warning-it's not open on a Monday.The outside was very like Lenin's mausoleum in Moscow.They show great respect for their leader ho chi minh everywhere in Hanoi.
Wish you could see more. You can see the summer home, but not inside the main palace. I would have liked yo see more, but did enjoy what was there. It does not take long to go through.

More for pictures as you walk by. Personally, I have only walked by the place. It sits next to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, which is a far better for pictures but, the palace is nice to walk by and take a picture just to say you did.

A rather unique experience. We visited Ho Chi Minh Mauseleum and the Presidential Palace site. It was a very strange experience walking past Ho Chi Minh's body which has been in state since 1969. The guards in the Mauseleum are very strict about the process of viewing and will keep you moving. You are not able to take any photographs inside but once you are outside you can visit the rest of the grounds which show Ho Chi Minh's house where he chose to live, the presidential palace and the beautiful grounds. He truly was a person of the people choosing to stay in a humble dwelling rather than the palace. This tour really gave you an insight into why the Vietnamese people love Ho Chi Minh so much.

Worth visiting. There is a cost for foreigners here, VND20,000 but not for locals, fair enough. This is a pleasant way to spend an hour or so though the gardens are fairly basic, more parkland than anything and the buildings are not open to the public. The exception is the stilt house where Comrade Ho lived, very sparingly one would think with US bombs being dropped all over. The stilt house and the views through glassed-in doors in his work and reception rooms and garage reveal a man who lived very simply. This site has no bells and whistles, it is very simple in its essence and presentation but nevertheless, is well worth visiting. The security presence here is not as intrusive as at Ho's mausoleum. The tourist shops all the way to the gate are a disappointment in such a historically important site. An area of calm well worth visiting.

A must see. Fascinating site to see how the revered "Uncle Ho" ruled and where he lived. Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum is very impressive and while the lines may be long, they move quickly. Be aware of the dress code
Lovely French Colonial Building.. Our Guide described everything in an understanderable way. It's an area of quietness and calmness. I expect it's busy in the Summer. Visit after the Mausoleum.

Worth a visit, especially HCM museum. The presidential palace is nice to see where Ho Chi Minh lived for the last decade or so. Although Uncle Ho did not live very extravagantly, he did have a lot of gifts, including 3 cars. The Palace was crowded with tourists and tour groups on Sunday late morning, so try to go early to avoid the crowd. After the palace, head to the HCM museum, which was well organized with good amount of information from the Vietnamese perspective. Expect to spend about 2 hours.

interesting. This complex comprises the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, the Governor's Palace, the house on stilts, the One Pillar Pagoda & the HCM Museum all in lovely parkland. The downside of the visit is the security staff who keep you moving on with barely a second to look (particularly at the house on stilts) but the exhibits are interesting to see ... State cars, phones etc used by HCM & the contrast between his official residence (closed to the public but a beautiful colonial building) & the simple house on stilts he chose to live in

Worth a visit. Especiallyif you like old cars - Ho Chi Minh;s 'fleet' is encased in glass there. A nice old Peugeot and an early 50's Packard too. There is also a Russian made car that that we didn't recognize but in perfect showroom condition
I respect Bac Ho. As a Vietnam Bac Ho everyone knows , Here you can understand the history of Vietnam in general , and about Uncle Ho own words . A good person to follow.

Good insight into Ho Chi Minh. This sight sounds like a busy day, but in reality it only takes about 1hr-1.5 hours. Get here early to avoid queues. Shows you where Ho Chi Minh worked during his final 15 years, shows his cars, houses, the outside of the presidential palace, and of course his Mausoleum. Watching the guard of honour change so ofter, in there brilliant white uniform is also worth a watch.
A cultural experience. Worth it just to see Uncle Ho lying in state in the Mausoleum he had to have (whether he wanted it or not). The 'queueing process' is an experience in itself.

Educational. This is a pleasant place to visit while in Hanoi. A walk around the presidential palace will through light on the life and times of Ho Chi Minh. You can see the cars in the garage, his small preferred home, garden and the lake where Ho Chi Minh would stay.
nice , gardentype. Nice french architecture. Got to see ho chi minh's house and how simple he was, being a leader of the country.nicely maintained gardens and residence.

It’s the bright yellow palace. Located next to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, it’s the big bright yellow fenced off presidential property. We viewed the palace from the front and it’s a really interesting shade of yellow that one would not see often. Tours of the interior are not possible and this would be the same residence where visiting heads of state (i.e... Germanys’ Angela Merkel) would reside while visiting. This attraction can easily be viewed in addition with the Mausoleum, museum, One Pillar Pagoda.
The building is really amazing... it is very interesting, the architecture is in Italian Renaissance Style, very nice and refine. it is worth the visit
Very interesting, nice building and setting. You enjoy the pleasant setting, and it also helps understanding the history of Vietnam and the personality of Ho Chi Minh

Do walk by if you're in the mausoleum anyway.. A park with a presidential palace in it, as well as Ho Chi Minhs old house, his garage and his offices. The gardens are nice but you're not allowed to just walk about, and most places are off limits. Gives some very useful insights into the popularity of 'uncle Ho' though, and should not be missed when you are visiting the mausoleum (and that's a must-see in Hanoi)
Boring. I found it boring and did not enjoy standing in lines for such a long time in the heat. Worth it if you are a huge HCM fan

Nice to see. This is a nice thing to see after being at the Ho Chi Mausoleum, the ground are lovely and it is a nice escape from the Hanoi city. I think if I had my time again in Hanoi, however, I would have gone to the Temple of Literature before seeing other sites which are not as exciting. With three days in a city you cannot see everything you want, however, especially travelling with young children.

Attractive for History Buffs. Well the actual Palace cannot be entered, but you can visit Ho Chi Minh's old house on the stilts as well as the other house where he worked from. It is a nice walk, in their gardens and around the pond. Sadly the 1st time we went there, we were not allowed to enter as they shut at 2pm, which if they had told us when we reached there, we could have seen the house first instead of the museum.

A must see in Hanoi. This is an interesting place to visit. It is steeped in Vietnamese history from the French Colonial period through to the time of Ho Chi Min's residence. After visiting the site of the Mausoleum (it was closed on the day we visited so we only saw the changing of the guard) we walked round to the Residence and then to the Palace - although hardly a palace in our terms. Ho Chi Min's cars - a Peugeot and two Russian cars - his quarters and the house on stilts. The yellow painted building made great reflections in the lake on a very chilly, grey day.

Vietnamese Comunist Leader House. After seeing his body well conserved by the Russia's at a masoleum, his house, the Presidential Palace if all of wood, simple, gardens and gives the ideia of the times. Nearby is the garage with some cars used by him...Definitelly, he is a major figure and his palace reflect his simple life as a Comunist should have,.

Historical importance. Is an Historical point, you can enjoy it with a tour guide, but there are better places to visit in Hanoi!! during the winter is lighten up and is nice to see during the evening

Independence, freedom, struggle. A respect to the great leader. Long queue to pay respect to the freedom fighter both from Vietnamese and foreigners alike. The entrance to the mausoleum is from Ngoc Ha street, to the west of the mausoleum. Better to inform your driver to drop you there, else it is long walk from the main street I.e., Hung Vuong. No entrance fees to get into the mausoleum where Ho Chi Minh body is preserved. However cameras are not allowed, so they will provide you with a camera bag where by you leave this camera before you enter the mausoleum and pick it up after you exit the area (on the way to Ho Chi Minh house).After paying respect, you are free to wander around the area snapping photos. If you are interested to visit the house, the entrance fee is 25000 VND per person. Worth a visit especially the mausoleum itself. Open daily except Monday and I think it is also closed on Friday afternoon. Whenever it opens, the visit time is from 8am - 11am and 2pm - 4pm.
Have to go see. His body is embalmed and in resting in a glass case surrounded by security for everyone to see. He is sent back every three years to Russia fir re embalming

Grand and informative. There are many parts to this property, so plan to be there a couple of hours. There is the mausoleum, the gardens, various buildings and offices, the palace and residence, a suspected bunker, the changing of the guards at certain times, and the gauntlet of vendors as you depart.

The private house of Ho Chi Minh is a must see...the palace not so much. It was interesting to see the humble house of Ho Chi Minh and its grounds. Although you cannot go inside, you are more than able to see the private rooms of the residence. the palace, although grand from the outside, was not so interesting.

Great insight into Ho Chi MInh. a very busy site but well laid out: house on stilts really interesting and conveyed simplicity of Ho's lifestyle. Relaxing place to stroll around and after the mausoleum, no pressure to rush through. Lots of school children visiting who are fascinated by Westerners and it was so lovely to listen to them practise their English and let them take selfies!

Nothing special. Visited as part of our trip to the mausoleum. The Presidential palace itself is quite an impressive looking building, however you're not able to get within 20 meters of it and obviously not allowed inside.The residential area itself again is a little interesting, however you can only view it from the outside. If visiting on a sunny day it may be better, however during a damp and grey day there is little to interest and make it worth the time.

Go late in the afternoon. Touring after 3:30 allowed us to see the grounds without the crowds. It made seeing the house and garden more relaxing. WE spent an hour and a half and could have spent more time if we had it. It is alot of walking and some areas were under construction.

well preserved. being one part of Ho Chi Minh complex, Presidential palace is a stunning building. The place is for the official residence of the president but specially, Ho Chi Minh president refused to live in this luxurious house. interesting! now, it is still preserved very carefully like any other tourist attraction. The Palace interior is not open to tourists but Regular visitors are allowed access to the Palace's botanical gardens, where you can get a good look at the Palace's fruit trees and Ho's stilt house. The Palace is visible from the beginning of the visitors' path.

Beautiful Area. Our tour group of 20 took Cyclo-rickshaws to visit this area. They are beautiful grounds, very nicely maintained. Not overly crowded. Guarded by special guards in white uniforms. Very interesting government and historical buildings.
Peaceful place in a busy city. We found this interesting and well worth the visit. The grounds are beautiful and peaceful in a very busy city.

Wow, so amazing. Just passing by all the government buildings here is so amazing. These buildings are fantastic. It is sad that one is not allowed to take pictures. If you can try and get one picture if they are not looking. So amazing building after building. Wow I want to get back soon.

Yellow building. The yellow building is just looking nice.. Got entrance fee to get in the location.. Cant get near the house of Ho Chi Minh but you cant go to the stilted house in front of the pond.. Just beautiful! A must go places..

Interesting Place. Walking through the grounds was fascinating as was looking at the stilted house Ho worked in. Was really fascinating that the US did not bomb this place at all during the war and Ho could keep a daily routine. The US learned lessons from this in both wars with Iraq.

Fabulous Gardens. This was not placed on our itinerary by our tour company, but we fit it in and were glad we did. The gardens surrounding the site were the perfect calm, beautiful place to relax after our long travel from the US and we enjoyed seeing both the french era buildings and the more characteristically vietnamese house built for Ho Chi Minh.
manners. closed on fridays. take of shades when going inside the mausoleum. take out hands from pockets too. very organized.

Interesting if not a littel strange. A very interesting area but we went without our guide so probably didn't get the most out of it. Ceremonial guards aren't the friendliest but that's ok. Ho Chi Minh Museum was one of the strangest museums we have been to - history crossed with Art deco ! All worth a visit.

You was a big guy Mr. Ho Chi Minh. The Museum is very, very nice, I met a lot of people at the ticket Office and inside and all of them super nice and friendly, they did everything for us. The only peaty is that Mr. Ho Chi Min was not looking for a Presidential Palace, he wanted to be cremate but in the other hand the people did all in order to thank him for what he did for the Vietnamise people. Very, very nice all the story behind the Presidential Palace. You should go and visit him after read something about Mr. Ho CHI MIN.

Walk Like A Russian. It was ok. Best part was all of the military, walk this way, drop your arms, no hands in pockets...what a hardship for young Americans with their stupid caps. Funny just to watch them try to follow rules,epic fail.

Worth a Quick Look. This is one of the buildings from the French colonial area. It is worth spending a few minutes having a look around the outside, though you cannot go inside. Worth making a little detour if you are in the area, which you probably will be as there are lots of other interesting things in this part of the city.
True history. Go see the Mosoleum, pagoda, and this place as soon as it opens in the morning to avoid all the tourists. Take a look at real buildings and structures used by Ho Chi Minh and others

Ho Chi Minh's official residence in Hanoi. A lovely hour spent touring both Ho's official residence and the simple house in the grounds where he lived throughout the War. Although there were inevitably many tourists there (a large number of whom were Vietnamese) it was very well organised and everyone had a chance to see and enjoy it all. Delightful gardens and a large pond which brought a sense of real peace to the place, although the official palace was fairly humdrum and functional

Most popular attraction in Hanoi, must visit.. This huge memorial is in the same line as all economical poor communist countries invest huge people's money in one man memorials and investing big money in embalming dead body of leader . The huge complex include Presidential Palace, Politburo meeting room, old used cars of president, House no. 54 , Buddha trees, Cypress tree , President Ho Chi Minh museum, one pillar Pagoda etc. timings are awkward from tourist point of view : morning 7:30 to 11AM, evening 2-4 PM open every week days , closed on Monday n Friday evening.

Worth a visit. it is best to do this attraction with a proper guide otherwise you would have to wait in a very long queue. After visiting the Mausoleum we kept on going along the path and went to see where Uncle Ho used to live.

Refreshing, beautiful, photogenic!. The delightful Oriental architecture set amongst lakes and trees must have been a great tonic for Ho Chi Minh if he ever had a down day. He really lived simply, and this place was an education as well as a refreshing 45 minute tour.

Stunning in Appearance!. It was a guided tour around the lakes and home of Ho Chi Minh, when we saw the palace through the trees. French colonial in style, it is stunning. We gazed and gazed, but understand that one cannot be admitted unless one is a national president or similar. But loved the exterior. Awesome!
interesting. The site has 'Uncle Ho''s home on it. Interesting to see how simply he lived. Enjoyed the visit despite pouring rain....

we are Vietnamese people, too!. we are from venezuela but we admire Ho Chi Minh president so much that we choose his palace historical site as the first place we come to Vietnam. the palace has a special structure and it is surrounded by others historical site, too. in his private house, every thing is simple and well- protected. it is great.
Definately a standout building. A beautiful, bright yellow building I stumbled upon accidentally walking from the Ho Chi Minh complex. Well worth a couple of photos.

not so much for us. Yeah, why go here, seriously? Overcrowded by tourists, and for what? Nice to see how the government was seated and international guests were welcomed, and you can see the bunker. But we were so not impressed by it all. There are much beter things to do in Saigon. And the building itself is very ugly too.

Pleasant shady compound. Disappointingly little content - was expecting a true tribute to Uncle Ho, but very controlled access. Stilt house is modern construction; his old cars have 'pilgrimage relic' status; no access to old buildings.

Very modest dwelling. By the beautiful and very photographic Presidential Palace is the very modest Ho chi Minh house.Based on a rural Vietnamese stilt house this is where "Uncle Ho " lived the last years of his life.The inside is sparse, the study has his typewriter and books -the bedroom is equally sparse with just a bed, clock and telephone.All surrounded by trees and a small lake .This site also has the museum dedicated to his life ,the One Pillar Pagoda and the mausoleum (closed in November)

Amazing. We were with Viking a River group therefore did not have significant lines to deal with! It is interesting thinking of the history and seeing how loved zho Chi Minh was by theses people. The mosoleum was a shrine, respectful the way his body is preserved incredible.

Big place. We took a tour to the mausoleum , but don't go Monday, it was closed. But did see the changing of the guard. Everything else was open. Lots to see, need 2 or 3 hours. And that doesn't include standing in line to see Ho chi minh

Uncle Ho's home. Our impression of them here and the former residence of a head of state is completely different, the president's house will not be so in other countries. Ho Chi Minh's former residence perfectly natural elements and Vietnam compact housing construction flair. Walk in it, you will feel unique here.
Visitted July, 2014

All about Ho Chi Minh. This is the location of the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum (didn't queue to view) as well as his house and lovely extensive grounds, including an old pagoda. This is redolent of the more recent history of Vietnam, so both significant and pleasant.
Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace. You can get to the Presidential Palace directly after visit of Mausoleum. You may get here from Old Quarter by foot.
Vietnam Hero area. This area was nice and so much meetting for vietnam goverment with another country come to here meetting right. we saw have so much police and army stay here and working here.

Snapshot. Even that you cannot go inside, is good to let you imagination run. The building is really amazing... I still can imagine that building in the french colonial era and all over the time until our days, and all the stories that held inside.

Pure History. the first thing that cae to my mind when i visited this place was to imagine all the history that took place onsite... only that made my visit worth it. The beatiful yellow buildings are like taken from the story books.

Ho Chi Minh is revered in the North. It is obvious that HCM is revered in the North and the Palace, Mausoleum, and Ba Dinh Square have been dedicated to his memory. If you travel to the South, the comments are understandably not as glowing.
Historical. A fascinating piece of contemporary Vietnamese history. Well cared for, beautiful and fascinating especially Ho Chi Minh's private residence. Beautiful gardens.
Beautiful lake around the house. This was kind of interesting for me but not really. I think the highlight is the massive garden and pond.

Fascinating historical insight. We did a guided tour of the presidential palace and it is beautiful. A must see if you visit Hanoi. Beautiful lake around the house and the house on stilts which Ho Chi Minh lived in the last part of his life. Historical items to view including his cars!

Learn about the man. it was very interesting to learn about the personal side of Ho Chi Minh. We got to see the simplicity of his preferred lifestyle and the formal area that was created to host dignitaries from other countries. Beautiful gardens and lake.

Interesting site. wasn't what we thought a palace would look like!
Worth a couple hours stroll to check out.
Personal favorite was he bunker and war room in the basement!

The essence of Hanoi. This is a beautiful building. It features the simple life style favoured by Ho Chi Min. You will see it together with the Ho Chi Min Mausoleum and the Viet Palace which are set in a very artistic garden.The Palace is a restored French building.The essence of Hanoi is the successful blending of the best of French and Viet art and architecture

Lying in State. It is free to visit the mausoleum but no photos can be taken and the line of visitors moves slowly (no stopping allowed). Near the mausoleum there are other sites of interest which cost 25,000 dong admission. We visited in a Saturday morning as there is restricted visiting times; check before you visit to avoid disappointment.
