Lovely gardens and a history lesson as well. Very interesting to see how Ho Chi Minh lived a very humble life. They have everything set up as he lived when he passed away in 1969 so it's like walking back in time. Gardens and lakes on the property are beautiful.

Ho Chi Minh Masoleum. Interesting to see if you are a history buff, Ho Chi Minh was and still is much loved by the people a good insight into the Vietnamese culture and traditions. Be prepared for long queues, however everyone is friendly and particularly as a westerner the children love to say hello and ask where you are from.

Just a view from the outside. We only saw the Presidential Palace when our cab passed by it. We hailed the cab just outside the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum complex. We were told that entry to the Presidential Palace is prohibited so we did not bother anymore to walk over to its location to have a closer view of it. The building is beautiful, though, even from our passing view.

A must see. If you come to Vietnam, and have any interest in history, this is something you should see. It was interesting to learn more about Ho Chi Minh and see where he actually lived. It was quite crowded when we were there, so going early is a good idea.

Overrated. I found the whole HCM Complex a little overrated. The presidential palace is cool and you can walk around and check-out the different houses where Ho Chi Minh spent time, but you can't go inside the main presidential building, so there isn't really that much to see.

Mildly interesting. Decided to swing by here after seeing Uncle Ho in the mausoleum. The site has pretty gardens and it was somewhat interesting to see where/how he lived. If you are in the area, stop in. If not, I would make the trip.
History visit. good tour around the HCM palace and museum, it helps to get a view on Vietnam's history and culture, worth the visit

When do
You get a chance to go in a place like this?. This was one of my most enjoyable real life historical sights in HCM city.
It is in original
Condition and has a wonderful glamorous feel to it.
The vibe is awesome and it's not too time consuming.

amazing to see, very particular hours. This is an amazing building. Its big and yellow and cool. I go there around 3 and it was already closed for the day but still cool to see while seeing Ho Chi Minh tomb.
Go if you are in the neighborhood. We visited after seeing Uncle Ho. I liked the park and it was very interesting to see how he lived. Simple and stark interiors.

remarkable to see where Ho lived. Simple, almost tropical, spare and reminded me of Gandhi, quite honestly. It's worth seeing, even if it just takes a few moments time,, certainly less than 30 minutes.

History Experience. Allow at least 2 hours or more. We got there later and was rushed.
It is worth making the time to see at a slower pace.

Uncle Ho's base. The walk is interesting mostly due to the size of the park surrounding the site especially on the contrast with the rest of super-packed Hanoi. One is wondering here where the reality borders the legend of super "modest" leader's life

Worth visiting but with a good tour guide. A place that's worth visiting when you go Hanoi because you get to see how simple his life was as a leader of the country. Everything was maintained well but make sure you have a good tour guide who can explain everything to you, tell you the story about this great leader. Or you need to google about him before you go because there is no board, pictures or anything with his story.

Avoid weekends , long busy queues, read up in advance as poor reporting here .. Worth the visit as it includes a few different areas, the palace is viewed from outside on a roadway only so that's a pity as not hectic for photo taking . However you do see the simple way Ho Chi Minh lived in the simple home and his summer house on stilts. Also his cars provided by the USSR are in display. These homes and cars are views from outside but you can see into the property's and its interesting. All these places Are very busy and just manic at the weekends and on public holidays when the Vietnamese all travel to pay their respects to Ho Chi Minh . There are long queues to vist his remains on display in the mauseleum and be aware you can't take bags or cameras in to the mausoleum but there are lockers to leave your property in. For the rest of the property you have security checks and xray machine queues for you and your bags. If u on a tour your guide will mind the property and give you information , if not read up before hand as the amount of historical information on display is most limited ....but all has some English translations.

Exterior view only and thats a pity.. The exterior of the building is all you see of this palace which is a shame as its a fine historical palace. It's a shame that the security there doesn't allow you a better vantage point to even take photos of the exterior as the area close is so prohibited its hard to get a decent photo. As its inc,used in the rest of Ho Chi Minh tour it's worth seeing .

Visiting Uncle Ho. Visiting the mausoleum of Uncle Ho was a an interesting experience and much more moving than I accepted. He was clearly a dearly loved and visionary leader. Also loved visiting his simple house on stilts in the palace grounds, a beautiful building that seemed to personify his character.

A palace you can't visit and a badly presented museum. The palace ground is very clean and almost artificial. Palace well painted but can't be visited. The Ho Chi MInh museum is an example of the worst museum presentation and content. After one hour there, I still have no clue on the life of Ho Chi Minh, were he was born, his life, his family, his politics, etc. just an empty museum fill with pictures, almost no text and not worth a visit.
Beautiful Place To Visit. Well worth the entrance fee and so much to see that you need to allow plenty of time to take everything in and would strongly advise to take a good camera.
Very peaceful place. I also want to have a place in my house to enjoy the fresh air with the natural winds in the afternoon. Very happy to come to the president house.

Simplicity yet powerful. The whole set up of the rooms and furniture show the simple needs of the man and yet the location and building demonstrate power in their own way.Much of what was there was paid for by Russia, including the cars used by Ho Chi Minh. The gardens brought an opportunity to have tranquility in a noisy city.

Lost and awe. When we arrived we weren't too sure where we had to go to enter. After spotting a line we just joined it and was pushed through security in a rush and with 0 English from any of the staff who spoke to us in Vietnamese. We were pushed through security and just randomly trailed behind people as we did not know where to go, there was no signage that could assists us as everything is in vietnamnese. The place was amazing and was very well maintained and had high security. Being such a significant place of history where tourist would want to visit I did expect it to be more accommodating to tourist but there was no information in English that could help us navigate or even understand the site. After roaming around the site and looking at all the beautiful architecture and beautiful landscaped surrounding i was disappointed as i would have liked to understand more about the place even just a little. It looked like you would have to hire a private guide to take you around if we knew this from the start it would have been something we would have done.
Beautiful. A beautiful place with lovely gardens and atmosphere. Very impressed with the whole area. Lots to see there.
Interesting .. Worth a visit to see how Ho Chi Minh lived. Check out the fish in the central lake, his car collection and his tree house.

Must see in Hanoi!. If you go to Hanoi, this should be number one on your list. Ignoring the politics, it is very interesting to see the reverence Vietnam holds for "Uncle Ho". They have done their best to keep him alive, though locals tell me the preserved body has lost weight over the years. The buildings and gardens on the compound are worth your time also.
looking good. all the site was being cleaned so we could only see from the outside, but looking great on a very big square

Home of Ho Chi Minh. The palace and gardens are beautiful. But the highlight was the humble home where Ho Chi Minh resided and ruled the country through difficult times. A short walk from the mausoleum and shouldn't be missed.
Uncle Ho was not available for showing. The university student guides made the historical role clear and informative. The grounds were nicely maintained in conjunction with the adjacent museum

Excellent with a guide. This is a don't miss site when in Hanoi. It's also a don't go without a guide site! There is little information in English, and a good guide will give you far more information about HCM and insight into the significance of the sites than any brochure. The only downside was the crowds. It wasn't so crowded that it was difficult to walk around, but it was difficult to take pictures and stop and discuss aspects of the sites. When in Hanoi, definitely hire a guide and check out the palace, house on stilts, pagoda, and mango road.

Beautiful, but sometimes crowded. Make sure you read up on what you are looking at: house on stilts (I want one) the smaller formal living quarters, and the huge palatial home, the fishing pond, etc. Beautiful grounds and gardening, well preserved and identified.

The history surrounding the palace is very fascinating! . Very fascinating to learn about president Ho Chi Minh's efforts and how and where he lived. The architecture is simple but very beautiful and the grounds are kept in great condition. If you have spare time in Hanoi, it's worth a look.

Be Guided Well. Very crowed place, the Vietnamese get in for free , but for everyone else there is a charge. The place becomes more interesting if you have a great guide who can inform you about the presidential homes. For example, there is a bunker under the hill behind his house on stilts, also the wooden chair in his house was given to him by Fidel Castro. There is a story about the pond too. All this information and more made our tour more interesting. There are no signs to help out the non-speaking Vietnamese. The French buildings are grand amongst the the other humble buildings that Ho Chi Minh lived in. Interesting for the history buff.
Very interesting!. What's a trip to Viet Nam for if we don't try to capture a little snippet of HCM. Very well preserved. Don't miss it if you're in Hanoi.

For a non vietnamese traveller, not so informative.. Don't be put off by the queus, this place is well worth the visit. Make sure you take a tour guide with you, as they can explain the significance of all the major buildings in this area, and how it relates to Vietnamese history. Expect crowds, it's a very popular place, especially for the locals, as well as tourists around the world. If you can, take your time just to enjoy the peacefulness, and serenity of this place. There are toilet facilities, but I didn't go in them, so can't vouch for how clean they are. Take at least 1-2 hours to enjoy this place, and loads of pictures, the french colonial style buildings are apparent in this place. Don't expect to understand the signs, unfortunately they are mostly written in vietnamese, so not so good for the english speaker. So do go with a guide.
Underwhelming. OK, but I felt I could have spent my time better someplace else. The house is only two rooms, but beautifully maintained. The three cars were interesting, but poorly displayed.

Impressive French Colonial Building. A very impressive, but startlingly yellow, early 20th century French colonial palace, built for their governors, but now used by the Vietnamese government for state occasions.The palace is not open to visitors, so one has to be content with viewing the exterior from a distance. The gardens are lovely, and afford some shade. You can also visit Ho Chi Minh's stilt house where he actually lived and worked, and see his car collection.
Must go. The museum is so well done up, informative and exhibits interesting. You cannot visit Hanoi and not visit this place!

Worth a visit. Well, you can see how humbly Ho Chi Minh lived. Too bad that isn't the way the Communist party leaders lived and are living. If there was a little more sharing of the wealth, perhaps the Vietnamese people would be a bit better off than they are. Anyway, you can see Ho Chi Minh's original house and then the house on stilts that he later moved to. Also, several cars that had been given to him. The grounds around his residence are quite nice.
Interesting but not exceptional. Of important historical interest, nice gardens- certainly not glamorous and a bit commercial. You have to be prepared for quite a walk.

Well worth a visit!. Really interesting place to visit, to see the simple way of life Ho Chi Minh lived his life in a truly communist way, with no luxuries. Well appointed gardens, with interesting & trees & lake.
average communist landmark. Nice park with tropical flavour. It is great that they honour their big man to such a degree. Maybe a better tour guide would have made our sightseeing more enjoyable.

Interesting visit. We couldn't visit the Mausoleum as it was closed but did walk round the gardens and see the house in which Ho Chi Minh lived. We were only allowed to look through windows which was a pity. However his second home was slightly more accessible, though we could not go inside the rooms were more open.
Pretty impressive. Ground are impressive though there is definitely The Cult of Personality at play. Only need about an hour to see everything

Historic building. We did not go inside the building, but it was very attractive and well-kept. I fainted while listening to our tour guide just outside the building, and the doctor and soldiers from the palace came right out to assist me. They were wonderful!
Strange in a good way. This was a strange experience. No cameras no talking no hands in your pockets but so glad I got chance to pass everything about it is a must see

Well worth a visit after the Mausoleum. The contrast with The President's last resting place is marked. He occupied simply furnished rooms in a delightfully peaceful setting. There is a very modest entrance fee (under £1) and you can purchase refreshments and souvenirs.

Great artifice but there are so many unnecessary restrictions for photography it is laughable if this is in the West. Beautiful and unique architecture and surrounds well kept gardens but the unhappy and suspicious looking guards and keepers can be intimitating. However, every country has its rules and the adage applies: "When in Rome, do as the Romans do."
Beautiful grounds. Very interesting to see the homes where Ho Chi Minh lived. Very peaceful place in a city filled with motor bikes.

Not Allowed. We went here as part of our very enjoyable walking tour. Nobody was allowed in because a Russian delegation were visiting so we cannot give a fair review. Just disappointed not to see it having travelled halfway round the world.

don't go there when holiday..long queu... it's better fot you to go form monday to friday, not on holiday or weekend because you will stuck in long queu..but over all this is one of interesting historical place to visit

A must do when in Hanoi. This is a relatively large area with a lot of open space. It includes his house where you can see his rooms plus the cars that he drove. Is also next to the presidential palace and not far from Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum
A must visit. A must visit. Check the opening hours as they don't open every day. PLUS they stop close during the day for rest. Is a great place to understand their history.
Palace visit. A very interesting place which gives an insight into the recent history of Vietnam. The place is meticulously kept.

Historical value. Visiting the presidential historical site add values to our trip this December. It gives us a glimpse into his lift style and why the country loves and respect him. The site is well kept and it was a nice afternoon stroll in the park.
Beautiful grounds. I loved the grounds, which are very well maintained. A lush garden in the middle of the city. A very enjoyable walk on a Saturday afternoon.
Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace. Our Guide from Indochina Odyssey took us to the Palace which was really fantastic to have a local guide who knew all the history

Impressive, even the changing of the guards still happens. The area is well maintained, busy with visitors. The entire area is worth a visit to understand the history of the country, the influence of the rulers, the ravages of the wars, blend with Buddhism, a mix that seems to tell that the Vietnamese have not forgotten but forgiven the genocide and inhuman acts perpetrated by a 'superpower' to force its ideology against one the colonials found it unacceptable in a country half way around the globe.The inequality still exists, the Vietnamese Government propaganda, notwithstanding. It is a challenge to harness absolute power to build a nation from the crumbled pieces.
Should Visit. This site is more memorable for the gorgeous gardens although you can view some of his actual rooms used through glass openings.

Beware the one-way paths. We were disappointed with this site. I believe the stilted house was closed with no explanation as to why. Other areas of the complex (which you could see photos of in the brochure you are given) were also off limits (looked like it was for security reasons). There are a few places where the road forks. And if you pick the wrong fork you can't get back to take the other one. Make sure you see everything else before walking around the lake/pond.Also had a similar problem with many Vietnamese attractions - there are no maps!

Nha San Bac Ho & Phu Chu Tich Nuoc. Quiet and peaceful place where you can see Ho Chi Minh's humble and thrifty way of living. There is a pond surrounded by exotic trees, there is a mango trees street which made for starving kids in Vietnam, small house where Ho Chi Minh passed away, etc. There is a male peacock who symbolizes Ho Chi Minh who lived as a single forever.

Ho Chi Minh was a hero. Ho Chi Minh was not available for viewing as he was away for refurbishment. The museum at the mausoleum was really good. Ho Chi Minh was a real hero to the the Vietnamese people. He kept them focused on independence from outside occupation. I think he has been unjustly maligned in the west. I would enjoy reading an English translation of his manifesto. The presentations were thoughtful and complete.
On Oasis. A peaceful place to visit in this busy city, steeped in history and well preserved. Can get busy as with anything with Ho Chi Minh, it is a pilgrimage site, and understandable so.

A day in Hanoi. While on a 18 day tour from Hong Kong to Singapore, our choide gor yhe day stay in Halong Bay was just one : visit Hanoi,! The full day tour offered by Holland America Line was perfect and gave not only the great opportunity to enjoy this city with shadows from the past but also get to know the countryside on the drive to and from Hanoi. Visiting the Presidential Palace site is a must.

The Place of Ho Chi Minh Lived and Worked. This destination is part of our itinerary in Hanoi City tour. It is an interesting place to visit just for about 30 to 45 minutes.We planned to visit the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum first, but it was closed for renovation. After taking a few photos in front of the building, then we are heading to the Uncle Ho’s house. We bought our tickets at the tickets counter just beside the entrance, all visitors have to pass through the security scanning before they are allowed to go inside.Our tour guide telling us lot of stories pertaining to Uncle Ho. You can look and walk around the place where Ho Chi Minh lived and worked in most of his revolutionary life. There are some old French style buildings, Ho’s cars, a beautiful lake and etc inside the historical site. It is not too hot if you are there morning and because of lot of trees there.An interesting place to learn more about Ho Chi Minh. The site will close at 11.00am for lunch. There are local people waiting outside the exit gate there and asking for your tickets. Once they got your tickets, they will resell to others. I do not mind to give it to them but sometime they are really rude in getting your tickets. It happened to my friend that a person just take his ticket without asking his permission. Some of my other friends that refused to give the tickets are followed by them and not allowed them going up to the van until you handed you tickets to them.
It is History!. If you go to Hanoi you will want to see where and how Ho Chi Minh lived. It is located in a beautiful area, and there will be lots of visitors but it is worth it!
Recommended. We visited this place during a short city tour, nice to see. Lot of history is preserved. Good for photo stop as well.

Interesting perspective on culture. The place has nothing amazing to offer. Besides (and probably luckily), when we visited the mausoleum was closed, so we didn't get to see the body.
In any case the visit is worthwhile to understand the character, Vietnam history, and how the people of the North of Vietnam worship him.
Palace. The Palace and surrounds - nice idea. The gardens were quite spectacular and peaceful but there was an awful lot of cement and concrete and it seemed to miss the mark.
mostly disappointing. didn't see much of the inside of the structures, the one person bomb shelter was interesting, just couldn't get excited about Uncle Ho, the grounds were nice

Amazing building really worth a visit!. We only went because we didn't go 5 years ago. So worth the visit. For reasons: great architecture of the 60's, historical interest. Especially regarding the Vietnam war. The helicoptor on the roof and the basement war time bunkers were fascinating. Really great 60's decor in original condition!

What's to see. We booked a full day group tour of Hanoi. This was on the list but the guide took us past a barricade and in her awful English said something about tourists causing problems with the guards and therefore we couldn't go in. (Oct 29, 2014) So we stayed a street corner and from a distance looked at the mausoleum building which was closed and same with the presidential palace. Not sure why we even bothered to stop here.
It's really palatial. Once you go there, make sure you know the local language or you have a guide and interpreter . It's fun to learn so many things about Vietnam

awful museum. Unfortunately the mausoleum was closed so I went to the museum. At a little over $1 it was cheap but seemed full of weird propoganda and hordes of tourists. The under explored Ho Chi Mihn museums in Hue was a much better historical experience.

nice place for history. I'm not going to go in to the politics of my visit but suffice to say as a veteran of the war and considering this man represented my enemy......this visit was cathartic and I suggest you do it if your situation was the same as mine. Per all of the wonderful people we met in Viet Nam, everyone here was...
interesting and well preserved. Beautiful park like setting and interesting back story. Takes more time to see everything than expected.

Something and Nothing. We didn't realise that Ho Chi Minh's body went to Russia for two months of the year for a vacation and oil change...I think the information should be added to the leaflet/Trip adviser as it was very disappointing when we really wanted to see this man laying in state.The rest of the museum was o.k but lacking in information.
Interesting. Lots of political info on how Vietnam has been shaped over the past 40+ years. With lots to see and take in. very informative.

Historical relevance. A much admired place by the locals. Parts were closed to the public e.g homes of Ho Chi Ming but it is an important place in Hanoi. Don't ask to have photos taken with the guards. Nice gardens to wander through and at this time of the year not too busy

Mixed bag. Museum was Interesting and informative, albeit probably biased but we learned a lot. Seemed to have to walk for miles I for security reasons although Ho Chi Minh's were in Moscow. Could do with clearer signing.

A visit to ho chi minhs houses as president of vietnam. For me as a rabid hater of communism a visit to ho chi minhs two houses as president of vietnam was an eyeopener as to how great leaders in modern terminology walk the talk.with all the splendour of the presidential palace ho chi minh lived in three stark rooms away from the palace.a functional bedroom a dining room with mis matched china and a study.it taught me that truly great men are above mundane matters.ho chi minh was the gandhi of vietnam and may his tribe increase.the other aphorism is corrupt people are all alike and they are fleeting memories.people like ho chi minh and gandhi live in our hearts and souls.strongly recommend a visit.

See It Along with the Mausoleum. We visited this site in early November only to find out that the Mausoleum was closed for renovation but we went into the Presidential Palace site anyway. It is not a big place and one can easily finish just this portion of the tour within an hour. You get to see his old house along with the house on stilts that he moved into with a bomb shelter immediate next to it in case this complex was bombed. A big pond sits in the middle of the complex and you do get to see 3 antique cars that Ho used during his time. I would deem visiting this site worthwhile only in conjunction with the Mausoleum but not making an exclusive trip just to see this site...

Looked Beautiful But Was Closed. The Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum (with his embalmed body still lying in state) and Presidential Palace look interesting from outside, but were closed due to renovations. Instead we went to the beautiful Buddhist Temple, Tran Quoc, which was the best Temple we experienced in Vietnam. It's nearby and worth a visit.

Truly beautiful. Beautiful palace, painted a vibrant yellow colour, set amidst lovely gardens, and close to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. The Ho Chi Minh quarter looks at the life of the father of modern Vietnam, where you visit the Ho Chi Minh Museum, showing where and how he lived. Very hard to take photos into the rooms on display, as they have very shiny windows which reflect. Great photo opportunity of the palace though! When you enter, make sure you get your ticket checked to the right of the gate, as it isn't in line with the path, and the poor man was having trouble with the crowds who were entering. Amusing for us, but not for him!

Gotta See It. This includes the ochre presidential "palace," Ho's "office" and garage, the bomb shelter, the one stilted pagoda, and the surroundings. There is some explanatory signage but a guide makes the experience more rewarding and I recommend it. A guide costs no more than $40 for the entire day. The entire site conveys the greatness and intellect of the man (despised in the West) and his simple and austere nature.

More than a palace. The site encapsulates the nation's admiration and love for the man but it also reveals the connection Ho Chi Minh had with the people. He was a truly great man and deserves the adulation he is given. It is interesting how little Westerners have been taught about the cruelty of the regimes and colonialism he helped destroy.

Contrasts. The Governor’s Palace was built in the early 1900s to house the French Governor of Viet Nam. The French colonial palace with its columns is impressive – large, beautifully designed, very yellow. Tourists are not allowed to go into the palace, but it is worthwhile seeing from the outside. When independence came to Viet Nam, Ho Chi Minh chose not to live in such elaborate style, choosing rather to live in an extremely simple 2-room stilt house on the nearby pond. The contrast to the Governor’s Palace is striking. The furnishings in the rooms were also simple, although the antique cars used by Ho Chi Minh and displayed in the area were quite elegant.Again, in contrast to the simple housing in which Ho Chi Minh lived, his imposing mausoleum is huge, tall, with multiple columns, heavily guarded, built to impress. When we visited the area in November 2012, we were not permitted to go into the mausoleum, but the view from the outside was impressive.Also in the area is the one pillar pagoda, an interesting structure and a place many tourists, including the two of us, had our pictures taken. The gardens in the area were very pretty and peaceful. The gardens are not far from the “Hanoi Hilton” where US prisoners were held during the “American War, “ as the Vietnamese call it.This is a site we would recommend you see, not just for the buildings and gardens, but also for a sense of history of this country.
Beautiful Gardens and Some Insights. We spent an hour or so exploring the gardens around the palace. The gardens are beautiful and kept with great love and respect.

Less than expected. It is sure a great place to visit when we are in Hanoi. It is a good opportunity to get more information about Ho Chi Minh era and learn more about Vietnam's history. But the complex itself is not as incredible as everyone in the city advertises.

Ho Chi Minh. Ho Chi Minh lived most of his life in Hanoi and the country calls him the father of independence. The Palace grounds date back to the French colonization and was the centre of military command during the Vietnam War, which they call the American War.
Beautiful!. This palace is so beautiful. It is so different to any other palace i have seen, so unique. The yellow colour is so beautiful as well.

Well worth the visit!. This attraction is definetely well worth a visit if you do go to Hanoi. It is a very pretty area, especially the yellow colour of the presidential palace is very beautiful. I enjoyed very much visiting where Ho Chi Minh used to live as well. There is so much history everywhere you look.

Ho hum!. We couldn't get into the mausoleum itself, but were able to witness the changing of the guard. I can understand why they revere him, but, really, it wouldn't have been a problem if the French had done what they promised!

Ho Chi Minh. The Ho Chi Minh Presidential Palace Historical Site is quite a large are in Hanoi. In the middle is Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. You can visit Ho Chi Minhs house and also the museum and learn a bit about this man who is the founder of the modern Vietnam.

Pretty interesting..... We found our tour of this site interesting. Although it was very much pro Ho Chi Minh, as you would expect! It is advisable to be on a tour so you have the whole thing explained to you as we did. Especially at the museum as there is a lot of symbolism there that would be difficult to interpret unless explained in person. Unfortunately the Mausoleum was closed for renovation so we did not get to see Ho Chi Minh lying in state.
Touristic attraction. Perhaps because it was raining but I found this attraction too small, because there´s still a lot of closed places.

Confusing place without a guide. as expected, security here was very tight with lots of areas blanked off by high metal screens and lots of guards telling you that you have to walk miles to go around the closed area. Not really set up for tourism. Only able to get a glimpse of the original palace.

Good place to know about. Visited the Palace during august 2014.
Nicely preserved and the history is clearly presented.
shouldn't miss this place if you're in Saigon.

Presidential Palace.. This tour of a very mediocre building could hardly be a palace more a typical government building built by military minds not kings. Wish there had been some of the old building left to admire. The grounds were imalulate and presented well. Ho Chi Min's house was well presented and depicted how the leader wished to be perceived by countries people. I expect he lived two lives a political and a private one. Worth a visit for the history of Vietnam but a really boring building.

Very interesting. Our guide told us of the story of Ho Chi Minh which made this visit very special. The gardens and his homes are beautiful and peaceful. We'll worth seeing, particularly with a knowledgable guide

Beautiful and well worth a look. Ho Chi Minh is respected right throughout Vietnam and many of the visitor that come are Vietnamese. Our group enjoyed the hour or so we took walking through the beautiful gardens, seeing where Ho Chi MInh worked and rested.
lack of access. If you have a good guide, you can obviously learn a lot on this tour, but its one of those places where you are looking from a few feet away through glass at everything.
Gorgeous grounds. Loved this...well worth a visit ...so much to see and gorgeous grounds...covered in beautiful tree lined streets...a lot of history.
Must see. This whole area is worth looking over and around including the Palace and residing areas, the museum and the markets. Lovely area and a must see for all travelling to Hanoi

Beautiful grounds. This was a beautiful place to see, the grounds are lovely and peaceful and it was interesting to see Ho Chi Minh's living quarters. His body is preserved in the masoleum, however, it shuts down for a period every year so you have to time your visit. It was closed for 3 months when we visited, so we were not even able to get close to the building which was a real disappointment.

Definitely worth a walk around. Quite interesting to see the places Ho lived and to see his mausoleum. There is a lovely lake and his house on stilts plus the cars he used which were gifts from the Russian government and the French. Renovation kept us from going up close to the mausoleum.

Strict Palace Guards. Oh yes I read that you could be refused picture taking. I wasnt ready to be whistle blown at. Apparently its a no-no to stand in front of the presidential palace. It made me disappointed. I was no fan of communism in the first place. The only thing that saved this visit was the tourist guide's story telling of how low-key simple and country loving Ho Chi Minh was. You could see it in his pictures - a nobleman. We were toured in the bedroom he stayed in, the front lake. The body of Uncle Ho was touring in Russia for preservation work. But, Sorry, Im not a mausoleum person. The one pillar pagoda was nearby and so full of people plus under renovation. So, when this place is more friendly, I'll give a better rating. But for now... 3.5 stars out of 5.
palace. A nice walk out to the palace, is a good way to get the feel of the area. I would say that the Viets need to have more English signage to cater for tourism. Generally a nice morning stroll
Great. Every time i visit Hanoi, i come here. It is lovely place and meet many friendly Vietnamese. Hope this place will be more succeed.

Disappointing. I had read good reviews of this but it was a worthless tour to do. We had hoped to get a guided tour but there were no signs up saying you could get one. We walked around in 10 minutes which is about as long as the guided tours around us took. Its very cheap to do so you might as well do it but see if you can organise a tour guide somewhere.

An insight into the life of Uncle Ho. An interesting place to visit and a chance to see how Ho Chi Minh lived in a place of calm in the city centre, his collection of cars are on display, his stilt house is impressive next to the lovely carp lake.
wow. Every time i visit Hanoi, i come here. It is lovely place and meet many friendly Vietnamese. Hope this place will be more succeed.
amazing. Awesome, we had a english speaking tour guide which made it awesome. This is a must see. Great place.
His home was great. This site was really good. There were a lot of people there, so we had to stand in line (about 50) The gardens were beautiful and tons of fish in the lake

Not great!. Was quite surprised with this palace actually. I am a great Ho Chi Minh fan, but was disappointed with the way the palace has been portrayed. There could have been more life to the place in depicting the rich history

History in a beautiful setting.. This whole complex is stunning. The transformation of what was once the biological gardens into a residence for their leader means the setting is special. Seeing the modest houses in which Ho Chi Minh lived somehow negates the need for a mausoleum but that's their choice. This is a good way to spend a couple of hours in Hanoi.

Must Visit. Historical site is well maintained and worth visiting. Ho Chi Minh's story and history of Vietnam can be heard from good guide. We were lucky Ms. Mai was there whole day with us in Hanoi tour. She was good, she had lot of things to say but we had little time.
Good history tour.. Very strict guidelines, didn't bother me though. Need to have your arms covered to access, so take a cover if you have your arms showing.

Getting to know how Ho Chi Minh lived. 12 of us visited the HCM Presidential Palace and we were very impressed as to how HCM lived his life as the head of North Vietnam then. Nothing extravagant, nothing luxurious but the nature surrounding the palace was just so exquisite. In comparison, former South Vietnamese Independence Palace was very extravagant...No wonder the South lost the war.HCM museum is also worth a tour as you get to know how he lived his life.The landscape of HCM Presidential Palace is just too beautiful.
Wonder. Even though we didn't see HO Chi Minh in his final resting place as he had been taken back to Russia for some body work we enjoyed the tour of the palace and grounds immensely.
Good Palatial grounds. Nice walk thru the palatial grounds & park around it. Some good photo opportunities. Long walks through.
A magnificent place. What a treat it was to visit this place, it is truly magnificent, from the round red carpet in the foyer to the many state rooms.
Long queues. The opening hours for the Presidential Palace complex are so short that tremendous queues form, and you shuffle round Ho Chi Minh's Residences and the grounds which is a shame
Enjoyed it. Worth a visit if you are interested in Ho Chi Min. The lake and landscaped areas are quite peaceful. We didn't get any access to the French building, that was a bit of a shame.

Huge territory full of Korean tourists. Even though i couldnt make into HCM mausoleum I ended up here - a vast neat clean foresty park-like territory. Nice to walk when u r full of energy, but no benches to sit. Tond of noisy Korean tourists. This place is good only if u go to mausoleum as well. One-time attraction though.

A good way to understand the history of the country. A trip around this site enables you to understand the life and times of a man who is intrinsically linked to Vietnam. Our guide was good and gave us just the right amount of information whilst the site itself was well maintained and and very interesting. The usual gift shops try to take your money at the end of the trip but you don't have to spend in them!

Amazing. Ho Chi Minh's house on stilts and surrounding gardens are beautiful, very serene and pretty surroundings. The guards are quite intimidating. Missed visiting the mausoleum as only open in the morning.

Loved the palace. The place is very grand and definitively one of the must sees in Hanoi. There is much in the area and you can take great pictures and learn many historical facts about Ho Chi Minh and the era.

confusing. We stumbled upon this after seeing the HCM museum.There were signs instructing visitors to wait for a guide, but none were around. We kind of wandered around, not really sure where we were allowed to go or what we were looking at. The grounds are a nice respite from the city noise, and within the Ho Chi Min complex, but not much of a sight in and of itself.
Very attractive grounds.. Interesting combination of Asian and French landscaping. Good concessions and reasonable prices. Nice shaded spots to rest on hot day.

Respite from Normal Life. When we visited the huge mausoleum was closed (building work we were told) – quite spectacular in its own way. Skirting around it we were kept away from the bright yellow main house and close gardens. However, the gardens are a wonderful respite from the heat and mayhem of the streets. This historical site was one of our highlights for Hanoi. It was good to see how Ho Chi Minh lived on the grounds and the nice effort that the government has made to keep the site a highly respected place. The house “on stilts” was a lovely quiet spot and gives more of an insight to the way the man saw himself.Worth a visit certainly.
Interesting site. Interesting site to understand some of the history of Ho Chi Minh. Nice grounds, but a long visit not required.
Tranquility amidst Hanoi's chaos. Beautiful gardens and although you can't enter the presidential palace itself you can peer through the windows into the other house where Ho Chi Min actually lived.

Humility and simplicity is Uncle Ho's trademark. Like any tourist attractions, having a good tour guide to tell the history and to explain each spots within an attraction is very important. Otherwise, it will just be looking at structures and buildings without much understanding. I was lucky to have a very good tour guide who explained in detail the history of Vietnam at this place. He was detailed enough to make it seem so real for us and to hear it whilst visiting this place gives us a better feel of what he was telling us. It is a very interesting site to visit. The only disappointment is that Uncle Ho's body is sent to Russia for "maintenance" every year around this time so I missed visiting the mausoleum. We were told that the body will be away for 1-2 months every year so I guess it will be next time to get to see it. Even then, it was still nice to visit the places where he used to stay and walked about. Knowing how he "called" for his fish and to know the Mango road that he used to walked and exercise is like walking down memory lane. Interesting!

Lovely gardens. You seem to keep you away from the presidential palace but showed you his small and simple wooden house in beautiful gardens. the guards didn't seem to want you to stop but kept you on the move.

Very good perspective of the life of Ho Chi Minh. This historical site was one of our highlights for Hanoi. It was good to see how Ho Chi Minh lived on the grounds and the nice effort that the government has made to keep the site a highly respected place.

Didn't get to see much. On our one day in Hanoi,the Indian president was visiting and so we couldn't get close to either the former presidents house or mausoleum. Just saw the little shrine located behind and it's not much. Other sites were much more interesting.

Another informative and interesting Site. Although the HCM Mausoleum is all a bit bizarre, the rest of the historical site, palace, gardens and museum very very interesting and great to put some context around who the Man that the Vietnamese revere so much was.You could spent a whole day here if you had the time
An oasis in the city. The beautiful peaceful gardens and visiting where 'Uncle Ho' lived for the last 15yrs of his life. The Ho chi Min Museum and Tomb are next door so 3 sites together.

simplicity is life for this president. large area, sheltered by tall trees,lake teeming with fish,and the palace and the presidents residence nestling among the trees.
the president abandoned his designated palace and lived in a small tenement on stilts. spartan bedroom and dinning area.
adjacent is a single pillar pagoda-small quaint structure.
Historical site. Our guide walked and talked us through the history of the palace. Some buildings had been destroyed in the war, however they were being restored

Excellent insight into the history of South Vietnam. A must see especially the gates made famous in 1975. Be aware that the tank on the grounds is not the actual tank that crashed the gates, that is in Hanoi, but it is still a T58. There are fees but cheap. Explore the whole place and were possible take a tour as a lot of information is provided that may not be written.

Worth a stroll to breathe in the essence of a great man. I'm interested in this iconic man so I was happy to take the time. I caught a moto from the old quarter for 30,000 dong and the entrance fee wasn't much more. There is a huge monument or mausoleum built to house the embalmed preserved body of Ho Chi Minh, Vietnams great communist leader. The day I visited the building wasn't open so that was disappointing. I'm sure I was there before 12 noon. Anyway the building itself is fairly over the top and nothing amazing but the walk around his residence when he was in power is very cool. I liked the architecture and the grounds and the lake in which you walk around to view the buildings.. You can imagine him in residence here or sitting by the lake consulting the oracle. Worth a visit and if you time it right hopefully they're not doing maintenance on his preserved body.

Important history and perspective. The insight we got into Ho Chi Minh and his leadership and humble lifestyle is important. It says much about his vision for the country and his integrity. The stilt house is beautiful in it's simplicity and elegance. The grounds of mature trees, lake and water-lilies are lovely to wander in and provide desperately needed shade. The Mausoleum was closed although we would not have gone in anyway - preferring to leave that to the Vietnames to whom Ho Chi Minh means so much.The entire complex required a lot of walking, so wear comfortable shoes, carry water, and use an umbrella or fan! We were there off season, so visitor numbers were few and once a tour party passed on, you could enjoy a space in peace and quiet.

beautiful, historical. nothing to dislike, water closet/toilets every floor, impt for elderly like us; place kept pristine and very true to its history, bunker is still as is, equipment well preserved like the two bombs and site where they were dropped, this is a must see place when in Vietnam

Huge complex and museum. Be prepared to read for hours on end. The exhibits are mostly photographs with write-ups. At the time of visit old Ho was in Russia for touch-up work. Apparently it is worth seeing.

A different way of life. Nicely laid out and pretty grounds.
Really does demonstrate in bucket loads how Ho Chi Minh believed in living
the simple way of life and the appreciation of being surrounded by nature.

Worth a visit.. We attended this historical site recently and would have to say it was very worthwhile.We did have a guide and this added to the experience as we learnt so much about Ho Chi Minh and how he lived his life and inspired others.The contrast between his various homes was amazing.The entire area is immaculantly clean and tidy.The day we visited it was very hot so come prepared. Once you pass the Mausoleum there is shade in the garden areas.Not overly busy when we attended but I was told it can get extremely crowded at times. The site is spread out and it is easy to walk around.
Soviet architecture meets Asia. The contrast between theses styles could not be greater. We enjoyed the museum and the walk through the grounds was peaceful if busy with locals
Nice place next Ho Chi Minh Mouseloum. You can go there through Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum or from Hung Vuong street ( infront of Presidential Palace). I will come back this place when i come back Hanoi
Historic site. Interesting place to visit.Palace beautiful. Ho Chi Minh house on stilts overlooking a pretty lake, Also his collection of cars. The Mausoleum takes 'pride of place'

Beautiful setting to honor Ho Chi Minh. The extensive area required some walking to get around the whole site but worth it. The gardens, fish in the lakes, tree lined walking paths provided cool atmosphere on the humid day. Really important to have a guide to fully explain each building, and it's significance. So important to include on any tourist visit, for overseas people to really appreciate the high respect that Vietnamese people show towards this special leader.
Ho Chi Minh. We went there after one night stay in Hanoi...and we come back from Halong bay....he is great after we read something in his house..

Brief Visit to Ho Chi Minh Palace. Despite deciding not to join the queue to go through the Mausoleum I was impressed to learn about choices made by Ho Chi Minh to remain a humble leader. I particularly liked his wooden house beside the lake and found this part of the compound very tranquil and cool in the heat of the day.

Important insight into the country today. Turned out our tour was on National Day (2nd Sept) so it was very, very crowded, huge queues everywhere and especially for the inside of the mausoleum, we skipped that. Rest of the site was interesting, worth the tour.

Interesting, but serious business!. Seeing Ho Chi Minh is a serious undertaking. You will line up, walk along lines and will always be watched by guards. Dress appropriately and be aware that you will not be allowed to take pictures. You will only see him for a few moments, but it is actually more interesting to see the reaction of the people, some cry and are deeply moved by seeing him. Be aware of the opening times. After that you can see his old house and pagoda which is very nice. The HCM museum, which is also nearby, is one of the most bizarre musuems I have ever been to. It's grotesque.

Tribute to Uncle Ho. This is a large site that contains the Mausoleum to Ho Chi Minh which is a vast, imposing mausoleum which reflects the importance of Ho Chi Minh, or Uncle Ho as he's affectionately known, Within the site is the HCM museum - unfortunately both were closed when we visited. Nearby is the One Stilt Pagoda and other attractions such as the Botanical Gardens
Very grandiose. Although we were there on a Monday when this monument is closed, there was still plenty to see in the actual grounds. Also plenty of information from our guide - Toan.

Nice Presidencial Palace. This site is now a museum, it is very interesting but you have to get a tour guide other ways you'll miss all the interesting factors, the architecture is in Italian Renaissance Style, so very nice and refine. it is worth the visit

Worth the wait. this will give the visitor a better understanding of why the country sees him as Uncle Ho, well deserved I believe. And learn there is much more to Vietnam's history than just it's involvement with USA.

stumbled upon it. We stumbled upon this place as we went to the museum and as his body had been sent back to Russia for its annual touch up there was not a lot happening. The grounds are very well kept but the wander around will only take a short time as access to most of the buildings is closed to the public. It is interesting to see the buildings from the outside

great place to visit. i felt very peaceful and vietnamese. i knew more about Uncle Ho Chi Minh. There were a lot of school tours of highschool kids visiting. after visitng i felt more appriciate Uncle Ho.

Uncle Ho Final Resting Place. Huge place build in remembrance of Ho Chi Minh. The Place was crowded with locals and tourist. We did not enter into mausoleum as it was crowded with people. We circle around the place.Uncle Ho house was nice and simple. The garden was beautiful. Very green and calm. Worth the visit.

Nice place. I didnt like the Ho Chi Minh muselum, but i did like to visit his house the museum and the garden. Very peacyful and very vietnamese. Next to it, you can also see the one pole pagoda, a very beatiful monument

Don't go on Monday. We took a tuk tuk bike ride up to visit Ho Chi Minh. Very hot, but a great way to see the city streets. Walked out into the sun to visit the mausoleum and all was quiet. Checked out the tourist guide and then found out it was closed Mondays. Oh well, walked around to the one pillar pagoda that was open, didn't venture too far into his gardens, it was too hot. They looked beautiful though. The museum on site was also closed. We caught an air conditioned taxi back to our hotel for a swim.

Bit better than average and worth a visit.. Interesting enough - you get a good brochure with pictures and in English. There are signs around so you can read about the house and grounds and a little about Ho Chi Minh himself.. We couldnt go into the Mausoleum as my son didnt have sleeves on his teeshirt and we were happy to miss it rather than go searching for something suitable for him to coverup with. The grounds are pleasant - lots of school tours of highschool kids visiting.
You cannot go in the Stilt House. You walk around the house and look through glass windows where you can see the bedroom and office. The tickets are cheap, but I didn't think it was worth it.
Rather over-rated. While it is a 'must-see' a lot of the site is not very interesting. Try to avoid it on weekends as it gets extremely crowded.

Too crowded to be enjoyable. The most photogenic building is the French colonial Presidential Palace, you cant go inside but it looks impressive towering over its finely manicured gardens and ornamental pond. There are a lot of rules when visiting this place, but its hard to know what they are.

Nice walk around park grounds and palace. We did not find it overly crowded today...Saturday. The mausoleum was closed due to HCM body being sent to Russia for 2 months to be re - embalmed which was disappointing. We enjoyed the walk around the palace grounds, ponds and viewing the places where he lived modestly...the gardens were well manicured and had some amazing trees.

Fascinting piece of Vietnamese history. Amazing to see how Ho Chi Minh lived in a simple hut beside the grand French built palace, whilst the South Vietnam President lived in a corrupt extravagant environment in Saigon. Uncle Ho really was a leader for the people.

good to see. from old quater to the jut 15 minute by taxi but you shut go ealy because open 7am to 11am.you can come in side look ho chi minh and visit around presidential palace every thinh beautiful higt reconment this palace to everyone come to hanoi

It would be nice if there wasn't so much tourists. Seriously, if you thought about visit the complex at weekend, think it twice. At weekend, Vietnamese family (from other provinces) or school take their children/pupils there for a field trip, creating a huge, long line. You cannot live the atmosphere of once how the President Ho Chi Minh had lived before.

Free to get in!. Only got there just before the gates closed at 11am and the queue seemed never ending. Had to leave all bags and even water. When you finally get inside you are pushed along by guards and are only in for about 20 seconds. Then comes the joke you have to pay to get out! Ah well it was less than a quid!
Visiting Hanoi. Very interesting place and saw many things in this city and also saw the old city and saw the prison when John McCain was a prisoner.
Square and Mausoleum. Wow, culture, architecture plus. By the crowds this is a very special,popular site for locals and tourist alike. A very solemn place for the Vietnamese.

Good sense of Vietnamese culture and mindset to be had. The massively long queue on a very very hot Sunday morning resulted in us not queuing to see Uncle Ho....standing in the sun and heat would have killed us. I estimated 50,000 people. But we gladly accepted the remainder of the tour to see the residence and grounds. It provided a good insight into the mindset of the Vietnamese people and their beloved Uncle Ho. If only our governments had the people's interests at heart like he did :-/

Interesting look, but not much interaction/learning. Ho Chi Minh's residence was an interesting look into what the "curated" view of Ho Chi Minh and his administration lived like in Hanoi, but it's a brief tour and not a whole lot of interaction. I enjoyed seeing the artifacts and the campus of his residence is well preserved. The historical learning and the interaction with the place is very minimal; just a walk through and look. Some placards are present, describing the uses and how Ho Chi Minh and the North Vietnamese lived and operated in the residence. Most were only two or three sentences though. I rated as "average" due to my preference for more learning and hands-on interaction to occur when I'm touring historical sites.The residence is beatiful; definitely worth the 20,000 VND to stroll and take pictures. Stop a minute at the pond located in the center of the buildings and notice how incredibly large the goldfish are, you'll be amazed.
Nothing much to see.. It was a long walk there from the Old Quarters, but ended up dissapointed as there were nothing much to see and look at.
OK but not wow!. It is nice to stroll around the park and see the wooden house that Ho Chi Minh resided in and it was great to escape the madness of the city and walk around the park.
Nice to see. We visited here after seeing Uncle Ho in his mausoleum. It is well kept and good to see he didn't try and live in opulent surroundings.

Ordinary Leader. After queuing to enter Ho Chi Minh mausoleum, exit to Ho Chi Minh residence. VN leader has simple and easy lift style. Well preserve stuff for tourists. Small bed room with minimal decoration.

Worth seeing to understand the veneration of Ho Chi Minh. Hard to say how authentic the residence is but maybe this is not the point. Ho Chi Minh was the great leader in a much-troubled time and coming here provides some insight into his character..

Well preserved !. We visited this as part of a tour of Hanoi which we decided was the easiest( and safest!) way to see Hanoi!We did think we were going to see the museum but only saw the houses ( and Ho Chi Mins mausoleum!)The residence shows where he lived with rooms set out as when he left it,together with a collection of cars which he had used or received as gifts,but there was very little information available- our info came from the tour guide but otherwise we would have got little from looking at the houses.It is a popular destination as there were lots of visitors,I think most people combine it with a visit to the mausoleum,30 minutes and you would be finished!

Bringing the History of Vietnam Alive. Take your time to visit the past residences of Ho Chi Minh. Spend time viewing the area and looking at where his body is on display. We visited on a Sunday when it is opened only for several hours. It was a great way to see the tourist attraction as many school children were there. The queue moves very quickly and it is well organised. There is under cover walkways set up for you to wait. Be aware that women need to wear clothes that cover the shoulders, as it is disrespectful to wear tank like tops. As you view Ho Chi Minh's body your hands need to be by your side as it is a sign of respect. You can also view his residences that are situated nearby. After visiting there I felt that the history of the country had come alive and it brought a new perspective of viewing the country and its people.

Presidential palace today a museum, Hanoi. If you are at the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum you might as well stroll through the gardens to the Presidential Palace which today is a museum.It was originally built between 1900 and 1906 to house the French Governor-General of Indochina. The official French architect for French Indochina - Auguste Henri Vildieu designed it in the Italian Renaissance style. After the French evacuated Vietnam, the Communist Party of Vietnam took over. Ho Chi Minh never moved into the Palace but instead lived in the stilt house near the palace grounds, in true communist fashion of endearing the simple life style to all citizens. Without our excellent tourist guide we would not have understood many of the interesting and important facts of this site.

Learning more about a leader. The entire complex, I.e. Mausoleum, residence and Museum, is worth a visit. Provides plenty of details on Ho Chi Minh and allows for a better understanding of how this man was so inspiring to an entire nation and a true leader
interesting. a visit to the mausoleum is like visiting the British crown jewels:no stopping, keep walking, no pictures. Is it really HCM?You're not even allowed to speak!

***My humble insights***. We went on to this place one of the most visited sites in Hanoi. To describe & give insights about Ho Chi Minh is considered as the Father of the Vietnam country (South & North). His face is on every monetary bill in the country.Ho Chi Minh is their great hero. He can speaks 29 different languages and he can write at least 6 different languages internationally. He was a genuine & genius. We visited his residential and his house he used to be stayed before we saw his old cars displayed on his residential. And we saw his underground tunnel he used to hide before during war and many more memories on his throne. Highly recommended to all tourists to visit and must see. Thank you!

Place with historic value. Ho Chi MInh was the hero of the country and a legend they worship for his great contribution to civilize Vietnam after the war. His residence, vehicles and other things with historical value are preserved in this place. Ho Chi Minh's Body is also preserved and displayed in Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. They have strict opening times and Photographing is not allowed only inside the Mausoleum.
An experiance of uncle Ho. Liked a view into the life of such a highly regarded leader and the simplistic lifestyle he prefered

Walk in the footsteps of Uncle Ho. One of the most visited sites in Hanoi, if not the most visited. Ho Chi Minh is considered the Father of the Country...well, at least in the north. His face is on every monetary bill in the country.Plan on several hours here as you will see a replica of his home, visit a museum and his mausoleum.

A must see. If you travel to Hanoi, you can not miss it. A peaceful and nice place. Visit Uncle Ho's Mausoleum to see his body at least one time is thing every Vietnamese people want. Walk around Ho chi Minh's house will make you feel comfortable and relax instead of crowed and traffic jam outside. This place is quite and beautiful.

To do list in Hanoi. If you have the time, do visit this. In my personal opinion this has to be in your to do list especially if you like history. A very nice place to have a peaceful walk out of the busy city of Hanoi

A must do once in Hanoi. We went with a guide who provided us with a lot of propaganda but also a good factual summary of "Uncle Ho's" life and a summary of the history of communism in Vietnam. We went on a Saturday so there were lines but we only waited about 40 minutes and got to watch the "changing of the guards" while we waited. You cannot bring your camera in with you and have to check it at the gate as you get in line. I did use my IPhone to take photos while we were outside in line and no one seemed to mind that. I did not take any photos inside. Needless to say, my teen age sons thought viewing Ho Chi Minh's body was pretty cool but I also think they learned a bit about the history of Vietnam and were surprised at how humble his residence was.
Very interested from historical point of view. This is a very important piece of Vietnamese ( and world) history. A very interesting visit to comprehend modern Vietnam

Part of the History of Vietnam and a must see. The residence of Ho Chi Minh is a part of Vietnamese history and a must see in Hanoi, the grounds are quite beautiful and the lake is very pretty, you would probably spend no more than an hour here, and if you can try not to go on the weekend as this is a major site for locals and the weekends can get crazy.
Nice. Nice. I wished the tour of the palace was included. The spacious garden was well maintained. This place is really crowded on any weekend. We went on Saturday.
Majestic gentleman. Highly respected gentleman with guards surrounding the building where the gentleman sleeps peacefully. Look out for the changing of guard. Interesting.
Required. One of the requisite stops on a visit to Hanoi. Worth seeing and experiencing, but try to go when the crowds are light.

Not worth the visit. Even the relatively cheap entrance fee doesn't feel like it was worth it after walking around the grounds. It takes about 30 mins. the impressive presidential building is off limits, and that area would have made the visit worth it. But the rest of the area open for exhibit was a bummer. Not recommended unless you arrive at the area and the mausoleum is closed and you do not want to leave the area not having done anything
Ho CHI Minh's Residence. Worth a 1 hour visit as part of a wider tour. Interesting to see the simple quarters he lived in but all views are external through glass. Grounds very pretty.
Interesting insights. The park consists of the mansion that he never lived in, but used for state meetings. The quarters that he lived in on the grounds were very humble.
The security was fascinating. It was worth it just to see how highly protected it is and experience the huge but continuously moving line.

Uncle Ho's Residence. I like the Mango road at Uncle Ho's residence and his 3 units old cars but the pillar garden near the Mango road not maintain well , if they maintain as the brochure picture it will nice to see it .Love it overall:)

Historic but not enjoyed. The historic element was interesting. His actual residence and the French influence, the old cars and his lake, where legend has it that he clapped and the fish came to the surface. I dislike being herded in a line and walking pass his corpse as I did not expect or was not prepared by the tour guide to be walking past an actual corpse. The children found it quite difficult walking past a corpse.

Neat to see how he livied. Ho Chi Minh's modest home is a great example that modern politicians should follow. It was very simple and functional. Uncle Ho was a gardener, maybe we need more politicians to be gardeners.

Ho's House. There are lovely gardens and a pond. The house is as someone said humble. The treehouse is on the other hand humble but also opulent. Simple wood with great craftsmanship which creates the opulence.

Friendly insight into life style of Ho Chi Minh. The gardens and simple housing were a peaceful getaway from the traffic of Hanoi. A beautiful place to stroll, relax, and unwind. The displayed life style of Ho was different than what had been expected to this American's eyes.

Insight into the life of the great "Uncle Ho". A great insight into the life of the revered Ho Chi Minh himself, nice well kept parkland and lake with the original modest residence of the great man, outside of Vietnam little is known of the life and character of "Uncle Ho" and this is an opportunity to discover more
Ho's house. What a humble man he appeared to be. Well maintained property not allowed to go into his bomb shelter tho, maybe it is too dangerous
Interesting. Lovely walk around beautiful gardens and very interesting to see how he spent his days. Well maintained buildings and gardens.

Well preserved and maintained landmark, showing simple way of life followed by Uncle Ho. It was great to see how and where Uncle Ho lived. Such a simple place for a person of his position and stature. The main draw back is that you still feel you are on the continued conveyor belt of people from the mausoleum, with little chance to set-out alone.

Peaceful and Tranquil. This area is a peaceful oasis in the hustle and bustle that is Hanoi. The gardens and pond are well maintained and it was interesting to see how humbly Ho Chi Minh lived. Well worth a visit.

Wonderful glimpse into the past. Well preserved glimpse into the past and life of Ho Chi Minh. This place has been well respected and preserved. It was a pleasure to witness first hand the life and humility of a well respected leader. Was just upset that the burial spot of Ho Chi Minh was closed, and the pagoda was under renovation on the day of my visit. Nonetheless, good to know that proper maintenance is being done.

Uncle Ho's home. Visit this place and see how the father of Vietnam lived. An insight into his personal life. He preferred living here as opposed to the government palace. Simple house surrounded by gardens and tree-lined walkways where Uncle Ho would normally do his walks. Prepare to queue as this is a popular site for Vietnamese people.

worth a visit. the surroundings are fantastic! and it was interesting to see the house and compound, so you should defenitly go there, it was amazing to see how small the acutal residence was, and it was very homely.
A peaceful place. Beautiful buildings and picturesque gardens. This is a tranquil place amid the hustle and bustle of the city.

The Simple Life. After first visiting the Palace from a restricted distance as all foreigners are restricted access, we were intrigued to view more closely the simple sparsely furnished bungalow where Ho conducted his daily business and work while in power. He also lived in a very basic house on stilts next to the lake in the Palace grounds - not even equipped with its own bathroom. He had to use the bungalow 300m away. The gardens were beautiful and we'll worth a visit.

Nice guided tour. We chose a guided a tour rather go it alone, just as well when we saw how long the queue was, we chose not to queue up to Ho Chi min, so just toured the gardens and area, well worth a visit.

What a humble leadrer. I don't know much about the history of Ho Chi Minh. Apart from realising what a humble man he was. Imagine a leader not wanting to reside in the Palace. He was happy to live out his life in a cottage within the Palace grounds. I admire him for that.

Interesting, but limited . As someone fascinated by history, subjectively I found this really interesting, however objectively there isn't much to it. It's good as an addition to visiting the mausoleum, Presidential Palace etc. and you can't really fault it but at the end of the day it's a simple house for a man of the people and, unless you're particularly interested by history, I could see how it could be construed as very limited as an attraction. Not a must see but if this sort of thing interests you then it's inexpensive.

Neither bad nor amazing . Sure, if you're visiting the complex on the whole I'd recommend walking past but in itself it's hardly much. It's not bad looking but it's hardly sensational - it's a bit of history that is more flattered by where it is in relation to other attractions rather than in itself. You pay 25,000 VND (just over a dollar) to see more than this and were it just the palace you'd feel somewhat cheated but it's hardly a bad place to visit.
Must experience. To really understand Ho Chi Minh the way he lived etc must see, had a guide so he explained everything which was a great help.

A Simple house for the great revolutionary. Located within the grounds of the Presidential Palace, to the north of his mausoleum is a simple wooden house on stilts which Ho Chi Minh lived and worked at instead of the Presidential Palace itself. He lived here between May 1958 and August 1969 and so it's become a national symbol. Set in a stretch of mango-filled parkland around a small pond, Ho Chi Minh's stilt house is built of polished wood.There are only two rooms here, and one can still see the personal artifacts of Ho Chi Minh

A piece of Italian Renaissance in Hanoi. Presidential house was built between 1900 and 1906 to house the French Governor-General of Indochina. It was constructed by Auguste Henri Vildieu, the official French architect for French Indochina. Built in Italian Renaissance design the Presidential Palace housed French Governor-Generals from Doumer on to the end of the French occupation of Vietnam. After the French evacuated Vietnam, the Communist Party of Vietnam took over. Uncle Ho never moved into the Palace but instead lived in the Stilt house near the Palace grounds. Today the yellow palace stands behind wrought iron gates strictly off limits for the tourists.
A very memorable experience. The residence shows how simple Ho Chi Minh was. It is worth visiting as it does not take long to go round the place.
Go here!. and do not miss the mausoleum while you are there. Uncle Ho is a true national hero so please go and pay respects.
humble home. I enjoy the visit to Ho Chi Minh's house. It was inspiring to see that a president of a country chose to live like his citizens.Not sure if it is a must see for every tourist.

Excellent example of colonial architecture and history. Great way to learn more about the man and how he lived. The Presidential palace is a beautiful building and the grounds are superbly manicured. The shade provided by the old trees proves a brilliant respite from the heat, and it is really close to the mausoleum. The old hous of Ho Chi Minh is fantastic, we recommend using Hanoi Kids to get a guide to take you through these bulidings you will get much more out of it that way.

Not sure.... I'm sure this is a very must-see place for Vietnamese, but for Westerners, we found it a little strange. You have to go early (it closes at 11am), queue for a very long time (a few hundred metres at least) in the Sun, leave some of your bags at reception (stressful as they ask you to collect them before 11 and the queue seemed like we wouldn't even get in by then!). Anyway, eventually you get in, there's a security guard every 5m and you walk in single file around the body.Air con is also so strong that your glasses will mist up when you leave!Worth seeing if you have a couple of days there, but if you're in a rush, could be missed.

Ritual of the state!. The founder of the modern Vietnam body is preserved in this Russian made mausoleum. Visitors are guided to be respectful, not to take pictures when inside and remove hats and shades out of respect. Groups are let in and have a about 30 seconds to look at Ho Chi Minh embalmed body, the time between entering and exiting in a circular fashion in two-person lines. Young soldiers are present and they change position in an orderly military fashion. Then the presidential palace, his home and working office are visited. He was a single man so you will see a simple single bed only!
home of ho chi minh. we found this a very humble home for such a man who chose not to live in the presidential residence.
Jaw-dropping!. I wish I owned a house like this one, situated in a quiet and peaceful area of the city with maximum security!
WOW!. Splendido giardini, ben tenuto e puoi respirare l anima del VIETNAM in questo luogoSurely need go to visit, nice garden, and can feel the Vietnamese Soul here

Hanoi - Ho Chi Minh's Residence - Peaceful and surreal. It's a sort of natural progression after visiting his mausoleum and as many have said here on TA the simple and tranquil surroundings within his residence suggest a quieter and more normal side to such a powerful man. The residence building itself, which we couldn't access, is beautiful. The yellow elevations and architectural style stand out but it is his more simple garden buildings which suggest he was more real. The gardens and central lake area are beautiful and some of the outer buildings where meetings took place site perfectly within their surroundings. Even the few cars which are on display suggest another side to the leader but perhaps these are only a sample of what he actually owned. I thought this place was great and would have been better if the local Vietnamese knew anything about following in an orderly queue and keeping their kids under control. The only down side was we were continually being pushed past and bumped as people couldn't just go with the flow. Overall the place was superb, but wish I could have drifted around on my own.

Must see. Truly interesting history, architecture and beautiful gardens. Go with a guide so you learn about everything that took place there and get to learn more about Ho Chi Minh's interesting lifestyle.
Ho's residnece. Surprisingly calm setting. Includes an old car he used . Much art work including contemporary-like sculpture.
Ho Chi Minh lived a simple life. The grounds were immaculate. Furniture, clothes, belongings were quite spartan considering his power. Very nice area to walk around following a viewing of the tomb.
First hand experience. As an Australian I was struck by the life of this man. This was instrumental in learning about him, what he stood for and why he was so important to the Vietnamese.

Surreal experience. Quite a humbling experience to walk around Ho Chi Minh's residence, much of my history knowledge of him was gleaned from film and it was quite odd seeing some rather basic living quarters for such a powerful man.Very helpful staff around who were only too happy to impart their knowledge, though we didn't take them up on an official tour which they can do in many different languages.

Very interesting insight. Went here directly after visiting the mausoleum. There is not a lot to see but the buildings give an interesting insight into ho chi minds lifestyle. Be sure to go to the museum next door for a more detailed account of his life
nothing much to see. just a few houses and stuff. there are better museums in hanoi to visit than this.... have to pay 25000vnd to get in too

Peaceful and tranquil. It's an interesting place, right in the shadow of the very prominent mausoleum is the former residence which is quite grand and very French colonial in architecture. The gardens and ponds are very peaceful. I found his smaller cabin residence more interesting - Ho Chi Minh considered himself one of the people and didn't believe in grand things and gestures, so to see the contrast of the plainer living against the luxurious residence building is interesting. And also the man himself did not want to be interred into a mausoleum, a lot of things seem to go against his wishes and he has an almost "God like" status amongst the Vietnamese.
Greattt. An authentic interior, spare a thought for the man, a former student in France, his life, his career, his desire to create a Vietnamese nation ...Visited May 2014
A Place for hero. This a very well maintained historical place, I think Vietnam people love their leader very much. I do not about the real story, but I really admire.

Well kept and worth a visit. A place you will just have to visit if you go to Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum. Features how Ho Chi Minh lived when he was still alive, and the view is just lovely. Heat of walking is bearable thanks to the shady trees around.

Well worth visiting. You see how simply he lived. However it can be busy so go early which means a lot of queuing. His cars, bomb shelter etc., are all there to be seen. Warning. The museum closes at 1130.

Lovely. The actual house on stilts where Ho Chi Min lived was in beautiful parkland. As we visited in low season there weren't massive crowds which made the visit all the more pleasant. However the price we paid was scorching heat!
skip this place. there is really no need to visit this, though the masoleum leads right into it. just keep filing past and go clockwise the right back to the museum
Ho Chi Minh's residence and retreat. The Residence is really an adjunct to the mausoleum,to be viewed only through open windows,with glimpses of furniture.Very peaceful location and garden.

Average at best.. This was the most average stop during our tour in Hanoi. THere wasn't much to see except the manicured grounds, which were nice. The part I enjoyed most were the old cars, but besides that there wasn't much there to see.
