We had a guide and he was able to explain things that others would've not have been able to pick up, and without this, it would've been a waste of time in my opinion.
Unexpected tranquillity. Visiting Ho Chi Minh's residence was a surreal experience. The complex is so tranquil and gives you a good insight into Ho Chi Minh's life.

interesting but certainly not wow. Vert very pleased that we organised private tour guides for every city we stayed in during our Vietnam holiday. It is the information they provide that enhances the attraction you are experiencing.Whilst there is no wow factor with this attraction it is interesting to see and hear about the social and political environment of the time and of course the main actor Ho Chi MInh.
Very informative. Really enjoyed this visit, learned a lot a bout Ho Chi Minh. Our guide Juan, was so knowledgeable about Han oi and in particular about Ho Chi Minh himself.
Interesting. It was interesting visiting the residence and hearing more about Ho Chi Minh. The gardens are beautiful.

Little to see but you get a feel for how he lived. First trick is to avoid this area on a Monday - it's all shut for cleaning! The gardens and lakes are lovely to walk round (expect to be joined by a throng of local children) and his cars and home interesting to see. Though it's difficult to get a true feel as to how Uncle Ho found the place because of the tourists and souvenir stalls!
Beautiful place soaked in history. Even on a rainy day was lovely to walk around taking in all the beautiful French colonial buildings.

A leader lifestyle. The place you can see/know how a leader live. And the place was well maintained untill now, the area quite big. Ho Chi Minh Residence was near with Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and One Pillar Pagoda,,, 3 in 1 :) .... So the weather around these place cold and windy also. Just enjoyed the trip

The "Father's" Compound. There is so much to see, a tour guide is needed to explain the compound properly. Ho's working area, his personal residence (including man-made bunker), ponds with fish and birds, a pagoda, and his final resting place. Guards (whose photos you are NOT allowed to take) are everywhere, reminding you where you are and make an uneasy feeling. Very informative and well worth the experience.

Stunning French Gardens. While its interesting to see the simple conditions under which Ho Chi Minh selflessly chose to live, my family and I were much more interested in how the old stables had been converted, the selection of species in the gardens that the French imported from all their colonies, and also by Uncle Ho's old cars. Very cool all around.Just be wary that the guards on site can often be a bit rude and will insist that you stick to the route without any retracing your steps, so try not to take any shortcuts

Surprisingly simple lifestyle. The House on Stilts is where Ho Chi Minh spent most of his time. It's like a fancy treehouse :) The grounds and little lake created a pretty setting for his home. It was interesting to see the way he lived - simple furnishings, uncluttered & utilitarian rooms. There is also a bomb shelter connected to his House on Stilts via a bookcase at the back of his ground-floor office. Admission to this site is included in your ticket into the Presidential Palace (25,000 vnd).

Admire the exterior only. If you are already at the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, you might as well stroll through the gardens. We paid 25,000 vnd, which is a bit pricey for the amount of things you actually get to see. The admission allows you into the grounds and you can take a look at the House on Stilts as well.You can't go inside the Presidential Palace, and can only admire the pretty yellow building from afar. After a few photos here, we moved on to catch a glimpse into the life of Ho Chi Minh at his House on Stilts.

Shows that you do not need a 5 star house to be great.. A visit to Ho Chi Min's mausoleum means an early start. You have to check which day it is open but get there not later than 9:15 AM or else you will miss out. Some days the queues are lengthily and the process of actually getting to the mausoleum is quite structured. The whole of the mausoleum site is a national monument and looked after by the Vietnamese army. The most simplistic bedroom, study, and work spaces to Ho Chi Min with a striking contrast to the rather baroque palace built next door by the French government general to Indochina in the 1930s.Be prepared to leave your bags behind the door, go through the usual security checking, and take money to buy water once you're inside. Recommended experience beautiful gardens

Loved it. Beautiful grounds, crowds but moved well, easy adjunct to the mausoleum, interesting to see the house, cars, lake and gardens. Enjoyed this place and found it quite restful amongst the pace of Hanoi.

Simplicity and beauty. I chose to visit the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum complex on a Friday (knowing that the Museum would be closed). As a result, the rest of the complex was quieter than usual, there were no queues, and I was able to take as much time as I wanted wandering throughout the place. Also, cameras were allowed.The gardens, with the small fish lake, are beautiful - such peace in the middle of this bustling city.When one has had the opportunity to visit in other countries and see the residences of individuals in power, and then see the simple home and workplace chosen by Ho Chi Minh, one cannot help but be in awe of the man's humility.

Unbelievably busy. The place illustrates the point that HCM lkead a simple life and if you have an interest in history it is worth a visit but be prepared for the crowds. In the mausoleum the crowds are well behaved (controlled) but after that it is a free for all and you can barely move. We got there relatively early and still struggled to get around maybe later in the day would be better.
Simple and humble. Simplicity and not the kind of residence I picture it to be. No wonder he was loved by his people. A place for all to visit.

Worth a look. We spent a very hot afternoon walking around the entire complex of HCM Mausoleum, Museum and Residence. Of all these things I would recommend the Residence as the best place to spend some time. The grounds are shaded and beautiful. There is not a whole ton to see here, but it is worth hanging out in the shade and checking out the well manicured grounds.

Good insight as how lived Uncle Ho. Various buildings where Ho Chi Minh lived and worked from 1954 until 1969. It reflects the simplicity and the humility of Ho Chi Minh. It is a good example for Vietnamese also. The parc is beautiful.
An interesting exhibit of how this powerful man chose to live. . It was an eye opener into the humble beginnings of a man who was so powerful and influential in Vietnamese life for so many years.

House on the stilts. The gardens and home of Ho Chi Minh is a calm and beautiful reprieve from the starkness and cold cement structure of the Mausoleum. The gardens are beautiful and well maintained as well as the small lake with koi fish. The most interesting aspects of his modest home is the book collection and pictures of Lennon What is unfortunate is the lack of time you have to view his home through the glass walls from outside. You have to stand in a single queue and walk at a fast pace along with all the visitors. The structure was heavily guarded with soldiers in white uniforms that were adorned with badges and metals. Their were no sign cards that were informative. The vintage cars were interesting as they were rare and gifts from France and Russia. You cannot bring a camera onto the grounds. But they do allow a smart phone. My suggestion is to go there before 10am before the tourists arrive. I was there during the government holiday so it was almost all Vietnamese visitors. The most interesting aspect of the visit is to see the North Vietnamese's respect and admiration for their former leader Ho Chi Minh.
Very interesting!. Beautiful grounds, lots of interesting history, packed with tourists and Vietnamese alike. A must see in Hanoi.
Fascinating insight as to how Ho Chi Minh lived. Liked all aspects of the residence Showed how Ho Chi Minh lived very simply.Must have been an example for Vietnamese nationals to follow

A privilege to see the living quarters of a great man. This large complex incorporates various buildings where Ho Chi Minh lived and worked from 1954 until 1969. The gracious, French-style Presidential Palace that HCM rejected as too lavish stands in stark contrast to House No. 54 which he first moved into, followed by the simple stilt house. All three can be seen, and in the latter two, HCM's bedroom and work place, including relics from the "American War". They say an enormous amount about the humility of the great man. The lake in front of the stilt house and the gardens are relaxing to walk around, following in his footsteps.

Just ok. After visiting the ho chi minh mausoleum we came in further into house of ho chi minh. Entrance was 25k vnd (1.25usd).
It was just ok to spend time for about 30-45 minutes there to see his working room, his old cars, a pond with interesting roots.
If you don't have time you won't miss anything.....

Very thought provoking. Seeing the simplicity of Ho Chi Mihn's lifestyle was both illuminating and inspiring. There is a real sense of place here - you can close your eyes and see back decades - very well done.

Ho Chi Min's residence. Well worth visiting. Hoi Chi Min was clearly a humble man who did not seek out the trappings of power, the house reflects his simplicity, the gardens are also simple and the small lake full of gold fish is interesting, clap your hands loudly and they will surface to be fed. Near to the Mausoleum, The French Governor's residence, which Ho Chi Minh shunned as a place to livestands boldly next door.

Lovely spot. Well worth visiting the complex of buildings used by Ho Chi Minh whilst in office. Clearly a humble man who did not seek out the trappings of power. Near to the Mausoleum, and accessed next to the French Governor's residence, which Ho Chi Minh shunned as a place to live.

Uncle Ho Chi Minh's Residence. I am told by our tour guide Lin of HanoiKids that after the father of the house an 'uncle' is the next most important person in a family. With Ho Chi Minh leading the humble life he did - indeed he chose to live in the former house of an electrician rather than staying in the grand Presidential Palace across the way.It was truly interesting to see his humble accommodations with little gifts from leaders around the world including a radio from Fidel Castro. I especially clocked on to that being from the West Indies.And for the motor car enthusiasts there are 3 antique cars in the garage - including a Peugeot 404 from the French president and another from the Soviet Union as gift in 1954.Finish off the tour by having a go of clapping your hands to bring the fishes to the surface of the pond..Part of the Ho Chi Minh complex tour and ticket price and is suitable for persons with push chairs and wheel chairs.
Don't forget to visit it if you go to Mausoleum. You will walk with the crowd visitng the residence that looks quite romantic in a nice garden. As a foreigner you have to pay entrance fee.

All part of the Ho Chi Minh Complex. All in the same complex to Mausoleum, Museum and Ho Chi Minh's Residence.If you go to the Mausoleum (see review) then you must do the complete Ho Chi Minh learning tour.Note: summer and winter opening times differ but same as Mausoleum Closed on Mondays and Fridays. Very well maintained.
Good. its good, to visit, the residence of Ho Chi Minh's, but it was a very little visit, and very strict rules, so it is a one time watch..
Oasis of calm. Much bigger than I expected. Very pleasant surprise. Not just the residence but the lake, summer house, the garage with the cars, all worth the visit.

Some interesting insights. Crowded but well-organised these extensive grounds and buildings offered interesting insights into Ho's life (or at least the official projection of it). Definitely worth a visit.

Simple and inspiring. It was amazing to see the simplicity of Ho Chi Minh's dwelling and to contrast this with the pomp and formality of the mausoleum which, in any case, seemed contrary to his wishes

Memories of Ho Chi Minh. Stunning gardens, beautiful homes and some beautiful memories of Ho Chi Minh. The Presidential Palace is next to the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum and worth the time to visit. Absolutely beautiful gardens and quite a show piece.

Peaceful place of casual Uncle Ho. All the Uncle life is so simple , he lived like all the normal Vietnamese people . Even his house look very simple but tidy . For all area around look exactly like Vietnamese hometown long long time ago. The reason why so many people from all around the world come here to see his life , a great father of Vietnam.

Part of the Ho Chi Min Complex. The whole complex was interesting including this house built on stilts - as a gift to Ho Chi Min. The old cars were intriguing as was the original residence of the revered man. The house was well laid out including the bomb shelter where Ho could go during the American bombing raids on Hanoi. The whole complex is well laid out with it's small lake, well tended gardens and well signposted route around the complex. It even has a collection of shops at which to buy various mementos, drinks, snacks and ice creams. There were hoards of school kids being led around the complex on the day that we were there.
Part of the Mausoleum tour. Another great place of interest that you should not miss out on when you are doing the Mausoleum tour. Tranquil surroundings.
Nice. The presidential palace is one of the many sights that you will see when you take the Mausoleum tour.

A peaceful place with an sense of history. We had the advantage of visiting Ho Chi Minh's Residence as part of a organised tour and our guide explained about its design, layout and some of the personal history of Ho Chi Minh and his 'struggle' to achieve a free Vietnam. The houses and grounds are well laid out and like Gandi's house in Delhi there is a peace and solemnity when walking round.Having read some of the other reviews I would agree that unless you have a guide you don't understand it as well.
it had to be done. Well, it had to be done and you do it. excellent setting, peaceful surroundings but the guards were rushing us around and kept asking us to move on

Could give it a miss. You cannot go in the Stilt House. You walk around the house and look through glass windows where you can see the bedroom and office. The tickets are cheap, but I didn't think it was worth it.

Residence and resting place. HCM is lying embalmed in a mausoleum at his site, despite his wishes to be cremated and scattered throughout Vietnam. However, it does feel like a respected site and the 'palace' he refused to live in after a few months is still there, along with the raised simple house on stilts he preferred to live and study in. Well worth a visit..long queues so go with a tour to get ahead in the queue.

Very interesting!. We really enjoyed seeing where Ho Chi Minh lived and worked. It's obvious that he was a very humble man who decided to live in a small house instead of the presidential palace. There are really two houses where he lived. One is a normal house, and the other is the famous "stilt house." You can look inside the regular house as you walk by, but it's not open to visitors. When we were there, the stilt house could be seen from the outside but there was no access to the inside. The house are all set in a beautiful park behind the Ho Chi Minh pagoda. The flowers and trees are well worth seeing, as are the huge bonzais.
Good to see but busy. I'm glad I saw where the president lived and worked but it was crowded. No time for stopping, just look as you move slowly in line.

Very very busy. The opening hours for the Presidential Palace complex are so short that tremendous queues form, and you shuffle round Ho Chi Minh's Residences and the grounds which is a shame, as this turns what would be an enjoyable experience into an ordeal.
Interesting!. Interesting to see how he lived! I guess when you are the boss you get the nice things, the poor will just be poor, but that's ok, they are out there and I am in here.

A simple man. HO Chi Min saw himself as a man of the people, hence him living in his 'stick house' rather than the Presidential Palace. It is in the Botanical gardens, but you can only visit the area around his home. Worth seeing though.
great. come to know about the most well'known and admired in viet nam. this place is carefully guarded and secure. but people can still come inside.
Worth a visit. Interesting and worth spending some time here to get some sense of what went on here and some fine artefacts and history about Ho Chi Minh's background.

Behave and prepare for queues. Too crowded to be enjoyable. You join one long conveyor belt of tourists if you come here and may suffer the added chaos of large loud school groups. The most photogenic building is the French colonial Presidential Palace, you cant go inside but it looks impressive towering over its finely manicured gardens and ornamental pond. You can go inside Ho Chi Minh's minimalist stilted building if you are prepared to queue for a long time. An argument erupted between one of the soldiers guarding the house and someone in the queue. I don't know what it was over, possibly someone took a photo of something that wasn't allowed. This added an uncomfortable air of tension to the queue. There are a lot of rules when visiting this place, but its hard to know what they are. The only fun part of the visit was the quirky One Pillar Pagoda.
great. Saw the mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh. Wasn't able to go in as it was closed, but lovely to see it with lovely trees and flowers. The square had a lovely feel to it.

...don't feel bad if you miss out on going.... Long queues on the day we visited. Yes, the historical element was interesting and yes, the grounds are lovely, but don't feel you've missed out on anything if you don't make it.

Interesting. We enjoyed seeing the two houses Ho Chi Minh lived in. The park was interesting. The former French embassy looks quite monumental. See the One Pillar Pagoda. We did not go in the masoleum.
Buy the Eyewitness Guide for Vietnam
Ho Chi Minh's Residence. This place had such beautiful gardens. A quick tour. As with everything, try to get there earlier to avoid the crowds.

Interesting, a guide or excellent knowledge is necessary.. Lovely gardens, very beautiful grounds. I wouldn't say its a must do, very interesting and well maintained but takes a whole to go through, wouldn't really recommend for families with young kids - saw lots of tantrums on my visit! The architecture is lovely, and the gardens are excellent.

Very interesting place. Go on a weekday as the queues are not too bad, be aware you cannot wear hats or sunglasses or take cameras or phones into the tomb. Best for men to wear long trousers and ladies to cover their knees

Uncle ho's place. Definitely give this place a visit as there is so much to see and learn.
His summer house is amazing where he spent his last days.

An Interesting Part of History. The residence of Ho is worth seeing. He lived simply, and did not succumb to the excentric behavior of other supreme leaders. It is worth visiting if you are in the area.

Interesting to see how a wartime leader lived. On the grounds of an beautiful old French building which served as a Presidential Palace for the greeting of foreign leaders, the tour of the simple structure where Ho Chi Minh lived during the Vietnam War years is an interesting insight into the frugality of the North's supreme leader during that war. Unfortunately the ornate Presidential Palace next door is not open for tours.
Enjoyable piece of history. Lovely gardens, we'll worth a walk through but unfortunately you can't go inside. That would be awesome.

Glimpse of a leader. Visiting the Ho Chi Minh's residence gives a great understanding of the man and is a wonderfully restful spot. It is within the central government precinct and other memorials are nearby.

Well worth a visit. Known as Uncle Ho's house, it sits within the former leader's official residence. A beautiful lakeside location with lovely trees and shrubs, this simple wooden two storey house is just as he left it. A very basic bedroom and office are on view. the clinic where he died is just to the rear.

Beautiful place to stroll. We really enjoyed visiting this area! Beautiful gardens and history, It was a nice way to escape the busy-ness of the city! The gardens are very well manicured and the residence incredibly well preserved. A beautiful place to spend an hour!
Nice walk. Just outside Ho Chi Minh mausoleum, it is an excellent 30-45 min walk to complement mausoleum's visit.

Interesting. Despite the crowds and queues this is still worth the visit to see the simple life he lived overlooking the lake where he "called" the fish by clappingHe had his own bunker directly adjacent to his house not surprisingly taking into account the times he lived inNice to walk around the lake and look back on his house on stilts
From rags to riches. A large complex to see how Ho Chi Minh lived and worked. Opulent grounds but no real highlight to speak of.

Ho's humble home. Ho Chi Minh's former home is located next to an artificial lake and surprisingly compact for the residence of a national leader. In many ways, we found his home to be refreshing in its simplicity.

Worth a visit!!. Check the opening hours, as there are certain time of the day that its close for visiting. Good to know about Mr Ho's lifestyle in his early days. Such a simple and down to earth gentlemen.Should pay a visit
Should visit his modest home. Ho Chi Minh could have lived like a king but chose to live a more modest lifestyle. The gardens and very well maintained -- peaceful and quiet surroundings.
Ho Chi Minh's Stile House a "must see" in Hanoi. Very interesting and a beautiful oasis behind the Presidential Palace. The grounds are shady with beautiful well kept gardens.

Worth a visit. If you don't know much about this mans life this is worth a visit. We were surprised as to how as to how simple his accommodation was. The grounds were beautiful, quiet and well maintained. A morning well spent

A great insight into Ho Chi Minh's life and legacy. This is a must for a sense of what Ho Chi Minh achieved and meant to his people. His presence is the mausoleum is extraordinary, but also sad , as he wanted to be cremated and scattered in his country, not preserved. The house gardens and explanations give an insight to his work and times.

A glance at Ho Chi Minh lifestyle. After the visit to the HCM Mausoleum, his residence is definitely worth a visit. The magnificent Presidential Palace that was occupied by the French Governor-General of Indochina has been discarded by Uncle Ho because too luxurious and he preferred to live in a modest stilt apartment that become his permanent residence. A nice place to visit and understand HCM way to live. Always busy with tourists.
Interesting to see the way Ho Chi Minh lived!. Getting to see Ho Chi Minh's Residence explained a lot about his values. He lived modestly in keeping with his values.

Good to have a look. Behind the back of the mausoleum is Ho Chi Minh's house which is in a very peaceful location by the lake. Very interesting to see and hear how the man lived and the fact that he chose a smaller less pretentious place to live rather than the adjacent grand house.. Certainly worth a visit

busy but enjoyable. Another informative visit. The residence certainly is spartan, consolidating the view that Uncle Ho was a man who needed very little. The lake adjacent to the house was pretty. There is a lot more to see in the grounds than we had imagined as it is close to the tomb and Government buildings.

His humble abode. He did not seek luxury the way so many leaders do. If he had chosen capitalism instead of communism, Vietnam would probably be a thriving economy with a much higher standard of living, by now. The majority of Vietnamese continue to live in poverty, but in Hanoi, it is obvious that some people are very wealthy.This place was very crowded - a detracting feature.

House on Stilts. We visited former president Ho Chi Minh's house during the TET-holidays.Many Vietnamese tourists were in the gardens around his residence after visiting his Mausoleum.His house-traditionally built on stilts-is situated in a garden next to the Presidential Palace. He preferred to stay in this simple house instead of this beautifull colonial residence.This house was built in 1958 and modelled after the house where he lived near the Chinese border, fighting the French colonial army. The lower section is open and upstairs are 2 rooms : his bedroom and a working room with desk, telephone, books and a typewriter . It is said that Uncle Ho used this typewriter to write the Declaration of Independence !The open section downstairs was used to hold meetings with his Politbureau.In front of the house is a pond with hundreds of carp and behind the house is a fruit-garden and nearby a concrete bunker hidden under a hill to seek refuge from bombs during the Vietnam War.Honour guards watch if the tourist- crowds behave when visiting this house..This is a must-see place if you want to understand better the life of this leader .

cold was interesting didnt realise how bloody cold it was beautiful flowers every where. good looking place BONZAI TREES FABULOUS dot know how they grow in the cold lovely poinsettias everywhere . and orchids pity we picked the wrong time to visit cos of the cold we finished our tour of Hanoi with a cycllo ride hilarious the peddlas kept us entertained for the whole trip .
impressive. we enjoyed the colors, the vegetation, full of many different species, nicely trimmed, a lot of nice photos to be done there, but very crouded
It was quite an experience. The queues are something that you have to be prepared for . Apart from that it is quite an interesting insight inot the life fo Ho Chi Minh.

I am a new admirer!. To hear all the backgroung of this Vietnamese hero made me become a great fan of his. So humble and smart thinker, Ho Chi Minh was a determined person who managed to free Vietnam from the French domination after years travelling and studying abroad. In his residence there is no luxury or fancy objects, just the basic he needed to survive and become a national hero. The fancy cars were given as presents from the Russians and French and very useful for his own safety. Do not miss it and do ask about his history. You will be amazed.

Historical place to give some insights to Vietnam's past leader.. A fairly large complex, nicely maintained to showcase the simple living quarters of Ho Chi Minh. You get the feeling of the immense respect Vietnamese have for their great leader. A good place to understand the achievement and respect given to the revered leader of Vietnam. Look out for a unique coconut tree growing out of another tree in the middle of the complex. Quite unique.

Great place to learn about Ho Chi Minh. This is a great place to learn about Vietnam's most well known leader, see his residence and learned of his humility. Don't miss the mausoleum as well. Check out some of the 'free tour guides' in Hanoi (University students practicing their English) and have them guide you around. It was the best experience we had in Hanoi! Don't bring any liquids inside. This is a government area and security is tight. They will also ask you store any back packs in a locker.

A sight I won't forget. Was very weird seeing Ho Chi laying in the middle of a mosoleum definitely something I won't forget. It is very strict on security before getting in and whilst in there.Outside in the surrounding areas it is definitely worth seeing. The gardens and his house are quite nice and would have been better if the weather was good. There was lots of crowds there even at 9am so just go with the flow. We went with a guide and some of the details seemed a bit shady. after researching the man and his gardens the two stories dont add up but it is nice to see and hear things from a vietnamese perspective.

Well worth the visit.. Spending a short time here gives a real feel of how life may have been in Ho Chi Minh's time. The house is preserved as it was in the early 70's. It can get pretty crowded with visitors at times but it is definitely worth the time.
Lots of propaganda. A beautiful place but full of propaganda making him sound like a saint. Very interesting, crowds all over the place. It seems like theatre to us.
View Ho Chi Min lying in State. a moving queue for this unusual sight. Interesting to see where he lived and his Palace and his vehicles !
Very good. Great place to see where Ho Chi Minh lived, and the Presidential Palace and grounds he governed from. Really well set out, and a great experience overall.

Interesting to see but more of a national attraction. Not a lot to see, and it won't take you long. If your short of time I wouldn't recommend visiting. More of a national attraction as opposed to international.

No More than you would Expect. This is virtually an obligatory venue on a visit to Hanoi. It is interesting to see the rooms that HCM used and the fairly spartan way in which he lived, but in all honesty it is largely what one would expect and there is little to add to one's understanding or appreciation of the man, Not a waste of time but more a homage.

Lovely place. The grounds are beautiful, and the presidential palace is lovely to look at. The queue to walk through the house on stilts was quite long, but it kept moving so we didn't have long to wait. Nice collection of old cars.

Nice park. Lovely grounds of the residence but you only get to look through a couple of windows into rather boring rooms. Would like to have been able to walk through house. Worth a look while in the area. lovely old Pagoda and temple outside residence area.
Nice House. Nice house, not too elaborate and not that special, but it's what Ho Chi Minh wanted, it's in the grounds of the mausoleum so you may as well see it
Uncle Ho's residence. not a lot to see or comment on. 50's furniture was interesting, but not much of anything. a frugal man !!

Good insight into life of Ho Chi Minh. We visited the humble house on stilts from which Ho Chi Minh ruled Vietnam until his death in 1969. It gave a good insight into how humbly this great man lived in a really peaceful setting.

Surprisingly interesting. You don't actually go inside his house/palace (which is what I thought). But you get to see into where he actually lived - very humble! - and the grounds are quite lovely too. It's a pretty 'quick' stop but if you have gone to the mausoleum, it's worth taking a look at too!

Interesting Insight into his personality. Given the reverence for Ho in Vietnam, it was interesting to visit where he lived and to see how simplistically he liked to keep his lifestyle. It was a bit surprising.

I Wouldn't Have Believed That I'd Go Here. What a transformation. Initially we saw the very grand Presidential Palace, and then the Palace outbuildings, one of which housed his old cars, Then we see the humble dwelling where he lived (with its adjoining nuclear bunker).

Highly Recommended for History/Politics Buffs. Visiting this location meets several needs. First, visiting the mausoleum and HCM residence and museum is recommended for any one interested in Vietnamese history. But this location is great to visit for anyone looking for a tranquil and pretty respite from the hustle and bustle of the city. Visit early morning for the mausoleum and check the schedule as it is closed some days.

Very interesting historical site.. I think this was good to see along with the mausoleum. It is very representative of what influenced Vietnam during its early years and the role that communism played in the formation of the country. If you see the countryside and this place you can really see the difference between the leader and the common people. It is amazing to think that this place survived all the bombing of the north during the war. It is a must see if you go to Hanoi.

Interesting, but not a must see. This place has some interesting history about the French treatment of Vietnamese during occupation, and then the use of the prison during the US Vietnam war to hold US prisoners. If you plan to spend a bit of time in Hanoi, maybe check it out, but don´t prioritise it.
Cost. To expensive to only see a few rooms and they want you to pay extra for you to bring the camera with you.
Heavy Place use imagination. This felt like Tiananmen Square in Beijing without the atmosphere. Huge impressive mausoleum with plenty of flags and marching space. You need a good guide book or guide.

Get a piece of the Ho Chi Minh history. Whilst the Ho Chi Minh museum, situated not far from here, goes totally of topic when it comes to Ho Chi Minh, at least thats what I and other travelers obviously think, this is right on target.You will have a walk among historical buildings of the history of Ho Chi Minh in a pleasant park like environment with a little lake as well. The tranquility, the actual historical connection and the minimalistic guide pamphlet you'll get att the entrance will give you a small insight into the history of this man that is so present in the Vietnamese day to day life. Definitely worth the visit.
Relaxing. Ho's residence was very nice and seemed a very relaxing place for Ho to both chill-out and entertain guests.

Beautiful site. The whole site is very tranquil and beautiful (except for the mausoleum, which is ugly Soviet-era architecture). Go with a guide to learn of Ho's life and the long struggle for Vietnamese independence. Hanoi has incredibly busy streets and this is a lovely place to go if you need some space, quiet and beauty.

A must for your Hanoi itinerary. We moved on to this place after our 'mandatory' visit to the mausoleum and we were very impressed with how things have been maintained. There is lots to see in a peaceful environment, so don't miss it.

If you are going to the Mausoleum you may as well. Interesting to see where Ho Chi Minh worked and lived when in Saigon.An interesting tour around the grounds to see the tranquil setting nearby the Mausoleum.
Must see. When in Hanoi, you must see all things Ho Chi Minh. This is one of the more peaceful places in Hanoi and worth your time.

This is History and well worth the visit!. This is something you read about in North America so to visit and see all the different things that show you this man was just as ordinary as everyone else, he just chose to lead his people to victory over so many heartrending years. Everyone should visit this place not just for its place in history but for it's beauty and atmosphere!!!

Simplicity at it's best. We visited this attraction following viewing Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum. And this is an important component of the man's story as well as a lovely walk. An appreciation of simplicity in both needs and also a mans dedication to his beliefs and commitment to his country.Might be quite hot in summer.

Ho Chi Minh. A great site and a must see at Hanoi. The simplicity of the person at its best. Stayed in small rooms and work area although the full palace was there. The whole area is well maintained and brings a lot of peace and tranquility. A great man.

A humble residence.. The houses Ho Chi Minh chose to live in are as plain as it gets.
This was his thing. This was him.
The gardens themselves are nice, with a beautiful pond, where you can take some lovely photos.
An hour would cover the entire garden and the other buildings in the site.

Get to know a bit more about Ho Chi Minh. If you are visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum you may as well spend the extra time to see his residence. It doesn't take long and although it is usually quite busy it is still a nice walk and it gives you a bit more of an insight into his life. I recommend that if you use a guide to go here, make sure they have good language skills.

A must to visit if in town. I visited this attraction as an afterthought. I was visiting the mausoleum and decided at the last minute to pay it a visit, I am glad that I did. The grounds are very impressive and you get to visit H's house, see his cars, office, meeting rooms and even where he slept. All good stuff.

Surprisingly tranquil. As you walk past the massive Ho Chi Minh mausoleum towards the Residence you have little idea of the tranquil garden and pond you are about to see. The residence itself is very impressive but it is easy to see why he preferred to live in the small pagoda in the grounds. Very interesting and very beautiful.
Really Good. Very Interesting, Remember to have a Tour Guide, so they are able to explain it all to you. Well worth a visit. only wish that we could have gone inside.

A calm oasis from the cahotic rhythm of Hanoi. The setting and grounds are lovely and a pleasant diversion from the ever present and exciting chaos of Hanoi traffic. Perhaps not as grand as Western comparisons but entirely relevant to the context of Vietnamese history. The grander buildings and no doubt the park like setting are reminders of Colonial French rule and by comparison the modest living quarters that Ho Chi Minh took for himself seem entirely compatible to a revered leader who took on the might of the world to reunite his country. This is an opportunity to reflect and compare the paradox of two entirely different worlds clashing in the same land.

What a residence!. Okay - not all Vietnamese people rate Ho Chi Minh, and his home may be considered modest, but this place it so tranquil, and it is a delightful place. For a communist, his car display is rather decadent though - you'll see his vehicles here.
Not terribly interesting, unless.... You are a classic car buff. His cars are all there. You don't go in the homes, just see them in a park setting.
Just OK.. It is a nice place to visit if you have some times to spend, but you won't miss much if you skip this place of interest.

Part of the History. We were very lucky to visit with a guide who was very informative, and gave us so much information about the kind of person Ho Chi Min was, that it made the place special. the serenity he sought, his daily habits with exercise, animals, and his little stilt house..a perfect place to visit after the mausoleum

Interesting to see the way Ho Chi Minh lived!. It was worth a quick visit to get an insight in his living habits.He was a visionary in his era and wanted his followers to also imbibe his frugal living habits...

Inspired by Simplicity. Take the time to visit HCM’s residence after going to the Mausoleum. It is a very well maintained attraction and gives you a sense of the serenity he tried to live in amongst the chaos of the period. Go through the whole site but try not to loiter while taking pictures as the military guards are very diligent in making sure things are flowing nicely. I would recommend you do some quick research before you visit to better understand the history and the timeline to help put some context behind some of the displays, the commentary and the signage. But in doing so, remember that there are two sides (actually three or four in this scenario) to the story, so brush up on a bit of both otherwise it might come across a little skewed.

Certainly a great inspiration for his people.. Not a fan of this kind of visit but that was part of the tour (a bit too military for my liking) but the whole park is pretty making it a must see if you're in Hanoi. We saw a group of ethnic people from the mountain on an expedition to the capital to pay their respects to this great man,and that was meaningful for me.

A NICE DAY IN THE PARK. We visited as gruop with are own guide whos knowledge was priceless. We moved at are own pace and every thing was explained and answered. Like most popular sites the key is to get there early.The area was kept clean, also a nice area to sit and whatch the world go by..

Presidential palace. Our visit was on a pouring wet day. Strangely this made the yellows of the building really look vibrant. A wonderfully impressive building set in gentle sweeping gardens but a shame to see no other people on the day enjoying it..I did find the instruction... No stopping on the bridge over the lake rather a strange request.The bridge would gave been a good place for photos!Enjoyed seeing the home occupied by Ho Chi Minh very interesting and humble. So many leaders strive for opulence and forget their people they govern.A worthwhile visit

A bit of history. After a visit to the Mausoleum this is also worth seeing as it gives a further Insight into the man known as "Uncle Ho". It shows his simple tastes and his basic living quarters. Judging by the old photos that accompany the displays it has been kept very true to the original state. An interesting bit of history.

A life of simplicity. The homes of Ho Chi Minh are on display here and demonstrate his commitment to a life of relative simplicity which progressed from more to less resplendent as he progressed in age.
Historical Insight. An opportunity to see where he lived and worked. Expect queues and to be moved along in quiet reverence.

Ho ho where you bin. this going to see ho chi min was a highlight hed just come back from Russia to have work done but the whole experience was not to be missed his museum was excellent with a anti war slant and piccasos Guernica painting in the forefront well worth a day out the whole thing .
Cult of personality. Interesting and pretty grounds, but you must read history of Uncle Ho to see full picture behind the propaganda.
Boring. Very long queues the house and grounds were very busy with not a lot to see lots of waiting around and then were rushed past the exhibits
Beautiful gardens. Nice place to stroll around. Buildings are scattered around a lake that is very picturesque. You can see where HCM spent his days and nights.
good visit. Interesting to see where "Uncle Ho" lived and worked. The grounds, etc. are well kept and clean. He lived modestly which is unusual with leaders!

Good complex to walk around. After you've seen the HCM mausoleum, you can buy a ticket to walk around the grounds where HCM used to live during the war, his planning room and other areas built around a small lake. The place gives an idea of the simple life that HCM led and is probably one of the reasons why he is so revered nationally. The grounds are vast and well kept and it's a very relaxing to walk idly thru the tree lined paths. Once finished, you walk through a few touristy souvenir shops and head towards the One Legged Pagoda. If you're in the area to see the HCM mausoleum, you might as well get a ticket and see this as well.

A private view of uncle Ho. This is a relatively large area with a lot of open space. It includes his house where you can see his rooms plus the cars that he drove. Is also next to the presidential palace and not far from Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum
Historical. Pretty grounds with a few structures on it. The home itself is very, very simple.. There is a garage with a few old vehicles.Just one of the sights to see-nothing really spectacular
Very Beautiful. This is a very beautiful mansion like home with beautiful grounds. Interestingly enough, Ho Chi Minh lived in a separate, very small quarters away from the main house.
It's okay. I am not sorry I went, but am not sure I would recommend it. The visit itself does not take long, but it is all a bit cheesy and there are not good explanations of what is on display.
Nice. It was nice to see how Ho Chi Minh livedNice grounds I think it cost 20 000 or 25 000 dong Once again there is security everywhere

A Must see sight. Everybody coming to the city must at some stage head towards this attraction, and they will not be disapointed. A large lake is surrounded by little buildings, and in each is some history of what and when Ho Chi Minh stayed there, the signs are all very clear.

You Have to See. Very interesting insight into this man. There was the huge mansion that was his to stay in but he choose to live in a wood frame house on stilts with a huge pond infront of it where he enjoyed doing tai chi and clapping his hands to bring the carp to top of pond. Home was very basic and humble and he seemed man who lived by basic means. Another must go and see

An interesting insight of a local hero. A beautiful setting in parklands. The setting was very tranquil even though there were throngs of people visiting. The house was simple yet looked very comfortable and relaxing to live in. Well worth a visit.

A lovely addition to a mausoleum visit. We added this on after we had visited the mausoleum and it was good to see how HCM lived when he was in power. The former Governor's residence was very obviously French and it was nice to see that the new regime had left it intact. Three of HCM's cars are on display but the highlight would be the stilt house which looks almost like he left it. It seems to indicates that despite his obvious power he tried to live a simple life. Lots of Vietnamese also visit and it is interesting to see their love and reverence for a past leader.
long walk worth the visit.. First visited the resting place of Ho Chi Minh and then the palace. Beautiful place with a lake in the middle. Should not miss while visiting hanoi

A fascinating look at HCM's life. As a glimpse into the life of a man that I had learned that day was very learned and well travelled, and didn't seem to abuse his position in the way that some leaders would, I found it interesting to see the relatively frugal way he lived amongst the splendour of the old royal palaces.

You can look at it. The Palace grounds are quite nice, and you can follow the crowd walking on the designated path around the outside of the palace, but you don't actually get to see inside the palace at all. In start juxtaposition to the palace, you do also get to see Uncle Ho's stilt house, his small residence right on a small lake, and that is interesting to see his stark lifestyle.
lake side simplicity. Worth a visit to see how Ho chi min choose to live. nice walk, good little souvenir shopping, interesting garden

Definitely see while in Hanoi. The palace and grounds are beautiful and the private residence is quaintly situated on a small lake - all very lovely and a nice respite from the busy city. Definitely worth a visit while in Hanoi as depicts the REAL Ho Chi Minh, a simple man who wanted to live a simple life and win freedom for the people of Vietnam.

Nice but very busy. We visited at 8.30 am and already it was very popular and busy. Try not to visit on a Sunday if possible as the queues build up from around 7.30am. The actual residence is quite small and simple, but the grounds and a lake are pretty to walk around

It's all here, but who cares?. Here you have it: Uncle Ho's crib, the big French mansion he shunned for more modest digs, his rides (including a way-cool Russian armored car), his fish pond,and the bunker where he hid while Nixon dropped payload after payload from B-52s on Hanoi. Interesting, yes. But hey, everybody's gotta live somewhere.

Interesting. Was part of a day trip of Hanoi, is in a beautiful garden location
and still an interesting part of history that I'm glad I saw.

Take it very seriously. Went with tour group so were advised how to dress before we left hotel. Must nit wear shorts, knees must be covered, shoulders covered. No sunglassses or hats, bags to be left on bus. No cameras or phones. Hands not in pockets. Silence when entering mausoleum until you come out. Follow all instructions by the guards. Usual wait of 20 mins on a good day, hours in the summer. Nice covered walk way which will be good in the hot sun. Lots of people so pre arrange where to meet up after.
Better than the museum. We had a guide to take us around the Palace, it was very interesting, combining living with work and even strong rooms for war in the basement. An interesting experience

Ho Chi Minh Residence. Not far from his Mausoleum, it is interesting to see how this great little man lived . Cute the garage with the 2° hand cars. His house on stilts , bedroom , study. The lake and the gardens are an oasis from the caos of the streets.On the same grounds is the Presidential Palace. Opening hours :Summer 7.30 to 11.am and from 2 pm. to 4 p.m Winter 8.00am to 11.am and from 1.30 p.m. to 4 p.m.On every weekday except Monday & Friday afternoon. Entrance fee to be payed.Not much

Little HOuse On The Lake. It was hard to imagine why Ho Chi Min wouldn't want to live here. With all the hustle and bustle of the big city, a little house on the lake would be where I would settle that's for sure!It's not like Japanese movies like I'd thought. You know how how everything is dark green and then there's a pristine white pavilion. This was more like brown ground and palm trees. like Burma. I got a few ideas for my own house. It's very calming. loved the vege patch.

Nice Stroll. Walked thru this area with my guide who explained Ho Chi Minh's background as we looked at the two homes he occupied. He lived a very simple life and appreciated beautiful grounds/landscaping and water. There is also a bunker adjacent to his first home which I wish would have been available to tour. Peaceful but not exciting.
All the locals visit on a Sunday. Very busy here with the local people paying their respects & seeing where he lived but an interesting visit.

Calm and Serene. It is uplifting to visit Ho Chi Minh's Residence, as part of a tour we visited the Ho Chim Minh Mausoleum and then walked over to the residence and the house on stilts. The yellow house is resplendent and huge, but our tour guide told us that Ho Chi Minh actually chose to live in the house on stilts. We saw his three automobiles and some of his rooms sparsely furnished. The garden and the pond that surrounds the house is beautiful and serene. There were plenty of grapefruit on trees in the garden when we visited. The place is a welcome change after the gravitas of the visiting the mausoleum.

The simple life. It was interesting to see how simply Uncle Ho lived in this house on stilts adjacent to his mausoleum. A visit to the latter can include the trip through his gardens and this house with its lovely calming lake in front and also the one pillar pagoda.

Myth of Ho Chi Minh is Demonstrated Here. The Vietnam government has made a Ho Chi Minh a Washington/Lincoln cult figure. His humble abode that they show furthers the image they are trying to create. Beautiful place to visit. Can see it well on a walking tour

Check the opening times. Nice to get a brief glimps of where uncle Ho lived and worked in a building behind the old French palace. Check the opening times as from memory it is closed from 11am till 3pm on weekdays. You can easily tie this trip in with a visit to the Ho Chi Minh Museum, Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and one Legged Pagoda - also slightly less popular is the wreckage of a downed B2 bomber in a pond in local neighbourhood.
long walk. the entrance to the residence with the Presidential Palace in the foreground was impressive and also the house itself is symbolic of Uncle Ho's lifestyle..

Interesting and worth it. This is part of the complex where you can see his old house on stilts, as well as the yellow office/living quarters next to the garage with 3 old cars used by him. Typically you will enter these parts after the mausoleum. The grounds are lovely and the building is kept in pristine condition. The one thing to keep in mind is that the place is jammed with locals and tourists on Sundays especially, so you may wish to time your visit to an open weekday!

Ho Chi Minh's residence. Impressive. The monument is simple yet majestic. Like the man.The grounds are peaceful, full of trees and little market stalls. There are some lovely temples in the grounds, but remember to wear shorts below the knees otherwise entrance into one of the temples will be denied.Ho Chi Minh's house is stunningly simple and faces a man made lake. The guide told us a lot about Uncle Ho and the history of the area.Well worth the visit
Ho's House. This was part of our Day Hanoi tour. Otherwise we would not have gone out of our way to visit. The grounds are well kept but not a high interest level.
Well worth the visit. Go if you can, it is beautifully done. Loved his residence, would love to have the same to live in if I could. They have preserved everything well. Do go, it is lovely.

Ho Chi Minh comples. It is a nice area to walk through, see a very nice french house in an terrible yellow color. The residence where Ho Chi spend his old days looks very serene. He was enjoying his old life and did not need much only nice cars (how manlike).It is a nice area to walk around, the mausoleum is only open in the morning and not on monday and friday.

The home shows a measure of the leader. In stark contrast to most palaces we have seen around the world, the residence is simple, spare, wooden and surrounded by nature. We didn't know that side of Ho Chi Minh before.
Loved this. Was a beautiful place to visit and a nice break from the hustle & bustle of Hanoi.Well worth a visit and the garden & lake are a nice place to take some time out.

Interesting but busy. Found the grounds were peaceful even on a busy day it's easy to see how quiet it was a place to think. Was amazed to see how modest the accommodation was. But on the day we visited it was extremely busy so took away some of the experience and there was no detail there explaining anything around the residence.

Interesting and Serene. Surprising how modestly and simply this powerful man actually lived. His residence was quite humble and sparsely adorned. For all the power he had while living in Hanoi, you would have thought he could have lived a more lavish life style.The gardens surrounding his dwelling are stunning and serene. You can even see the spot from which he is said to have fished from on the beautiful small park located on the grounds. Take the time to spend a relaxing morning or afternoon here.

Tremendous Propaganda. This visit was very entertaining. The communist government has elevated this man to hero status who killed thousands of his own countrymen, not to mention thousands of Americans. Entertaining to see his modest home and bomb shelter but no mention of his some 300 "darlings".
Beautiful but not very interesting. Large territory with some buildings that once were the residence of uncle Ho. Nothing special, but worth visit if you walk by.
Uncle Ho's Cabin. Simplicity of the man is inspirational. True to his beliefs till his last day, this homage to him is a reminder about what only one person can do to influence world's history.

excellent!. Coming inside, you can witness a site left in the genuine state of the President last days here. The house has two floors. The ground floor was the meeting place, consisting of 12 chairs around a large table. Upstairs, there is a bookshelf used as a wattle between his study room and bed room. The lowest level of the shelf is laid a small typewriter for him to type himself. His bed room is very simple with a single wooden bed, a small blanket, a rush mat, a fan made of palm leaves and a bottle of water. you can see a cotton bonnet he used to wear when alive. Some books periodicals he was reading are left on the table.
Great history. It rained the day we visited but we toured the grounds anyway with hundreds of other visitors. Lots of history and very interesting place to visit.

Excellent. The house within the grounds is especially interesting. It has a simple, clean design lines. It's also interesting to see the other tourists who are visiting especially the groups from China.
learnt a lot about Vietnam history. good account of french colonialism, and more recent war with US. first few rooms a bit dull, then gets into it's stride

Nice cool and calm place. A nice historical place to visit in Hanoi. It is helpful if you take a guide. Guide can describe the background elaborately to make the visit meaningful. It is really impressing how they have preserved the cars and furniture. The visit will take about an hour.

Beautiful location, well preserved. Really interesting to see where Ho used to live. It's set in a very idyllic setting away from the noisy craziness of the streets of Hanoi. You can see the old cars that he used to own which is cool. The best part of it though is the gardens and ponds. Very nice place to walk around and it was free I think so well worth a short trip after visiting Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum .

A view into a very interesting life. With a big crowd of other people I wandered through Uncle Ho's residence. His life is on display there with his quarters and car easy to observe. Interetsing to think that this was the residence of a man who had such an influence on the world, yet failed to witness his final victory. Touching and thought provoking location.

Palace which you can't visit. The Presidential Palace looks great but as one is not allowed to go inside or even to take a photo...we did ask one of the guards and he said NO, you can only walk by and have a look.....

Beautiful setting. Ho (with a given name) meaning He who enlightens, Chi meaning Will (or spirit) Minh meaning Light Residence is in the lovely grounds of the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. The grounds also have a lovely lake and the Residence is a Stilt House with two rooms. This is a beautiful place to visit.

Interesting historical location. We found this location of great interest. We toured the site ourselves, even though there is an opportunity to do so with a guide/interpreter. Ho Chi Minh's garage collection of vehicles was great to see also.
Uncle Ho's House. Kind of a shrine. Bus loads of Vietnamese come to see where their great leader has worked and lived.

Interesting house and garden. This is a very well kept area, I think a guide helps you understand more about the history and political background when viewing the residence, but we found it interesting.

Great morning spent in Hanoi. This was part of a day tour we went on. It was very good. Lovely gardens to walk around and escape the heat of the day. An amazing property. The displays are very informative and it did help that we had a guided tour.

An interesting contrast. It was, from a historical perspective, interesting to see where this revered and highly influential person lived and just how modest he really was but it seemed surreal given all the overt capitalism going on around this area. I wonder what he would think...
Its ok. Its behind the hochiming mausoleum so if you are there, you could just go but you see a replica of his house and some old cars. Not really worth the time

The heart of Hanoi. We went there on an organised tour & it was very obvious that, to northern Vietnamese, this is a place of great reverence. It really is a must see if you go to Hanoi as it has a similar if not more important place in their history than any temple or historical museum.

Nice place. Good place clean quiet Everything look like still alive Everyone in here have friendly and they can use english wellFrom here can go many place nearly I have many nee friend in here And can buy souvenier from hereHave many shops before go out to museum and one pagoda after hereFor sure i ll come back here again
Uncle Ho's house. Nice easy place to visit, good history lesson. Very interesting to get the Vietnamese perspective of Ho Chi Ming.

A worth while excursion. This is a very interesting place to visit. The gardens are well kept and quite peaceful if you want to get away from it all for a while. There is some great French architecture to be seen here as well.

Beautiful & well maintained complex ........ This beautiful & well maintained complex of Ho Chi Minh's residence has a lot histories to tell. Thus it's a must to visit when you are in Hanoi. It's better than the Musoleum .......

Need to decide if they want tourist or not. Well worth a visit but they don't make it easy the staff certainly won't help you just don't seem interested in tourist.Would have been a lot better had we got the hotel to help us find a guide to take us round.

Ho Chi Minhs little house. This cute dwelling is set amongst the beautiful grounds and lake behind the Tomb. It is interesting to see that he chose to live a simple life rather than a grand lifestyle. There are soldiers on guard, but it still seemed to be very relaxed, unlike at the tomb. A lovely place to contemplate the serenity and calmness of Hanoi in an idyllic setting. On leaving there are a lots of places to purchase a cool drink and pick up some very cheap souvenirs.
Very special. It was very interesting very beautiful grounds and garden with a lake in the middle . You see some of his cars and furniture in his house
visit to ho. lovely garden. Good to view a home with so much history behind it. Seeing the old cars were great The crowds were conducted in a orderly fashion

Ho Chi Mihns residence. Very interesting to see his residence and the way he lived and worked. The crowd's can be a problem sometimes especially on weekends and public holidays but everyone keeps moving albeit at a slow pace.
interesting place. Went in the month it was closed to see Ho Chi Min where he rests. But the rest of the tour around the place was good

Simply Historical. The Presidential Palace is situated in the middle of well-manicured and well-maintained gardens. The main palace is a bright big yellow French structure, serves as a nice contrast of the luscious greens. You can also see and visit the famous House on Stilts, and the large pond.
Interesting. Visited this after walking past the mausoleum. Unfortunately this was closed but the residence was interesting. Not a lot to see but the grounds are beautiful and the cars interesting.

Home of a humble man. It was interesting to see how Ho Chi Minh shunned living in the Presidential Palace, preferring to live in the more modest servant's quarters, at first, until finally having a small 4 room house built as his home. The location is stunning, being right on a lake in the gardens of the Presidential Palace. Well worth the visit!
Beautiful Gardens. This was a haven amongst the hustle and bustle of Hanoi, very beautiful gardens and lake. Well worth a visit.
Lovely gardens. Its pretty basic really... everything is behind glass, but the grounds are beautifully manicured and the ponds are beautiful.

Too Bad Congress doesn't copy this lifestyle. This place is well worth the trip. The grounds are graceful and lovely, and the home spare yet elegant in its simplicity. It was very impressive and gave a real sense of a patriot who dedicated his life to his nation's independence, and worked for others and clearly not himself.

Insight into the place where he worked. Not sure if he really spent as much time here as they would have you believe, otherwise the US might well have dropped more bombs on it. But it does give an idea of how it is to work in the inner sanctum of the polit-bureau

Interesting if you are curious about history. A rather unique experience. Wear sensible clothing, as in clothing you would wear for a job interview. Go there early, and don't bring heavy stuffs with you. Bring either an umbrella or hats if you are visit during summer.

Ordinary but Noble Man. I respect such an ordinary but NOBLE man, as described in an
exhibition with the phrase. Visiting his residence, I fully agree with the phrase. I had a better understanding of what Ho Chi Minh had contributed to his country. I dislike nothing.

Mauseoleum and Residence - arrive early and dress appropriately. The dress code is strict - shoulders and back covered, clothes to at least knees etc. You must also check in backpacks, large bags, and water to the free luggage check in. The complex is only open from 830 to around 11am so timing is important. I get there around 930am and join the long queue. All up, it's probably 1km or so of queuing under shaded awning. Luckily today it was busy but we moved forward at a slow walking pace rather than being stopped. It ends up being a scenic and leisurely stroll through the park grounds so it's not too bad.I watch the changing of the guards in their crisp white uniforms, bayonets, and sharply defined steps. Entering the Mausoleum we are gestured by guards to remove hats and be silent. We file through the marblesque tomb past Ho Chi Minh embalmed and under spotlight. He looks rather like a wax figure from Madam Tussaud's. I don't know why people say it's creepy; I thought it was very reverent.I loved the moment when the guards around Uncle Ho changed and two of the young men smiled at each other as they swapped. The young guy struggled for a few moments to swap the smile for a Buckingham Palace guard type look and had to keep his face ducked down; I'm not sure if anyone else noticed.From there, we file outside and follow the path through the grounds. The Presidential Palace is viewed from the outside as is the Stilt House - though the windows are open so that we can view the interior. It looks homey and I can see why it would be more comfortable living there by the lake then in the palace.
Beautiful grounds. this was a lovely tour. Lots of tourists though. You see were he lived what cars he had. The grounds around his residence are well kept and beautiful.
must do. that the only tour you must do in Hanoi as it explain big part of the bloody complicate history of Vietnam

One of my favorite stops. I like how the yellow color of the Presidential Palace blends with the lush greens. We weren't able to go inside but the Palace itself was very picture-worthy. We also got to see Ho Chi Minh's stilt house and catch a glimpse of his humble lifestyle. The entire place is very relaxing with plenty of trees and a fishpond. I would recommend this!
interesting. all well preserved as it was left. Small cozy house in the middle of a park facing a little lake. very peacefull.

seen as total of a visit to Ho Chi Minh Square. Sadly it was very hot and we were required to stand around a lot to listen to much information, there was little shade and nowhere to sit. I only looked at the residence from the outside but as Ho lived a simple life there was little furniture.On a Sunday the crowds are incredible and you had to file very fast past this place.
Home of Ho Chi Minh. Ho Chi Minh devoted his life and his considerable skills to the Vietnamese people. It is interesting to see what a simple life he lead. Others could look and learn

Ho's house and gardens. Go visit his house and gardens and see the presidential palace. Go early as the buses come in droves. Its only $1.50 for entry, no guide needed, stroll through and admire the architecture.
Home of Ho Chi Minh. It was an interesting experience. Especially to see how warmly he was thought of by the two college students who were our guides. The grounds were beautiful

What a simple man Uncle Ho was!. Even though the heavens opened whilst we were visiting this attraction it didn't deter us. The grounds here are magnificent. His home was very simple and it makes you understand about the man.

Old Goverments Leaders Home and Camade post. lots to see, the old home is where the government (communist) leader once lived. Old Cars and living displays of the old Leader. It was called the palace, many presidents and leaders have stayed there.

Ho Chi Minh would suggest some corrections to the English signs.. A great place to visit in honour of one of History's great people. He spent his life fighting for the right of the People of Viet Nam to run their own country. He was responsible for demanding that his people be educated. He developed a plan, which included building schools, and he would be disappointed to see so many displays with poorly written English explanations. Staff at the complex should seek assistance, and correct this over site.

You are expected to see this place.. The walk will span the presidential palace, Ho Chi Minh home and his second residence- the house on stilts. There is a lot to see and it is a history lesson. You can certainly get well acquainted with the life and work of this important Vietnamese historical figure. Garden itself and the lake are very nice.
fabulous. We took photos about the residence of Mr. Ho. It was amazing and the environment was cool. There's an entrance fees but it was worthy.
Ho Chi Minh's Residence. Very humble house, beautiful in its simplicity. A must visit on your next trip to Vietnam. Gardens beautifully maintained.

Ho Chi Minh's Residence. Convenient since it is right next to the presidential palace which is at the exit of Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum. A nice walk through his first home, the garden and his 2nd home on stilts.

Part of the trip. PART of our tour of Hanoi, well looked after and we found it interesting, though younger people would probably not, it all depends on your interest in the history of Vietnam and the Vietnam war.
Exactly what you would expect. Well laid out but you cant get in the big house. Interesting but nothing exciting, again exactly what you would expect.
Ho Chi Minh's Residence. Beautiful grounds, and tour guides tell interesting stories not necessarily factual?) but well worth your time to visit.

Was relaxing. Another relaxing couple of hours, there are a number of things to see here, his quarters, the place he had meetings and his cars it is flat and there are plenty of areas to sit and relax.
watching the Vietnamese people here is half the fun. you truly appreciate the reverence that uncle Ho is held in, this is a great cultural experience that you should see after visiting the mausoleum.
Well worth a visit. The gardens are lovely ,the whole place was good.just showed how simple Ho Chi Mihn residence was and a simplistic life he led .

Kicked out by guards if you do not look Vietnamese. We followed the crowd in after visiting the mausoleum, but a guard blew the whistle at us to either buy tickets or get out.
After being singled out, we didn't want to waste our time and money here.
The tickets prices are for all visitors, but apparently only tourists must pay. The mausoleum, however, is free for all visitors.

Nice Cars. We stopped by here after seeing Ho Chi Minh. The weather was atrocious which I am sure soured our experience somewhat but apart from his small collection of vintage cars (3) it was a very underwhelming experience. Go and see it but don't expect a whole lot that's all.

fleshes out the Ho legend. Demonstrated his simple outlook and lifestyle. Uncle Ho wanted a simple burial, and lived simply before that. Didn't need fancy
lifestyle or rich lodging and furnishing. He knew who he was, and
the self appointed tasks with success.

Worthwhile trip. Ho Chi Minh's house is all preserved well and gives a much more in-depth understanding to modern Vietnam and Ho Chi Minh's life. There's a lot to see and it's really interesting- when I went with our group it was incredibly hot which meant we could understand the reasoning behind Ho Chi Minh's decision to build a house to keep cool. Definitely worth a trip, but get a tour guide!

Histocal place. We are in the column and slowly walking to visit. Very solemn place. We saw him lied there but not sure real due a little bit far. Anyway just few minute is hard to realize. The scenery around here is spectacular and quiet. For us it's very worth to see.

Interesting. I visited Ho Chi Minh's Residence after I visited the Mausoleum. It was very beautiful and kind of peaceful. The ground were lovely and there was a bit of place to visit on the compound. I wish they had more information about some of the residence, you could have rented a tour guide but I never like to rent a tour guide when I travel I would rather explore on my own. There are also a lot of people pretty much the line from the Mausoleum comes over to the residence, so it does get a bit crowded and loud. It feels like you are constantly in a line while visiting the whole compound. It is cool to see, but nothing spectacular. The best part was walking around the gardens, most people seem to continue on to his stilt home but I went off towards the Mango Walk and there was hardly anyone there, it was so nice to be out of the line.

Cool but Overdone. The grounds are beautiful and peaceful, and the buildings there lovely. However, once again, the Vietnam quasi-worship of Uncle Ho wears a bit thin after a while. We went on a "City Tour". Get ready for the stares from the natives if you're tall and white.

We visited following the mausoleum. HCM lived a very simple life and you can experience that by visiting his home. Although there is a very fine palace nearby Ho chose to live in this simple home where he welcomed guests , particularly children. The gardens are beautiful although they are very busy. Another must see if you are visiting Vietnam for the first time.

Nice place to visit. From Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, I kept walking and found out that there was another place to visit which is the Ho Chi Minh's Residence.
This is the place where Uncle Ho used to live. We can see the rooms, the cars, and there was also a lake in the area.

Stunning gardens. The residence is made up of the palace, garage, house on stilts and the beautiful gardens.You can take your time and wander around at your own pace, but there are a lot of people around. It was disappointing that it started pouring while we were there and be warned there is very little shelter, so take your umbrella!It was very interesting and we learnt a lot about Ho Chi Minh that I didn't know about.Well worth a visit.
Pleasant finish after mausoleum. Gardens beautiful and story of HCM good but a little sense of propaganda about it. Allow some purist imagination and expect HCM to seem more like Ghandi than Ghandi

Empty House in Pleasant Garden.. After visiting the Mausoleum we kept on going along the path and went to see where Uncle Ho used to live. To be honest it was worth it for the photograph of the Presidential Palace - which you are not allowed to take from the street. The house itself is quite attractive but is at the end of the day an empty house and I think the importance of it was a little lost on me. Having said that there is a lovely little lake beside the house and beautiful gardens so once again for you photo lovers - some great shots to be had here. Worth the visit.

Ok if you are in the area. Located quite near the mausoleum, this attraction was quite cheap to enter although lots of people didn't seem to buy tickets they just wandered in - think it was only something like 50p in. The place is completely littered with stalls selling pretty awful tat (and I am a tat queen) and snacks/drinks. It was pouring down when we went so umbrella and mac sales where going down a storm. You probably need about half hour/hour to wander around - the palace area is cordened off and you cannot access the inside. It contains Uncle Ho's house/meeting rooms and a 3 of the cars he used. There is also a building on stilts but not worth queuing to go in. Small lake and garden area finishes the walk off.Only slightly interesting and even when it was raining, there were loads of people milling about.Wouldn't go out of your way unless you really want to know more about Ho and how he lived.

Hard to find and still sells tickets after closing time. We found this hard to find and got there with 30 mins to closing time. Do not attempt to get there via the botanical gardens, you can't.A whistle stop visit of the major attractions before being escorted off the grounds by the guards.As we leaving a group were attempting to enter having just bought tickets after the place had closed. Get there in time !!
Ho chi min. it is best to do this attraction with a proper guide otherwise you would have to wait in a very long queue. They did rush you in very quickly though.

Architecture was great, small, tastefull, simple but beautiful. Part of the Ho Chi Minh Museum complex, easy to see this when seeing the museum and one pillar pagoda. Kind of on the garden walk behind the museum.
impressive residence. what a well-preserved square! it is well-maintained and guarded. we were just outside the building(residence) and took some photos.
Worth a visit. Interesting. Grounds and architecture are interesting. A bit of propaganda though likely as to be expected.
Go for the history. Beautiful surroundings and the history is great. Glad we got the opportunity to see it for ourselves. highly recommend

Very beautiful palace. It is worth the time to visit. It is better to have a guide who can explain everything, because there is no way you will see everything on you own. The large round carpet upstairs is breath taking. The wall murals a very intricate.

Great to see. Great place to visit be prepared to line up and weave your way through the resident as there are lots of visitors
So you have to take photos quite quick as you are waved on as not to hold up the que
Somewhat interesting. It's certainly worth visiting - since you're on-site anyway if visiting the mausoleum, however there's not really a lot to see.
Nha Bac Ho. Now i know why the people of Veitnam loved this man , and what he tried to bring to them. You can see that he was a man of the people.

A must do when in Ha Noi. We found it really interesting to walk the same paths than the Great Ho Chi Minh, visit the house where he lived, see the cars he'd been given and finally go around the house on stilts where he used to spent a lot of his time. All this is beautifully kept and although it's very you can't leave Ha Noi without seeing it.

Only OK. It was interesting to see where he lived, and walk the grounds, but the actual mansion is off limits. When we were there, it was elbow to elbow people. Not much time is needed, but it is a natural next stop if you are going to the mausoleum.

Big queues. There were big queues to see the body of HoChiMin. I like the fact that a good part of the queuing area has got shades but because there are so many people, your time in the mausoleum seems very short as you have to keep shuffling through. You are not allowed to take any bags in so our guide held all our bags but I don't know where you put them if no one stays outside!
An Attraction?. You can't visit the palace. This is worthy of a look if you happen to be walking past but it is not a destination.

Well maintained historic area. Ho Chi Minh was a revolutionary who set about ending the French colonialist's grip on the country after 100 years of them enslaving and exploiting the Vietnamese people until around 1954. Ho's modest living quarters are preserved allegedly as they were when he resided here for 15 years until 1969. It seems the President was fond of Rolls Royces and Peugeots, some of them still aging undisturbed in the garage. There are several buildings which are in good repair, and nicely presented, and visitors can view a number rooms, including Ho's basically furnished bedroom, through the windows and doorways. Lots of people arrive in guided tours, however I found I could make my own way at my own pace, opportunistically eavesdropping on some of the commentary here and there to pick up a little bit of extra information.The impressive stately Presidential Palace, appears to be in good repair and sits nearby, amongst well established well kept gardens, but is not open to the public, being used only for ceremonial purposes.
