The precinct includes a small artificial lake, stocked with fish and on the far side is Uncle Ho's summer house, a delightful two storey wooden structure which looks almost new, so perfect is it's preservation. The lower floor has no walls on three sides, allowing air flow during the hot season, and upstairs are his bedroom and private office/library, with personal items and authentic furnishings. Wonderful. Take a walk in the whole garden and you will discover some delightful spaces used by the President. You may also seek out an odd underground rest room. Most guards were happy to be photographed and would offer directions and a little information if asked.

Paranoid. We came across the palace when we were walking to the mausoleum. I guess that you can not visit it. Even walking in the sidewalk next to it is not allowed. Vietnamese government is paranoid about safety.
French architecture, very yellow (awful color) and huge gardens.

Nice way to spend an hour - good access. This is interesting to visit if you're going to the Mausoleum, just to give you a little ore insight into the way he used to live. The palace and several residences are all housed within the same park, and all of them are really accessible by flat paths, so good for those in a wheelchair. You can't go into the palace, (it's only now used to host visiting dignitaries) and there are stairs into the wooden house, but it's just a simple wooden structure, with nothing to see inside, so it's enough to view it from the outside. The brick structure at the back of the wooden residence is where he died, but you can't go in here either. There are cafes and toilets at the exit.Fine to visit to say you've been there, but nothing overly exciting, except a nice walk around the park, if you can ignore the hundreds of other visitors.

Impressive. Built for him but he never actually lived in it as he saw it to be too big and he just wanted to live basic. It is well painted and maintained and the grounds and gardens are beautiful so it is well worth looking at

Ho Chi Min residence. Great to see what a simple, humble man he remained even though he gave his life to freeing his country and it's people from many years of occupation by the French and others. We were on a tour and would have like to stay longer so another time we would just go to the complex where the mausoleum and his residence is, among other buildings, and spend our own time looking around. Lovely peaceful setting around his residence and the place where he fed the goldfish.
Well worth a visit.. Although you don't go into the palace, just seeing the garden and little house that was built for him to live in gives you a feel of his life.

Ho Chi Minhs Residences. Very beautiful, but the grounds were so busy but you can manage to find a quiet corner, take plenty of drinks with you as I aobseved the westerner were charged considerably more than the locals on some stores

Touristy place. It was crowded, hot, and humid in June. Locals are rude, especially the males. There were trees, a small lake, some flowers, lots and lots of stalls selling gifts items and drinks for tourists and visitors. That was it.
Beautiful. Beautiful house, interesting to see how he lived and what kind of cars he had actually. It is a beatiful park around too.
Mrs.Melisa. The very wonderfull,Ho chi minh mousleum is very interesting place to visit and is a historic place.

Uncle Ho must have enjoyed his twilight years here. A modest and functional home, as befits a communist leader, but beautifully situated on the side of a lake. Uncle Ho must have enjoyed his twilight years here.

Interesting visit but not sure what we were looking at .... This was an interesting place to visit but there is no real guidance for those of us who do not speak Vietnamese and not a lot of information on display so it is hard to know if you are missing something. Lovely trees and grounds, very peaceful, but the place could be so much more if they put some effort into displays and signs. Even a hand out in another language (like you get at the museum) would be helpful.

Ok if you have spare time. Basically you get a chance to see from the outside the two buildings where the former president lived and worked. There is no opportunity to tour the interior and all u get to see is just a look into the windows. There is no commentary or descriptions and without any guide, it's really difficult to get a feel of the significance of the place, unlike for the locals. You could easily get through the whole tour in 30 minutes or less, so I think it would be worth your trouble only if you have covered other places you had wanted to see.

Long Queues - Bland Displays - Moving Mosh Pit. OK, it is a sacred place for the Vietnamese. I left wondering what was I supposed to see. The queues were long and you were hustled along and it felt like an assembly line operation. I am certain there were things of significance in the displays, but I was moved so fast with so many people that I missed an opportunity to see ---- what? I probably should have read about the venue before going - and would have done so if I knew I was going to be flowing in a moving mosh pit. Do yourself a favor and read all about the place before attending then you can have a better idea of what you are supposed to be looking for.
peaceful place. I was moved by the tranquility and the Aussie trees in the garden A grove of Grevillia Robusta or Silky Oaks- I wonder if Uncle Ho planted them?

Missed seeing the mausoluem. We went early in the morning and there was already a long queue. We thought it was because it was a Sunday but was told by our guide that everyday has a long queue as the locals respected HCM. A pity we missed the mauoluem this trip as it is only opened in the morning. We had even gone to get long pants the day before as we were informed no shorts and sleeveless shirts allowed. We only managed to visit the HCM residence behind the mausoleum.
Some more queuing but not for too long.. Located just behind the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, the residence is set in the Botanic Gardens. Some more queuing but not for too long.
interesting. Cover up elbows and knees. You can't carry anything except a camera. No hats or sunglasses when you enter the building. Soldiers and security watching your every move.

Incredible. During our travels, we went to see the Reunification Palace in Ho Chi Minh City where President Diem and came up to Hanoi to see where Ho Chi Minh lived. The contrast was incredible. We could not believe how "down to earth" Ho Chi Minh's residence was and how he was more one with nature than into materialistic decorations.

Pretty cool. A nice slice of modern history that should appeal to even those who are not au fait with Vietnam's political history. Really enjoyed seeing the well-preserved vehicles and homes of Ho Chi Minh - a vintage-lovers paradise!
Nice place. Came here with Hanoikids. Nice place to walk about and know more about HCM himself. Definitely need a guide to bring you around here to better understand.
waste of time and money. it's not worth visiting, you pay the entrance fee, but every building/house is not allow to go in. You just can walk in the garden and view these houses meters away.

Could be so much better. With the intention of seeing some authentic Vietnamese buildings and the residence of Ho Chi Minh I felt a little disappointed.From the distance you see the prestigious yellow house, used to welcome formal guest in Vietnam. Yet you cannot come close and views from outside the gates are better.The house of Ho Chi Minh himself is on full lock down and can only see through some windows and it simply does not feel authentic - saw it as well in 2 minutes.All other building just do not feel authentic either and the lack of information did not really help either.
Interesting walk in shady park. Saw both his original house and house on stilts. Interesting walk on a very hot afternoon. Saw the changing of the guard.
A must go. Definitely a good insight to the life and contributions of Ho Chi Minh, one of the founding fathers of modern Vietnam.
Interesting and humbling. Very pleasant grounds to walk on, very humbling to see how Ho Chi Minh lived so simply. A must see!!

interesting but underwhelming. The whole Ho Chi Minh complex was extremely interesting to see and beautifully maintained. A must see visit for tourists and also a relaxing, beautiful place to escape from the hustle and bustle of the streets.
Very Interesting. Lovely grounds and interesting to see living quarters etc. The museum on he site is a little od - it is not very well set out and lacks continuity

Very crowded, quite interesting. I agree with other reviews that more information in English would be helpful. For us, it was quite nice but really, really crowded with school groups and we couldn't get out of there fast enough. Pretty, but don't expect too much.
Fascinating!. good insight into the life of Ho Ci Minh. Inexpensive and worth the visit if you enjoy history - very pleasant gardens and lake if you don't!

Good place to visit. The visit to the great former President's house was good as we learnt about who he was. The grounds are lovely and the house on stilts is worth a visit. I found the mausoleum vist a bit macabre and there were huge queues to stand but they moved very quickly and were well managed by the guards. The entire experience highlighted that we were in a socialst country.You have to leave your cameras with security and you get them at another exit when you leave. You also need to cover your shoulders and knees etc like when you visit a temple so remember to take a shawl and to leave any bags etc behind.

Interesting part of Vietnam's history. I went on a guided tour for this part of Hanoi and received a really good insite into some of the history in Vietnam. I found it to be a very worthwhile experience.

Nice garden- go with a tour guide to understand the significance of what you're seeing. This attraction is good to do with a tour guide. Without it you will just be looking at gardens and some dwellings without understanding the significance of Ho Chi Minh and his impact on Vietnam. This is a busy tourist attraction in the morning as those visiting the Museleum visit this attraction as well.The gardens are lovely and this is a well kept attraction with decent amenities.

Nice walk in the Park.. Lovely park and lake where Ho chi Minh spent his late years. Instead of living in the French governor palace (Beautiful colonial construction), he chose to live simply in these houses, the first one in the earlier part and the second wooden house in the park next to a bomb shelter when things started to get hot with the US. Loved to see the good old 404 peugeot! Better go early in the morning as it gets really busy around the pond and you have to move with the flow.

Good stroll. We walked through this after visiting the One Pillar Pagoda. This is part of the complex in Ba Dinh Square and can get quite confusing to reach because we navigated to the One Pillar Pagoda first right after visiting HCM Mausoleum and HCM Museum. So my suggestion is to do HCM Mausoleum (first and early to avoid the sun and crowd), then HCM Museum, then Presidential Palace and HCM's Stilit House, and finally One Pillar Pagoda before exiting the complex and collecting your camera. We spent close to two hours in this complex visiting all of the above.

We were 'forced' to visit. After visiting the mausoleum, we needed to get our camera and bag back, and were told that we had to go through park. The entrance fee for this was 25k Dong, so we didn't really have much option. The initial part, ie the Presidential Palace, and pond was very beautiful. But once you walk round the pond, you do feel like being on a conveyer belt as somebody else on TA mentioned. there is only one narrow walkway around the pond so you just have to go with the flow. Probably wouldn't go if i had the choice.

Must see to understand HCM. One of the great thinkers of the world and when you visit his residence you can see what a humble existence he had and how he used his surroundings to accomplish his work. Love the cars! A must see.
The Residence. Very interesting to see how simply he lived even though he kept three cars in his garage. Beautiful landscaped grounds. Takes very little time to get through.
See as part of whole complex. Interesting to see the simple house Ho Chi Minh lived in by the pond. gives you a bit more insight into his character.

worth a visit. set in well landscaped gardens we enjoyed the walk and looking at the house and artefacts. the main house which Ho Chi Minh never used can only be viewed from about 100 feet away. its a government office now. his house which is slightly to the left of the main house is much more modest and set beside a small lake.

Well reserved. It is great that they are well reserving Ho Chi Minh's stilt house. The area is very peaceful with gardens, fish pond. The house is very simple. It reflects the simple's living of the Great President. Admission is free for Vietnamese.

Quick visit. Walk through the "simple" life that Ho Chi Minh reportedly adopted. See the famous house on stilts, his cars, dining area, and kitchen. A quick visit after the mausoleum - takes 20 minutes.

A whistle stop walk through. As we entered the grounds the guards shut the gate - I guess it was their lunch hour or they were shutting earlier. The guards then starting herding people along the paths towards the exits shouting at anyway daring to just stand and look. Did not get the chance to look inside any of the buildings but from the outside there did not appear to be much to look at.
one of the reasons to visit Hanoi. you have to wait patiently,it can be hot,but we made the entrance in half an hour.worth the wait.beautiful house in wonderful surroundings.can be very busy!!.

Tourists on a conveyor belt. What one sees is OK but it is not much. The old cars and the simple summer residence are interesting but the whole place was packed with tourist groups and we saw nothing of the main residence which was formerly the Indochina General Governor's residence.I guess it is a tick in the box - I saw that - rather than a "must do".
Simple. Also know as the house on stilts - here Ho Chi Min lived in simple means, preferred over the large palace nearby, the house overlooks a lake where he walked and jogged.

Impressive. I was drawn to the history of this place. The place is well managed, very clean. It is surrounded with variety of trees, flowers and water. I was so impressed to learn about the history of this politician and how simply he led his life. It was unfortunate that we did not get to see his mausoleum as it was closed on Friday.

Humble Residence. Ho Chi MInh could have lived in a grandious house but chose this residence instead.It is very well displayed and in beautiful gardens and well worth a visit after seeing the mausoleum.Also displays old cars he was driven in at the time and is tasteful display.Grounds were immaculate as you would expect.
interesting. worth a visit just for the historic info and the way he lived. if you dont like history better to give it a miss.

Gives you an understanding of Ho. Next to the Mausoleum of Ho Chi Minh you see the homes that the people built for him - a Western style home and a beautiful wooden home that he asked for in his last years. Once again, take a good guide.

A Great Must-See on a Monday. Mondays are best because Ho's mausoleum is closed, thus there are no school groups or military groups making for an outlandishly long hours-consuming lines throughout the mausoleum area.

A walk into the past ( 1954-1969 ). It was a Sunday morning, this residence was packed with visitors. Looking at the historic house-on-stilts, the office, the study room and garden of President Ho Chi Minh told us that he lived a simple and moderate live. His garden was full of fragrant flowers especially from the mango trees. His antique cars also attracted many cars lovers.I am impressed by how much the people of Vietnam respect and love him. The whole compound is well-maintained and preserved.

Ho Chi Minhs residence. We liked the solemnity of the house and the fantastic gardens, The house and surrounds really gave us a solid idea about Ho Chi Minh and his part in the history of Vietnam. We would have liked access to more parts of the complex. We could not actually go into the home. We could only get a good look at the bomb shelter and old wooden house on stilts.
Solemn. Long queue - although it did move quickly. The actual mausoleumn part only lasts about 60 seconds for a glimpse of HCM. Has to be done.

Throwback (Thursday). It's inevitable that you will be compelled to visit this complex after spending time at the Mausoleum because they're just next to each other. While the Mausoleum is free, the Ho Chi Minh Residence has a fee of 25,000 VND where USD1.00 = 20,000 VND. You will be given a pamphlet which contains the areas of notice in the complex and their corresponding description.The grounds are vast but they can be pretty crowded because of the spill from the Mausoleum. In such crowds, getting a decent photo may be a challenge.

Simplicity exemplified. It was very illuminating to see the simple way that the Ho Chi Minh chose to live after seeing the grandeur of the Presidential Palace nearby. It showed his outlook on life and the spartan way he lived. He lived there for 11 years tending the lush surrounding gardens & feeding the carp in the fishpond.

Humbling Experience.. This is a must visit attraction, ideally after you come out of the Mausoleum as it is right next door. We visited the Presidential Palace, then saw replicas of the three rooms used by Ho Chi Minh and finally the wooden house where he opted to stay later on. It is a shame that the war time bunkers are not open to the public as this would have been interesting to see this aspect of his life at that time.
Ho Chi Minh's residence. Small wooden house with a few utilitarian rooms. He chose not to live in the palace just 500 yards away.
fascinating. This is adjacent to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It provides fascinating insight into Ho Chi Minh's outlook on life and his leadership of Vietnam.

Viewing Ho Chi Minh's Residence: An educational experience. Living modestly as opposed to living in the Presidential Palace was a real eye opener for me. Choosing to live in the Presidential Palace's former electrician's apartment in the servants' quarters defined for me Ho Chi Minh's values and character.
A simple place. 'Uncle' Ho was revered as a man of the people with simple tastes. Here you understand why he had this deserved reputation. A simple and pleasant memorial to him.
Must visit. Must visit for anyone going to Hanoi. Really interested to see waht the man was like not really knowing a lot before we went.
An important part of a trip to Hanoi. Should be an integral part of a cultural visit to Hanoi although parts of it were very busy with local tourists when we visited.

Very interesting. This place is really a very nice place to visit. You can see his small house at a little lake. It is a very nice and quiet place, if there are not too much tourists around. It is worth to go to that place in Hanoi

Ho Chi Minh's Home. Located just steps away from Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, Parliament Residences and the One Pillar Pagoda. It shows how he lived, very humble home similar to the those constructed and inhabited by the Mountain Tribes. Its a quick walk and worth it, if you are in the area. We were fortunate to have a great guide, that shared a lot about Ho Chi Minh, including his background (scholar) and his key principles.

Says alot about Ho Chi Minh. We visited following the mausoleum. HCM lived a very simple life and you can experience that by visiting his home. Although there is a very fine palace nearby Ho chose to live in this simple home where he welcomed guests , particularly children. The gardens are beautiful although they are very busy. Another must see if you are visiting Vietnam for the first time.

Modesty revealed..... Though a palace was built on the same grounds, Uncle Ho, as president of Vietnam, decided to live in a simple cottage. That is very rare to see and only shows the modesty of the great man. A lesson for most people of today.......

Take it or leave it. A pretty average add on to the mausoleum. Ok gardens and carp pond and you get to see where Ho Chi Minh lived. About it really. One of things that aren't really worth the visit but will leave you wondering what you might have missed if you don't go. Average all round.

Place where Ho Chi Mi stayed in his final days. Place where Ho Chi Mi stayed in his final days , lots of jingoist communist graffiti this can make you bit uncomfortable if you come from culture that's anti communist

Worth a look if you not on a tight schedule. If your visiting the Mausoleum then you may as well visit the residence. Not a great deal to see but, Ho Chi Minh's stilt house and the simple nature of his existence is quite cool and the gardens it is set in are wonderfully maintained

nice wooden house. The guards are way uptight at these, Ho Chi Minh last residence. He is the father of the nation but shortly before the liberation of the country was pushed out of an active role in governing by General Giap and ? General Duan. A man who lead by example...
the 4 sites make a great must see attraction. You visit the residence as part of the bigger tour, nice lake full huge fish, nice cars, house and gazebbo could be missed.
Beautiful area. The gardens and general area are very beautiful and well worth a visit. Ho Chi Minh is so revered in this country and his achievements well worth hearing about. Be prepared to queue.
Pleasant Walk. The site is quite relaxed and a nice place for a walk. The home a grounds don't stand out as anything special, but if you visit the tomb it is worth the walk.

Beautiful grounds. The grounds of the residence of the former president of vietnam were amazing, the gardens are beautiful, I could have spent more time just seeing the grounds, the residences were interesting, the guides tell you that these were simple homes for Uncle Ho, for the time they were ore than simple, even today if the standard of living was this good all Vietnamese would be happy.

Not a bad life for a simple man. No chi minhs residence in Hanoi is set among a beautiful area, the grand palace within the grounds and the beautiful gardens, for a simple man who believed in taking care of te Vietnamese in comparison, lived a good life
Very interesting. It was fascinating to see how he tried to maintain a simple life at the centre of history. He seemed to achieve this in life if not in death.

Good as an adjunct to the Mausoleum. We wandered into this place after paying our AUD1 for entry. Most visits are AUD1. We didn't plan the visit but were visiting the Mausoleum so its very close. You dont have to spend much time there and why not take a look.
beautiful house and garden. pictures not allowed! very strickt controlled by military persons.but you can find the picture on internet....

Interesting, but not a must see. A nice place to visit if you have time; some history, which our guide shared with us, but not a must see. We happened to be there with several school children who we enjoyed sharing some English with :)
interesting. A very unassuming place although in reality it is not proven that he really lived there permanently. He could easily have moved about in the whole compound.
Ho Chi Minh Residence. Very interesting and well preserved. Great to see HCM's cars, house and other artefacts all in lovely grounds.
Very simple like Him. Both Ho Chi Minch's residences were very simple with a small number of furniture. You cannot enter but you can watch and take photos from outside.
Go see The house on stilts. The wood work is neat, and to think he could quickly make it underground to escape. He also died in this location.

Fascinating. This is a must see for all those who are interested in the history of Vietnam.The presidentail palace is a fine example of a French colonial buidling while Ho Chi Minh's houses demonstrate the great man's humility.

Interesting. We unexpectedly walked into this area as we were exploring the city and I was glad we did. It gives a little window into history. Explanations are written in Vietnamese and English which was helpful. Beautiful grounds.

Quite boring. Quite boring, your are shuffledl thought, seeing the wax model of ho was more interesting and the guards minding him, they did not move a muscle. Go to the complex and you will see everything easily in one go, takes about 2 hours in total
nothing special. He lived in a plain house on the grounds of the presidentail palace. It was intersting to see but not a trip highlight.
Lovely. This is another visit you cannot miss in Hanoi - walking through all the park and listening to all the explanation given by our local guide added to my liking of this fabulous country !

nice but nothing special. Our guide took us there after the Mausoleum. It took us about 30 minutes to walk around the property. Nothing special as you cannot enter any rooms/buildings, you can only see through the windows.
Brings it to life. Interesting to see where he lived and a good partner to the Mausoleum. Very good to see they have retained it as it was when he lived there.
just ok. It was very not and just not worth the walk around the facility. Also it is not advertised that it is close one day a week and has strange hours

A nice day with my grandmother. I like the most of Uncle Ho's Residence is his fish pond. You can feed them and watch them to jump, wave, swim nicely. I met some friends from Switzerland- they were very friendly and easy going.

Interesting. This residence situated in lovely grounds, gives an interesting insight into the simple lifestyle that Ho Chi Minh adopted. You are able to look into the rooms that he used and even see his cars in the garage. The wooden house on stilts is delightful.

Worth a visit. Worth a visit to see Ho Chi Minh lying in state and to see where he lived and worked in the latter years of his life. It gives you some idea of how revered he is by the people of Vietnam.

The grounds alone were worth the visit.. As part of the day tour, the visit to the grounds, the history of the Presidents Palace and Ho Chi Minh's actual residence was a wonderful way to better understand the history of politics of Vietnam and the key person in Vietnamese society that made that happen. I now understand why Ho Chi Minh - or Uncle Ho, was looked up to by his countrymen/women over the years.

Ho's Home. Yes you can see how he lived simply, as one of the people, and that would certainly explain to a degree why he was and is loved by the Vietnamese. The grounds are well maintained, interesting visit but crowded.

French Architecture. Impressive, but a pity you can't actually visit the palace. Nice colonial French architecture. Not sure if originally (very) yellow, as I was told that all Government buildings (schools, offices) were yellow, not sure if from royal history or Communism ??
Liked the house in stilts. Really liked the house on stilts. Beautiful made of wood, simple. I now would like a house in stilts. In the right weather I think it is an ideal house.

Worth an hour or two. Mildly diverting, rather than fascinating - but some nice touches, like the gallery of Uncle Ho's used cars, and some real insight into the man's style of leadership. The unfussy table underneath his bedroom, at which most of the Viet Cong's major military decisions were taken, is worth a look.
interesting. Interesting to see that varience in housing for HCM. And he rejected the beautiful Presidential Palace. Cars and houses are interesting.
Explains the man. Such simple living, it explains some of his appeal to the ordinary Vietnamese, living like one of them

A homely little house. Both little houses where he lived, near the Presidential Palace, are very attractive little places without any pretension. He was clear a man of the people who dedicated his life to them. Admirable!
Once is enough. First time to visit this venue, but once is enough. Long lines and noisy groups made it difficult to hear our guide. Love him or not, there is lots to learn about HCM

Minimalistic but impressive. Most impressed by the architecture that was employed so long ago. Beautiful teak structure that was rather simplistic but functional. You walk the stairs around second floor and back down and out. Rather quick but good to see.

Nice Place. I like it that in one complex you get to see so many sites already.
Worth going to.
Interesting peek at the live of Mr Ho and what he gave up for his countrymen.

Fantastic Wooden building.. The building is well-preserved and the wood is beautiful. It was very interesting to see where Uncle Ho worked and lived. Anyone interested in architecture as I am, will find it something not to be missed.
Very interesting place. Interesting to see where Ho Chi Minh lived and look at the furnishings inside. Beautiful setting beside a lake. There is a garage which has his cars on display.

A glimpse of the private life of a public man. Worth a visit to see how simply "Uncle Ho" lived. Set in pretty parkland which is nice to wander around. There's actually not that much to see compared to a museum display, but you can look into the rooms that he occupied during his life here. Probably best to engage a guide to bring it to life as there's not much by the way of description or explanation provided at the site.

How to rate it that is the question. The buildings are kept very well and it is quite interesting to see how simple Ho Chi Minh was living. There are his cars exhibited as well.The gardens in general are not interesting, actually boring. What was interesting were the cypress's roots (they grow out of the soil, sticking into the air) and what probably get's missed is the coconut tree that is encased from by a banyan tree (according to the info we got the banyan trees usually kill plants in there way). Location: close to exit where shops and eatery's are.Note: The Ho Chi Minh mausoleum, residence, house of stilt, one pillar pagoda are all in one area.

part of Vietnamese history. The house is not far from the mausoleum. Maintained well and kept clean and tidy. It is an important place for the citizens of Vietnam because the father of their nation lived there. Nothing special for tourist from other countries. There was nothing special to impress me.
An absolute must. Highly interesting historical place. Amazing how modest this leader was living. Reserve sufficient time for your visit.

Interesting from a historical perspective. The environment is catching. Interesting view on the life of Ho Chi Minh. The environment, gardens and lake is great to see. Appreciating the simplicity of lifestyle he chose was also interesting to see. It is however not one of the "wow" places to visit. If you are not particularly interested in history or the life of this leader and want to do or see other exiting things, you will not miss out if you do decide to go and do something else instead.
Historical Significance. Well preserved buildings that give an insight into Ho Chi Minh's life. Best done with a guide to give information.

Ho Chi Minh’s Residence - An Example for Modern Leaders. There would be very few who won’t be impressed after seeing the modest wood house that was the residence of President Ho Chi Minh of Vietnam. It could well be an example for the luxury seeking modern political leaders. What is impressive about the wooden house is that despite being simple it is not bereft of high tastes. Cyprus trees and the elegant garden at the edge of the pond on the bank of which the home is situated, gives it a green environment. Walking through the jasmine scented compound leading from the mausoleum to the residence would be a pleasant experience for the visitor. A pathway to the south of the mausoleum marks the exit from the place.
Interesting. This was an interesting peek into the home of one of history's most relevant characters. The story behind his home and the out buildings is interesting. Worth a visit.

The little house. Looks nice and simple - this is reputed to be the house Ho lived in instead of a Palace as he was a "smipe" man/ you can view the bedroom and living room and study - no bathroom or kitchen!

Make sure you cover up. A very long wait so make sure you are able to be on the left hand side for the best view. Not for small kids , very very strict and regimented , controlled by army personnel which I totally respect. You must cover your legs and arms
Gives context to an extraordinary life. These modest residences tell a story in themselves, and provide an excellent example for today's leaders.

Uncle Ho's Home- fascinating. Uncle Ho was a simple man and wanted his ashes to be spread in South, Central and North Vietnam - to unify the country. But no, they built a huge mausoleum to him. I'm sure he wouldn't have been happy with this.Having said that, for tourists its definitely worth a visit. Unfortunately, we visited on a Friday (closed) and couldn't see his body, but the lake and house behind the Mausoleum, next to the Palace, is actually where he preferred to live. Amazingly simple yet beautiful. Don't miss it.

Worth checking out. Ho Chi Minh's house is worth a visit as he's a very important figure in Vietnamese history. The house is near a lake and the grounds are well kept. There's also a nice collection of his old cars.

disciplined. the whole process of getting to see Ho Chi Minh's body is worth the experience. going to bagage check,no camera allowed through a room which actually takes us back outside! bizarre. then, you go through a row of soldiers who are very serious and pushes you to go two by two, in silence, no laughing. I got in little trouble as I thought they were saluting me and i was saluting back but they were actually signing me to take my sun glasses off....and I couldnt laugh.

A Beutiful Memorial to such an important man in Vietnamese culture.. Well preserved park like setting. Popular tourist attraction for both foreigners and the Vietnamese who come to pay their respect for the father of modern Vietnam. Well worth the visit.

serious institution. we were suprised at the military presence and the serious nature of the site. You are walked through each area, the guards are constantly watching, if you use a camera or step out of line in some areas you will be told. It was a good introduction to Ho Chi Minh and his life, definitely worth a visit
Interesting place. Well preserved and interesting. Could have more information about occurrences and interesting events that took place in the house.

Impressive!. The masoleum was closed but we were able to enjoy the gardens and Ho Chi Minh's various living quarters. Was surprised at how simple his favorite residence was - the stilt house. Well worth the visit.

Pleasant stroll with beautiful ponds. Remarkable to learn of Ho Chi Minh is such a humble and inspiration leader to the people of Vietnam. When he took leadership to this country; he refuse to live in the grand presidential palace, opting to live in a more modest quaint house beside the presidential palace. The well maintained pond is known to be his favorite hang out spots and kept his beloved koi. Great photography opportunities.

Well worth a visit. It's heavily guarded as you would expect for such a revered hero of the people. Demonstrating the simplicity of life unusual for a president.Best to go early morning, before it gets too crowded.

Gain a glimpse into the life of the father of VN. This is behind his mausoleum and worth the time to see how Ho lived. It is worth about 30 minutes to get an idea of the sort of person the government wants you to believe Ho was.
Iconic and intriguing. Beautiful and iconic place, with our guide from Urban Adventures we were captivated by the visit. It apparently can get very busy, but wasn't when we visited.

Enjoyable. Totally enjoyable. A great look back at history in a quiet setting. Odd that there was full on souvenir shops at the end. If you clap for the fish they come up to you. Heard this was how Ho Chi Minh interacted with the fish.

Ho Chi Minh. Very interesting to see how this man, who gave up his life to lead his country, lived. He could have lived in the beautiful french chateau on the property but did not which makes sense as he often lived in caves in the mountains. Interesting stories about him and the koi in the pond
Pleasant surroundings. Worth a walk around to see where the old dude lived and his relatively modest house. Nice setting by the lake

Interesting look at how a leader lived. Worth a visit to see how Ho Chi Minh lived. Check out the fish in the central lake, his car collection (i'm sure he had a driver) and his tree house. The bomb shelter is pretty cool too but you can't enter.
Serene. The setting is green and lush. The buildings are well preserved. The man obviously believed in simple living!

Hochiminh mosoleum and residence. we did city tour with Videtour, a local great guide told us a lots about Hochiminh and his life, Ho Chi Minh was the founder and first leader of the Vietnamese Communist Party. He led the movement for Vietnamese independence and unity through struggles with France and the United States. He also served as president of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam from 1945 until his death in 1969.
Worth a visit. We enjoyed our visit here, we had our own guide which makes it easier to understand and get the right information.

I´d say it is a must!. This visit is actually performed together with the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum and the one pillar pagoda. The visit is very well structured and is done on a line basis. You have to queue to see the attractions but generally the line moves fast so it is not a problem (in other words: Dont get intimidated by the amount of people - we went there on a very crowded Sunday and the visit was quite alright).
interesting. attractive set in gardens.popular with tourists.shops in grounds cheap.try to visit early to avoid crowds.
Worth checking out. To know the story of Vietnam's independence, you should visit the residence of one of its modern leaders. Very nicely kept and informational. Ho Chi Minh tchotchkes abound, too.
Worth a visit. Set in tranquil gardens overlooking a lake this place epitomises the studious nature of Ho Chi Minh, go early in the morning to avoid the crowds and take in the mausoleum too.
Worthy experience. Take care to check opening times for Mausoleum, etc as we arrived after closing, but enjoyed a visit to his two residences. An escape from the hubbub of Hanoi.
Worth a visit. Well kept residence of Ho Chi Min, with working and living areas and even some beautiful old cars. Nice garden with pond to stroll around in.

A Look at a Leader's Life. The Ho Chi Minh Residence is on the same grounds as the Mausoleum, so the two should really be considered a single visit. It is interesting to look at the home and artifacts of a man who had such an impact on his tie and his country. No matter how you feel about Ho Chi Minh, he was pivotal to his time, and impacted greatly on the history of the world from World War II until his death. The simplicity of his life impresses.

remembrance of philosophy. the residence is very interesting; to consider the profound impact of a man and his commitment to his beliefs for the betterment of his country; and to see the commitment he had in his own lifestyle and its simplicity.
Must see when visiting Hanoi. Great part of Vietnamese history and worth a visit as he is such an important character in Vietnam. It is very well preserved.
Worth the time and small fee. The architecture was awesome and the grounds were well maintained. Lots of places to take great pictures.
Grandeur denied. It is interesting snapshot of what HCM had - and didn't want. Caught a glimpse of the lifestyle he prefers

make sure you check times. We didn't see any opening times before we set off. Guards would direct us to the residence and say it opened at 2. Only at two the guard let us past to see a map which said it was closed today(Monday and Fridays from memory). Wsated a bit of time, wish it was signed better.
a simple life!!. a historical portrayal of the 'Father of Vietnam" who shunned the grandiose life but chose instead to lead his country from a very modest building.

A wonderful way to study about The Leader of Vietnam. Walking through with a good guide is a way to get closer to one of the most important leaders of the twenties century.You can see & touch his day today life by all means.

Worth the time to see.. Nice, peaceful setting in the craziness of Hanoi. Peaceful vista park setting. Need les than 30 mins to see. Combined with mosolleaum, although a little to see body on display. No large cameras allowed, must check. Wear pants, the comms take ho chi thing very strick.

A great place to learn about Ho Chi Minh City. It's a totally different concept of presidential house, one that you would never see for president of other countries. The house of Ho Chi Minh combines well natural elements and simplistic housing style of Vietnamese. Take a walk and you will feel this special place of Uncle Ho.

Excellent and accessible. The guide had planty to say and the areas you can walk around are worth the visit. There is also the bunker (which you cant go into) but would need a guide to point it out as it is not obvious

Beautiful, tranquil, peaceful. Another amazing field trip!!! Lots of historical stuff is tied up in this amazing place. You learn much of the life of the Great Ho Chi Minh and enjoy the peaceful experience of his residence!!!

A very serene experience. it's easy to see why Ho Chi Minh chose to live here. It's a very calm place on the edge of a small lake surrounded by large trees. When you go, you can easily imagine Ho Chi Minh sitting downstairs writing, drinking tea and planning the revolution. Worth visiting.

Has to be seen. After the awful mausoleum that was built for Ho, which it would appear he would have hated, this is a much more gentle view with the quite basic accommodation that he preferred to use. Nicely kept and very appropriate. Quite a lot of Vietnamese, especially those from the South of the country, dislike the current regime with a passion, mainly because of the corruption. However they do hold a great degree of reverence for Ho; interesting.
Nice to see where the great man lived. A modest and functional home, as befits a communist leader, but beautifully situated on the side of a lake. Uncle Ho must have enjoyed his twilight years here.
Uncle Ho's residence is well presented. The displays are authentic, and show his strong character via the nature and style of his residence. The whole site is rather impressive.

Lovely building. You have to pay to go into the gardens and residence of Ho Chi Minh but it is only about a dollar. The grounds are rather nice but the highlight is the stilted house of Ho Chi Minh. Architecturally, it is very simple, classic modern 1950's and absolutely wonderful. I wish I could transport it home.
Nice gardens. the gardens are quite beautiful. It is such a contrast to the street and evident that "Uncle Ho" was a influencial leader. Nice for a look but wouldnt necessarily go back.

Interesting but very crowded. We found ourselves in a long line of other visitors walking slowly past the buildings and some old cars. Although there is signage if you have a guide they can bring it to life.
Interesting. Always interesting to see how these revered people choose to live. Well maintained and good exhibit. Be sure to see his bomb shelter.

Interesting visit to Ho Chi Minh's complex. Very interesting visit to this complex including the mausaleum, still not suhe isn't a wax work.... But very realistic...... Really intersting to viet people reaction to seeing the body

Beautiful grounds. His official residence was very grand so you can understand why he would want something built that was not so ostentatious. A simple man for his standing who also seemed to enjoy the simpler things in life as he got older. The grounds and residence are superb and a must to see.
Interesting. Interesting if you enjoy a little historyand nice parklike gardens to walk through.More enjoyable if you have a guide.

Country retreat in the city. Spooky and interesting place to visit where you will forget you're in a massive crazy urban city of motorbikes. As you walk around people will be whispering instead of talking loudly, and you'll not want to talk much yourself as there's are real feel of tranquility you'll not want to disturb. Uncle Ho's country house is really a lovely insight into his personality and rejection of the pompous trappings of power. I remember really wanting one of these houses when I walked around it in the grounds, but also thinking that it must have cost quite a bit of cash to set up, not a palace amount but quite a bit nonetheless! Really nice relaxing place to come whichever way you look at it, and perfectly ties in with the visit to the Mausoleum and museum around the corner.

Not so simple. We are told continuously by guides that Uncle Ho lived a meagre life. Is house near his mausoleum whilst not particularly grand and certainly not a palace it can hardly be described as meagre. He visit here ins a worthwhile experience as it gives one a good understanding of how highly regarded Ho Chi Minh is and how revered his memory is.

Heart warming..... To be able to see first hand on the residence of one of the great leader of the world.They said "a Home is your castle..." and looking at someone's residence you can see the character of the owner of the house. And to me, visiting Ho Chi Minh's Residence open up my eyes not only to his humble character but also understanding his dreams and seeing his works on the country....

Ho hum.... Flock in the tourists. No different than seeing Mao's place, or Washington's . If you're emotionally hooked into them -- great.Loved the garage with the sign that said Ho Chi Minh's used cars.Come to think of it, with that many tourists, maybe they couild sell a few on the spot?
Tranquil.. Worth visiting whilst in Hanoi. Very well tended and if nothing else a tranquil retreat from the madness of the streets.

He wasn't here for long. Uncle Ho felt this place was too big for him, being a man of the people and not needing the trappings of great office around him. However, a walk around the grounds is restful and relaxing and provides significant insight into the great Uncle.

Interesting. I was really surprised to see the modesty of Ho Chi Minh's residence and the history behind it and other residences within the precinct. The gardens were lovely and worthy of lots of photographs. In particular the lotus ponds were beautiful.
History at hands reach. Very interesting and a nice walk through the park finding the spots related with Ho Chi Mihn. His house, his cars, his trees. But bring water!

A great place to visit. We walked through the grounds of Ho's residence, accompanied by a tour guide who gave us the history of Ho Chi Minh. You can't go into the actual original residence as it is now government offices, but Ho didn't live there long anyway because it was too big for him. He wasn't married, nor had a family, so he moved into the servants quarters, and then into a smaller house on stilts. You can see the house exactly as it was during his time, as well as his vehicles.
realy peacefull. it is a great place to be with and great surrounding. Strongly recommend to visit any time when you are in hanoi

Good place to visit!. Hanoi doesn't have so many interesting sites as Ho Chi Minh, but this one is good and worth the visiting, besides the gardens and the lake inside provide you an excellent spot to take very pictures!
Interesting visiit. Great to see how this humble man lived. The building is well located near the Palace and is worth the visit. Well maintained and very orderly.

Maybe better with a guide?. Visitors get to see where Ho Chi Minh lived for several years. The place is immaculate and very respectful.I wish it had some explanations so that I could learn a bit more!

A national hero house, you know what to expect.. Like in most of the countries, the place where a national hero used to live is filled with a variety of objects, rebuilt rooms and so on to showcase him.The gardens are magnificent, since the Mausoleum was closed we spent a couple of hours here, it was just fine.

Interesting recent history. Couldn't visit the Mausoleum as Ho Chi Minh wasn't there, but his residences were worth seeing. Lovely walk in shaded paths around each of his residences. Gained more insight into this man who the west reviled during the period of the War. Good to learn more about him and his vision for Vietnam even though he never saw it completed before his death.

Sublimity of older and younger times. In any event, on Monday, when next door the mausoleum is closed: silence and dignified grandeur in this place of historical policy in the city center, but shielded from street noise and bustle, which may be due to three things: the rest of the few visitors, the architectural imposing nature of French architecture of the monumental residence of the early 20th Century and not least also the impressive giant trees bathe the entire park as a forest in deep shade. The latter is already out of botanical interest worth a visit! The French construction was not to enter, but a central wooden stilts on the lake, which had been inhabited by Ho Chi Minh, with authentic interiors of his time. At the outlet a few souvenirs or. Devotionalienbüdchen with Ho Chi Minh-shirts, nostalgic postcards, small flags and busts in all sizes at low prices, perhaps a touching gift for the occasional old soixante home, to general East Asian knickknacks. But all is not intrusive, at least in January. On the edge of the complex Ho Chin Minh museum worth seeing, too, because affording insight into the history of the country's self-representation and his government put up generous. If you already in the park, it's definitely worth the visit.
A remarkable life. This was a highlight of our visit to Hanoi. We saw a side of a great leader that was not seen in the media of the Vietnam War. This area is well-presented part of Vietnam history.

Interesting. The grounds of Ho Chi Minh's residence was quite nice. It was interesting to see how they build the residence and the furniture they made. It seemed to be a relaxing place and the ground were quite nice.
Ho Chi Minh's house on stilt. It's a place you should come to see and learn how a leader lived and worked there. His house is very nice, clean and simple. It's surrounded by many trees.
Presidential Palace. The picture is as close as you can get. Costs VND20,000 entry to gardens. Go with a local guide to understand the history.

Very quaint and serene. To the Vietnamese, Ho Chi Minh is their greatest hero. And whether you believe in his cause or not, you must credit him for his simple life and philosophy. His residence is beautiful and peaceful. So wonderful after a man spent almost his entire life struggling and suffering with his beliefs.
Worth the visit,. After you visit HCM Masuleum you can continue with the gardens and house. There are more buildings, its interesting. Read up before you go, or listen to your local tourguide.
Ho Chi Minh's Residence. The visit to Ho Chi Minh's residence woulg give the tourist a firsthand knowledge of how he lived in those days and the type of house he lived in.

Uncle Ho's House..... As a former soldier in the South with the US Army....I was impressed by the frugal lifestyle of Ho Chi Minh. He refused to live in the Presidential Mansion while his people were suffering. His dedication to independence for Vietnam is admirable.

Interesting to get a glimpse of how Uncle Ho lived. Well, if you are at least remotely interested in Vietnamese history, you probably should pay HCM residence a visit. It is right next to the HCM mausoleum, so your trip here should be rather fruitful. From the preserved layout of his rooms, decor etc, you can tell that Uncle Ho lived a very simple and frugal life. Whether or not that is propaganda is a moot issue of course, though I am inclined to believe it.There is also a minor attraction in the vicinity - the One Pillar Pagoda, which is built to resemble a Lotus plant. There is a little story behind this pagoda, which I will leave to your curiosity or your tour guide to inform you. The pagoda is also where locals go to for prayers in fertility.
Ho Chi Minh Residence. I found our visit to Ho Chi Minh's residence very interesting, the Fishing Lake is very pretty, other reviewers are correct it is a very popular destination so quite crowded.

I often pass by it, but can you get in it?. Having lived in Hanoi for 10 years, I have pased by the presidential palace (previously the french governors house) innumerable times, but never known whether you could get inside it. I still don't. Maybe real tourists know better than me! The ouside is reasonably impressive and the gardens are nice.

Interesting. I found the response of the locals touring the residence more interesting than the place itself. HCM is very much revered to this day and it is interesting to learn about his history and overall impact on Vietnam.
Definitely worth a visit.

A nice stroll in the gardens, nothing more.. Well, the site's name is a bit misleading, as you cannot go into the palace itself, but rather see the much more modest buildings Ho Chi Minh chose to live in.The gardens themselves are nice, with a beautiful pond, where you can shoot some lovely shots.An hour would cover the entire garden and the other buildings in the site.

Attractive and interesting but crowded.. I really enjoyed this but it's very popular and crowded. I would advise trying to arrive early in the day to get more of the atmosphere how it would have been.

Ok to visit. We visited with our guide who told us many things about Ho Chi Minh's life. It was interesting to see where he lived and to hear how he lived. It's a quiet place, with a little lake and a park. His pagoda was lovely but he had no toilet or bathroom in it !

I you want to learn something more about the spiritual leader of Vietnam. This is something every Vietnamese wants to do at least once in their life. So don't be surprised if you're the only non-Vietnamese tourist out there. Though it's worth while if you're interested in Vietnam's rich history
last house to be built in wood. after this house was built no other house should be allowed to be built like his house, for me it is inacceptable
Interesting. Interesting to walk around, would have liked to be able to explore the gardens a little more. Would have liked to be able to go into the main residence to see a couple of rooms.
Simple life. Had a brief insight of the simple life the very influential Ho Chi Minh led. Quite crowded during the weekends, try to go there during weekdays or try to get there early.
almost minimal. this wood house could be designed by one of the fomous minimalist architects around the world. Nice house in nice emplacement
Average. make sure you have the timing of their opening hours, they are closed at odd days of the week. Security guards donts speak English so dont bother asking for directions.

Loved it. We did it with a private guide which really makes a difference as there is not much information. Quite surreal experience, my toddler got shouted at by armed guards more than once for straying from the line and then told off for making sounds inside the tomb. All very weird but nice and cold! We liked the whole complex, interesting stuff and nothing like anything I have visited before.

An insight into the life of Ho Chi Minh. It seems that generally most visitors are steered more towards visiting the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum than to his home. However, a visit to his home gives an interesting insight about his everyday life and lifestyle. I enjoyed wandering around the grounds and looking at his home, and working areas. It complemented the visit to his mausoleum.

Good stroll around the gardens. With lush greenery and shady trees around its grounds, the short walk around the residence is recommended.Although a man of power, but he chose to live in very humble accommodation with the bear necessities.

Still very well-preserved. Liked - well-preserved building and surrounding areas.Disliked - too many tourists milling around especially when going up to see the house on stilts. Nothing too exciting too see.

Beautiful garden in a wonderful residence. The house is pretty much as it was. Nice to see the residence and Uncle Ho's Russian and French cars. Very hot day and unfortunately, there were very many tourists, so that in the stilt house could not stand without having to stop everyone else. Should visit this place with a guide who stands at the entrance and waits for a larger group is formed. So I learned some interesting facts about the monument and the beautiful garden.Very short visit.

Step back in history .... **. I really liked this tour. It brought many insights into the life of the man. Nicely done attraction. The simplicity of the house he lived in as well as explanation of the lake/pond was very interesting. I would suggest a talkative and friendly tour guide for the first time Hanoi visitor to explain some of the history leading up to Vietnam as it is today. After seeing this one, I appreciate the experience but will move on to see different things next visit. A good day in Hanoi might include visiting Ho Chi Minh's Residence, the Mausoleum which is very close nearby and the war museum.

Good for more information on Vietnam History. I enjoyed seeing Ho Chi Minh's residence. This is another good way to get some information on Ho Chi Minh... after learning some interesting facts about him I was intrigued to learn more. Yes, there are national guards everywhere and they can 'push' you to hurry up but it's worth going, after all this is an important national spot. Remember to dress conservatively- girls no tanks or shorts!
Interesting. Very well preserved and good organisation. It is a must when you are in Hanoi. You will understand better Vietnam History.

A well-kept complex: house, palace, stilt house, mausoleum. I visited the complex on two occassions and was able to observe just how much the Vietnamese hold Ho Chi Minh in regard. On weekends, whole families queue for hours (under canopies but still very humid) to pay their respects and see 'Uncle Ho' in the mausoleum. You have to go through strict security controls and be very patient and respestful. Around the corner are the palace (not open to the public), Ho Chi Minh's stilt house, carp pond and car collection. Very interesting.
HCMinhs Residence. Very interesting. Enjoyed our guides commentary and understanding the dimentions of Vietnamese history.Worth a look
Cute house. This is a walk in walk out job. The Vietnamese are interested of course but for tourists it's a cute little cottage.
Very Crowded. Very hot day and very crowded. Nice to see the residence and his Russian and French cars. Very short visit.

it was what i was expecting. This was a nice day out. There were so many people there. You get to walk around the property which was nice however if you take a wrong turn and find yourself and the exit you cant make your way back!
Not worth a stop. I would not bother stopping into see it again even if I was at the mausoleum right in front of it.

Beautiful settings. We now understand much more about Uncle Ho and this country after this trip. The house is beautiful preserved and you will understand more about the history, people and cultural. Well worth seeing and escaping the city bustle.

What a fantastic house. This must be one of the simplest but most attractive houses you could ever hope to see, because of the use of timber throughout. There are only a few rooms, all simply furnished as "Uncle Ho" preferred. It is a place which, it appears, is revered by Vietnamese who have visited the Mausoleum a short walk away. The house is guarded by soldiers in crisp white uniforms.

An interesting insight. Worth having a nose at, as much to see the swathes of people still devoted to him as to see the house. It's beautiful simpicity is surprising when compared to the presidential palace.
Uncle Ho"s residence. Excellent well worth a visit. Very clean, shady and lots to see

Simplicity surrounded by beautiful gardens. While not so easy to find, this modest residence in the grounds of the Presidential Palace gives an interesting perspective on the life of the revered leader of the nation.

Short and swift. It's difficult to get a feel for the man and his simplisitc lifestyle when you're being swept along in a river of people constantly marshalled by soldiers with megaphones. Or is that exactly right? Anyway, you get a look at the teak house where the great man lived a simple life and also a glimpse of the cars he used, old Peugeots and the like. The parkland's pleasant - flowers - grass - refreshments - toilets - souvenirs. Hummm....
Good to see, but not a must. President's palace and houses he lived in, can't enter inside
Amazing buildings. HCM house was amazing, was surprised how he just wanted to live a such a humble house.

More commandments than Moses. Enjoyed the hour that we spent wandering round the complex. But just what is the purpose of the baggage x ray,body scanners and all the security at the entrance? Then there are dozens of signs to herd you round. no entry,this way,that way exit etc

Ho Chi Minh's Backyard!. Very simple taste and lifestyle. Required so little to be comfortable. The French influence is apparent in the buildings used for business and visiting political and officials. His love of children evident in his open plan room with low seating, his massive fish pond, aquarium and peacock! The grounds are beautifully designed and create a sense of space and tranquility. A pleasure to wander through.
Worth a look. Interesting to see the relative simpleness of Ho Chi Minh's residence. Good spot to wander around in peace for a while.

Worth a look. This is a really interesting attraction, although be prepared for a bit of a drive. If you book yourself on a good tour thee are lots of places to stop along the way.The house is pretty much as it was, and it's a place thats very respectful of the man himself, so if you don't think you can stay in line, best not to go.Keep in mind, Ho Chi Minh is still regarded as Uncle Ho by many Vietnamese so if your opinions are otherwise, its best to keep them to yourself.

A must place to go in Hanoi. For the family who want to educate their kid or give them so good knowledge about history, this place is the must to go in Hanoi. Our kid was amazed by all of the stories and every around here. Very peaceful environment.
Calm place. Interesting place, where lived Ho Chi Minh. A lot of unique trees (from many places in the world). Lake with fishes. They react when you clap in your hand

Not really my thing!. I dont know if I have just become tired of seeing every single item ever touched, sat on or eaten out of by Ho Chi Minh but as a westerner it just wasn't overly interesting for me. In saying that I dont regret going, I just didn't take my time and only looked at what i was interested in, but each to their own!
Good experience. Dfinitely worth seeing when in Hanoi. Great photo opportunities.
Love the color!. go with a tour and get the history lesson. I learned alot from my guide.
Interesting but not special. Worth a visit but tends to attract large crowds. Get there early.

Nice residence. We toured this place with our tour guide. It would have been much better if the flow of tourists were less! It's a simple setting place but felt very nice and relaxed taking a walk around area!
peaceful. a peaceful place but not much to see really. Ok, ok, uncle Ho's was living very humbly (not even a toilet in his 2 room house). There are many beautiful trees around and the park is lovely.

Enjoyable visit. I wasn't sure what to expect but wanted some education about the leader that the locals respect and celebrate. Even though it is really busy, the property had a really peaceful feeling with beautiful gardens and lake. As the last person mentioned it is interesting to see the humble lifesyle that this leader chose to live. Educational and enjoyable.

Ho Chi Minh's Residence. We followed the crowds to this and the Pagoda from the Mausoleum. It was OK nice to say we have been there and to see first hand evidence of the great leader's humble lifestyle.

History & Culture. very serene and beautiful place to visit, i enjoyed it very much steeped in history, i was lucky enough to go with a local and got to hear the true story of the fearless leader, truly amazing

Quite interesting and very beautiful garden surrounds. I really enjoyed this even though it was extremely busy. It took some time to get in and move around the grounds but it was really interesting. There are three residences that all differ and have their own history and unique beauty. The lake is stunning and there are some lovely photo opportunities. I think the fact that it is quite a large property with stunning gardens makes a morning here quite enjoyable. Do take a tour with a local if possible as I thoroughly enjoyed some of the historical references they made a long the way. We went with Hanoi Kids and thoroughly enjoyed it.
MODEST LEADER. The dwelling displays the obvious modesty of the Vietnamese Leader. The locals flock to this site, all showing great respect & love. Another must see on your journey through Vietnam
got a tour guide for awesome travel for day. really enjoyed this day. exhausting but brilliant. make sure your legs r covered up to visit mauseleum tour guide brilliant loved this place

You felt he was still there. You can peer through the windows of Uncle Ho's two residences and see his meal set out etc and they are set around a lovely lake and gardens it get very crowded here and the guards do not like you taking their photo.

Closed for renovations. It is part of the HCM mausoleum and gardens. It is under renovation so you cant go inside. You can take photos from the pathways though.
All I know about is that HCM chose not to live in, but lived in the smaller buildings that you see in this complex.

Interesting as part of the Hanoi city tour. The mausoleum of Ho-Chi-Minh was closed on Monday, when we did our guided city tour of Hanoi, so after marveling at the building from the outside we went on to visit the complex containing Ho-Chi-Minh's residence. Without being negative about the visit, of course there is understandably a bit of a cult about Ho-Chi-Minh in Vietnam, up to the kind of sandals he usually wore. So, while there is nothing spectacular about the visit, it is a nice walk over the grounds supported by morsels of information about the complex and the life of Ho-Chi-Minh by our guide. Interesting as part of the tour, but no show-stopper.

Interesting to see how HCM chose to live. Started to walk across the footpaths in the lawned area in front of the complexes and the security guard started blowing his whistle. Tried to explain to him that we only wanted to go to the grounds and not to the mausoleum. Not sure if he didn’t understand us or simply could not understand why somebody wouldn’t want to go to see the body at the mausoleum. We tried again to explain that we only wanted to go to the gardens at the entry gates. No we were told to go in the queue for the mausoleum. No entry fee but closes at 11am. Closed Fridays and Mondays. You need to cover your knees & shoulders. I had to buy a scarf to wrap around me as I had a sleeveless shirt on, skirt was ok as it went past my knees. Hubby was ok in his shirt and knee length shorts. Both of us had thongs on our feet. Seems like we were going to the mausoleum, whether we wanted to or not, just so we could get to the gardens. Trouped past HCM and then at last we could get to the gardens. For Vietnamese entrance is free. For us it was 25,000 dong each You can take photos of the Presidential Palace, but from a distance. You don’t go inside. Then you can walk around to the house where HCM lived & worked from 1954 to 1958, see his office and his cars. The house on Stilts is where he lived and worked from 1958 to 1969. Small and plainly decorated. The grounds are enormous and a huge lake is in the middle of it. There are signs telling you what you are looking at and a bit of the history. No need for a guide. Just as you leave the grounds, this is where you will find the 1 pillar Pagoda, and the museum.

picture-perfect views. the facade of the presidential office is quite beautiful although we weren't able to go in because it was under renovation. a tour of the grounds, however, more than made up for it. the grounds are well-kept and the pond in the middle of the compound can serve as a perfect backdrop for your pictures. take care not to go down the steps leading to the pond as these are mossy and we saw quite a number of people lose their footing when they attempted to get closer to the water. fortunately, no one fell in.
real insight into the man. The area gets very crowded, but the house is much more interesting than the surrounding Ho Chi Minh attractions.

Logical follow up to the Mausoleum visit.. Following our visit to see the mummified body of Ho Chi Min we wandered across to see his residence. We were again accompanied by our guide, Mr Cahn Anh, who happily answered our questions and shared his great knowledge with us. Importantly we were no with a big group, just the three of us. The grounds themselves are beautifully maintained featuring tress from all over Vietnam. We clapped our hands to attract the carp to the surface of the pond while waiting to file into the humble wooden home preferred by this leader. You don't have much chance to look inside, there were crowds of people and we were hurried along. Thoroughly enjoyed the experience.
Worth visiting. It's interesting learning about Ho Chi Minh. His residence is very practical and not at all extravagant. It is very tasteful and reflects his strength as a leader.
Be patient. A simple cottage but you have to be patient in the long queue that snakes through the grounds and is continually moving so you can't linger to get a really good look.

Interesting. I found the location and the layout of the grounds interesting. The facsimile of his original house was lovely through I suspect it was a romanticised version. I wouldn't miss not seeing it.

Wow, Ho Chi Minh embalmed.... Amazing site and very we organised. You get to see the body of Ho Chi Minh, guarded and all very dignified. Then you can walk round his old residence, see his cars, view the one-leg pagoda - all very well organised, well worth a morning there!

Not Sunday’s morning. It was a mistake of timing to go there in Sunday’s morning. Under the hot sunlight, we stood with huge number of people in line from the gate. It is a long path to go through main spots. After the mausoleum, we passed by HCM’s house. The house and surroundings delivers the picture of a humble leader with refined hobbies. All things are well-kept. In the center of Hanoi, the place is clean, green, and secure.
this is for his own purpose. all we know that this should be the last house made from wood. All other people should not use wood anymore. All are equal but one is more equal. What a lifestyle
Step back in time. Interesting to see where Bac Ho lived. Pretty gardens and interesting relics.
Good to see. Very interesting to see where Uncle Ho lived and worked, right next door to his Mausoleum.

If You Must. we found this to be fairly ordinary and we'd recommend it only if you have time to spare - otherwise work your way acros the site to the huge museum dedicated to Viet Nam and primarily to Ho Chi Minh - this is much more interesting.
little house. Very interesting and picturesque. Quite lovely to meander through the entire complex - it is lush and peaceful.

A very interesting site. Dont miss the residence, once you have seen Ho Chi Min in his Mausoleum. The residence of the governor of Indochina is a fantastic French mansion. Sadly one is not allowed inside. In contrast Ho Chi Min's residence and garden house are simplicity itself.There are lots of tours, but going on your own is not a bad idea as you can linger a bit longer and stroll around the grounds. An oasis of peace in the centre of Hanoi.

Well worth a look at how Ho Chi Minh lived. So many tourists visiting here but all the school kids made it a lot of fun. Interesting to see the transition from Ho Chi Minh's french quarters to the more traditional and basic living. I think everyone agreed he made the right move. Picked up a bargain from the tourist shop at the end which I'm still wearing now, it was my first purchase so there you go.

Peaceful, ordered, still. If you are interested in Ho Chi Minh then this is a must see. If you're not, then it's a good place to come anyway because it has open spaces that have an order and stillness to them, and you can spend some relaxing time wandering about here. Good on hot days especially. Ho Chi Minh's cars are worth a look. In general, read the history first or you'll be clueless about what you're looking at.
humble. Whta simple life he lived in this house. So interesting.
Gardens of joy. Very busy - lots of people visiting, but fasinating just the same, lovely surrounds
Basic living. HCM appeared to like basic living without all the granduer. He did not use the Presidential Palace but a couple of small properties in the Palace Area.
A must. Interesting to see the whole compound and observe the locals also visiting.
Very intersting place to visit.. Lovely grounds and beautiful gardens.Well worth having a look around.

Early morning is the best time to visit. This is an interesting area to stroll around from a historical viewpoint. To see his various residences and vehicles. Suggest doing it before the big crowds of the afternoons.

Just the grounds took us hours. Do this trip as early as possible in the morning to avoid the crowds - seemed like every Tourist in Vietnam had the same idea - or save it till next timeWe didn't join the queue to the Mausoleum either. That was at least another hour
Interesting. Very interesting place to see. Strange to see a leader house being so humble.

Beautiful grounds. This is well worth a visit both because of its historical value and the beautiful grounds. The drawbacks are the hordes of other tourists and the numerous guards forcing you to move on as quickly as possible. Not really conducive to being able to really enjoy the place!
History comes alive. Wonderful to experience the sense of modern history and to see the reverence displayed by both the Vietnamese people and foreigners in this location
Worthwhile stop. "Ho Chi Minh" is everywhere in Vietnam and seeing the simple and spartan way he lived helps understand the man and his philosophy.
Opinion from a distance!. The queues are so so long we did not line up we diverted with our guide and just took a photo but got excellant photos and we were pleased.

poorly presented. Can include this on your itinerary after a visit to the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It is just filing past the rooms with no photos etc. Crowd control is poor and much time wasted waiting etc.
Mornings only. It hadn't noted the fact that it is only open in the morning, but happened to be there. Very well organised and appropriately subdued. Loved the surrounds as well.
More History. Located just behind the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, the residence is set in the Botanic Gardens. Some more queuing but not for too long.
History Lesson. Go early to avoid the crowds and see a slice of Vietnam history
Good to see where his humble abode was. Completely different to the big presidential palace that you see nearby. Go clap your hands for the fish to come up to see you at the bridge.
Uncle Ho. Great chance to learn more about the father of modern Hanoi. Our guide from hanoiKids gave us lots of other interesting stories about him too which made the experience even more enjoyable.
Great bit of history but lots of it is off limits. we were hurried through this place and found a great deal of it was off limits!! Entry price was very low though
Not My Favorite. This was kind of interesting for me but not really. I think the highlight is the massive garden and pond.
30 seconds of nothing much. Not really worth going out of your way to see this empty shell of a house unless you are absolutely enamored with Ho Chi Minh

Well worth the visit to the residence and to the mausoleum.. We were a little unsure about standing in line to see a dead body, but much say that the overall experience was worth the trip. To see the reverence that Ho Chi Minh has in Vietnam is very impressive. We now understand much more about him and this country.

hopeless. had our bags scanned and our cameras taken off us then as we tried to walk around to the mausoleum we were told to get in another queue to get our bags scanned again the queue was for 1 and a half hours. We didn't bother but no one would tell us were our cameras were or how to get out!!!

Hanoi experience. I thought this was better than the mausoluem and for sure more interesting and more to see. He lived a simple lifestyle really and had like a meeting/war room on the ground floor in the open.His living quarters were very simple with a war helmet and emergency phones in his bedroom. His office and living room had a few pictures of former communist leaders adorning the walls with basic furniture and essentials, nothing palatial about it but I didn't expect it to be and outside he had three cars on display supplied for his use by the former USSR.A good photo opportunity.

Ho Chi Minh's place of rest. we visited the Ho Chi Minh complex and despite the somewhat daunting massive queues found the experience extremely efficient. Our guide Thinh Bui is a very knowledgeable with the History of Vietnam and Ho Chi Minh and his places of residence so we felt most enlightened in this super well kept complex
Surprising. His modest residence was a surprise. A pleasant place to visit.
To understand the man you need to see this. As a westerner I have come away from Viet Nam with a different view of the country and HCM and communism.
Go if you are into vietnamese modern history. Interesting but greatly touristy - great queues of interested indivuals shuffling past the rooms

Interesting but.... The Residence is interesting, and the grounds are clean and a nice small walk. Would love to have more history of the place and uncle Ho. Still, its a easy jaunt, and we recommend you do this in the morning after visiting the Mausoleum.

Long lines but well organized. First of all, you can visit here for free! The catches are that you need to go there early (only open from 8-11 am, 10:30 is the last entry to line up. Be prepared for a looooong line. Good news is that it moves fairly quickly due to the amazing organization. No pictures allowed but they have lockers for backpacks/camera. We couldn't believe how well preserved the body looked...

He never lived here !. Ho Chi Minh lived in a simple house near this residence. He did not want to live in this Palace as it was too opulant.
