He wanted to be cremated yet the people had him embalmed and his body constantly on display in a huge mausoleum that being a simple man would also would not have wanted.Sure he was revered, but why go against his wishes ?

Solemn. Really enjoyed it, just to witness the locals coming in stroves to pay their respects to their beloved Uncle Ho. Guards interesting, building huge, gardens lovely and was strange but interesting to actually see Ho Chi Minh in rest.

simple living. A simple stilt house where Ho Chi Minh lived for 11 years. Surrounded by quiet gardens and an nearby lake filled with fish he led a simple life. A bit cramped being part of a tour group going upstairs to view his study and bedroom.
See while at the Masoleum. Nothing too spectacular but worth a stop while visiting the HCM Masoleum since it is right next door.
Insight to a leader's life. That you are able to see how the hero of modern Vietnam lived, and that he stuck to his socialist principles, unlike some other so called socialists.
Beautiful. Beautiful but not much in English, sort of felt we needed a tour guide even for simple sights like this just to explain things
must see if you remember the Vietnam War. Seeing the simplicity- and it seemed authentic, brought back memories of how wrong we were to destroy this beautiful country...
Must check his simple living house in the same campus. He lived in simplicity and i did find Swami Vivekananda book in the bookcase along with other famous writers.
Ho Chi Minh's Residence. Very interesting worth seeing. The grounds and his garage of old cars was worth the visit and the history of the site was very interesting.
Huge - museum as well..good stuff!. Huge place for Uncle HO, his body, his houses and the general worshipping of HO adn his life. Wow those guards are tough!
A Modest Home for a modest man. Well worth seeing. I recommend making it part of your visit to the mausoleum.
Nice little house. Better than seeing the guy dead in the mausoleum- more info there, a short walk and worth a swing through

An example for other politicians?. This modest stilt house was used for 11 years by Ho Chi Minh, who thought the nearby presidential Palace was too grand. The house is beautifully preserved, and gives good insight into the man who lived in it.

lovely little pole house on a beautiful lake. Fun walking by Ho Chi Minh's house on the tour. I remember especially the cypress knees growing out fhte lake, and the football size durian fruit haning on nearby trees, and the unsmiling impeccably outfitted security guards guarding the place!
Insight into HCM life. Saw the opulence and the life that he preferred. Enjoyed walking around the lake.

Hardly worth the trip. We made the trip only to discover it isn't open most of the day to visitors. We went around the outskirts, avoiding overzealous guards who blow there whistle at you if you so much as have a bag held above the line painted on the ground as a barrier.
HIstory. Amazing to stand there and see were Ho Chi Minh lived! History awakens!

Splendid. The residence, that was never used by Ho Chi Minh who preferred to live in a small wooden house is, absolutely grand. This french inspired architecture house is well kept and is now used by government officials.
Home of the Great Leader. Not much to see, other than showing HCM lives a simple life. Like the 2 cars he left behind.

Peaceful insight into an influential leader. Extremely well maintained and interesting place to visit. Right next to the mausoleum and One pillar pagoda too. Oasis of green in the middle of busy Hanoi and you really get an insight into why 'Uncle Ho' is so revered.
Simple Man with a Simple Home. Great to visit. Gives you a good insight of Who the man was and how he lived.
Fascinating. Don't be put off by the queue because it moves really quite quickly as you are not allowed to linger over his body.

Very relaxing and informative place with a guide. A place where the Vietnamese are extremely proud that everything is still orignal and they are very eager to show you how modest Ho Chi Minh was. You see the old french residence from the outside (it is still used by the government) and then the houses where Ho Chi Minh lived. They kept the furniture in the original state so you get a good impression. Also some carse are on display that Russia gifted to him.Addionally there is some nice nature to see there (do not miss the two trees from one stem) two little temples (be there before 11 a.m. or one will be closed for praying) an artificial pond and a couple of hundred tourists. A very good place to learn about Ho Chi Minh and his life, the war in Vietnam and the devotion of the Vietnames people toward Ho.
Beautiful Photo Opps. A lovely residence. I cannot imagine the deep meaning this simple home must have on Vietnamese people.

Well-maintained and worth the visit!. I enjoyed walking the grounds here--the exhibits and buildings are well-maintained. I went to Ho Chi Minh's mausoleum first because I feared the lines I read about and then I came here. (There were tour groups for sure here as well, but I found that it was better to just let them go before me to the various small buildings and hang back for a few minutes instead of racing to get there first--that way, I could catch a few moments alone.) If you're going without a guide, it is worth it to read up on Ho Chi Minh and Vietnamese history to get more out of the experience.
A really busy place. Prepare for lines. You walk around the grounds and see his cars, gardens and the mountain house that was built for him. This is best done with a guide
Excellent insight to Ho Chi Minh. To see this humble residence within the palace grounds provided an insight to this interesting man.

Next door to the Masoleum. Not worth an independent visit, but it is literally next door to the Mausoleum, which is very much worth seeing. If you're going to see the Mausoleum, then this is certainly worth your time. This is the house were Ho Chi Minh lived, and ultimately died. It is also the site of the former French governor's home, which is extensive and also worth seeing..

Fascinating. When they say "residence," it's actually misleading, because Ho Chi Mihn apparently lived in three different houses on the property, downsizing to smaller houses as he aged. Go with a guide who can give you information about his life. It's really quite fascinating.
big garden. need local tourguide to guide on u when visit. coz need to tell u the real life of Ho Ch Minh. understand what his daily routine inside his residence.

Helps Understand the History around the Civil War. Extremely well kept and scenic. You should spend about an hour there. It really helps understand Ho Chi Minh's outlook to life and what drove him on. It is a great tourist destination. There are three or four parts including the French palace which can only be viewed from outside since it is still used for official functions. You should make time for going to this location.
Scenic. Very nice to look at the presidential palace where HCM held office, as well as the 2 houses where he lived.

Stunning area and he was a lucky guy with the house he used to have. Myself and my girlfriend visited Ho Chi Minh's Mausoleum, museum and home and thought it was well worth the trip across town. We walked from the Old Quarter and it took us about 1hour to get there and we got to see various different parts of Hanoi along the way as well as stopping for a roadside haircut.We arrived way to late to get into the Mausoleum which stops letting people in around 12 and had a queue of thousands and thousands in both of the entrances, so we gave up on that plan soon.However, we went and checked out the nearby Temple of Literature and National University and had lunch and then headed back to the Mausoleum complex and walk around the surround area that house's the Ho Chi Minh Museum and household.It was a small fee to acess the area and the museum but was interesting none-the-less.The house was fantastic and you could see the cars he owned and the surroundings gardens. Definately recommended on any trip to Hanoi
Okay. It isn't open on Friday and Monday so there isn't much to see except the changing of the guards.
Detailed history of his life in Hanoi. Well laid out for a short 30 minute visit. Crowds flow well through the huts in which he lived.
INTERSTING. This is a communist country but they are still very lovely and the people love their country. His name lives on and will continue to do so.

Gives insight to the living standards of Ho Chi Minh. Brochure offers a little information about the place, might need to read up a little before going. The area should be smoke free as I can still see people smoking even in the enclosed areas.

Simple furnishings and living arrangements. This house on stilts is one of the many residences that Ho Chi Minh had over the years and is in the same complex as the mausoleum and is easy to tour. Lines move quickly and you get a brief glance of the first and second levels while moving in line
very good. what an intersting place to visit lots of interesting buildings to see a gret feeling to have been where ho chi minh once walked

Interesting although it may not be all it seems. The location of Ho Chi Minh's stilt house is very peaceful and relaxing, which is presumably what it was designed to be, and it is certainly historically interesting to look at the artifacts and imagine them being used by Ho as he planned his campaigns. But the claim that he lived there rather than in the nearby palace (a simple man of the people living in a simple peasant house etc) does not stand up to scrutiny. The only rooms are a bedroom and an office. There is no kitchen and no bathroom. It may well have been his "shed at the bottom of the garden" where he like to spend a lot of time but he almost certainly did not live there full-time. But don't let that spoil your enjoyment - it is a relaxing spot to spend some time after the sobering experience of visiting the mausoleum and seeing Ho's embalmed body.
Good Insights. Provided was a visual representation of how Uncle Ho lived during those times. Another great history lesson

See this. Whilst you may not be too keen on seeing Ho Chi Minh's preserved body lying in state in the mausoleum, his residence is a very peacefu and enlightening place to visit. You learn much more about the real man from seeing how he lived and hearing more about his working life. Well worth a visit.

Worth a visit to catch your breath. It was peaceful away from the madness of Hanoi and the old quarter. Although there is a huge yellow (French) residence that has no entry the actual residence of Uncle Ho was quite beautiful around the lake. The gardens and residence are extremely well kept. There is certainly a lot of propaganda about Ho Chi Minh but still interesting depending on your view. The beautiful timber home is on stilts and he lived very simply which is why he is loved by his people. I think there was a bomb shelter there also but you did not get to see inside. Worth taking time to walk around and reflect on times gone by. Plenty of photo opportunities. We had a guide which is well worth it to explain many things.

Quite touristy, but still very beautiful. A very well kept residence that show Uncle Ho's self-claimed spartan lifestyle, even his automobiles. It's a very beautiful and soothing area with several houses, a lake and green areas. This place is a better place to learn about Uncle Ho than Ho Chi Minh Museum. Better if you can get a tour guide as a lot of stuff needs explaining. Or you can try to eavesdrop like me.I got in for free following one of the tourist hordes :P
Interesting. Certainly worth a trip. Interesting to see. The grounds are beautiful and seeing Ho's operations was also fascinating.

Central to understanding the legend. Very interesting to see the small house on stilts that uncle ho lived in. The unassuming modesty helps understand one of the many reasons for which he is so revered by the Vietnamese.

More interesting than Mausoleum. For 20,000 dong, you can see how Ho Chi Minh lived - in a side home from the Palace in a make-shift tree house (almost). A simple life like an every-day man, yet as my guide and hopefully, a guide that you would have would explain, Ho Chi Minh was a man of contradictions. At least that is what I learned from his life, how he lived and some of the policy decisions he made while in power.
Part of the Mausoleum visit. Don't miss this part if you go to the mausoleum, the architecture of the traditional house build for him towards the end of his life is simple and serene
historical place. it wa interesting to see where he lived, many pictures and documents trys to explain something of these years, it was ok

INTERESTING. I hadn't really read much about this place & it wasn't really on my list of things to see.
However, my little moto driver stopped outside & sent me in & explained what it was.
It was quite a simple dwelling but very interesting.
I'm glad I saw it.

Would make a lovely villa. The grounds are kept nice and if it really was his residence, then HCM did live very simply. The grounds would make for a lovely villa and HCM's house on stilts seems like a lovely lakeside cottage.Its close to the museum and mausoleum, so worth a look. There may be quite a wait to see into the house on stilts if there are a lot of people so prepare to walk slowly/stop-and-go standing.

not a lot to see. the actual area of the museum is quite beautiful and a welcome respite from the rest of hanoi. worth going there for just that but there isn't that much to see in the museum although it only costs VND 25,000
Boring. Boring site really. But if you have just been in the masoleum then for a few extra pennies you may as well have a look around as it's on the way out

The New & The Old. This showes the new palace that was built for Ho Chi Minh & the one that he decided to live in which was made of timber, & not many luxuries but still quite sufficient. He seemed to be a very humble person

Insight into the man. I left this beautiful, yet modest house with an appreciation of a great man. His dedication to his people and his vision of the future resonate. Its a pity the leaders who followed Uncle Ho insisted on the cartoonish and over-the-top Mausoleum.

Interesting piece of history. A good (though perhaps a little propaganda-ish) insight into Ho Chi Minh's life. You could devote a few hours to the grounds or see it all in 15 minutes depending on your taste. Easy to combine with a trip to the mausoleum.
A humble home.. I expected Ho to have lived in a lavish palace, so I was surprised to see a small timber home on stilts. Well cared for and in a nice lake and garden setting. A cultural must see.

Integrity personified. The overwhelming impression one is left with is of Uncle Ho's integrity. What else can you say of a leader who left a pair of sandals and a pair of spectacles, a portable radio and an alarm clock? The wooden house is well-worth the visit, despite not being able to go inside.
Peaceful Historical Spot.. Very peaceful place to visit. But the houses were renovated to be too new to be his historical house. Not much things to be interested without a good guide.

Worth visiting. It is only interesting when you read the hostory behind it ...it is only opened at limited times when you can actually see the 'preserved' Ho Chi Minh himself ... we didnt go in, we just had a look from the outside.
If you have time. Nice grounds to walk around & see his residences. He is very cherished in Vietnam & there are many pictures & statutes in Hanoi.
This was well worth a visit. It help in obtaining an understanding about Vietnam's past

Nothing special but good to visit. There is really nothing special about this house other than the fact that Ho Chi Minh stayed in it. It is part of the Ho Chi Minh complex so you'll see the Presidential Palace along with his house on stilts next to it.
More insight. A lovely time spent wandering through the residence and gardens - seeing the impotance of Ho to Vietnamese history
Very peaceful. Nice to see where the great man spent his time and understand why he favoured the small house over the grand palace.
Well worth the experience. It was almost surreal being in a place like Ha Noi and especially at Ho Chi Minh's Tomb in person.

Interesting place!. This is a very interesting place and you can get an idea of how president Ho Chi Minh lived and worked when in office. It is all well preserved and you can get a very useful pamphlet with the ticket fee that explains all the sites at the residence.

Very peaceful - make sure you have a good guide. A good guide counts - by itself it could be a little boring - and we had to miss some parts due to renovations - but a good guide made all the difference with the stories and history.

nice and interesting. it's nice to know that part of history, how Ho Chi minh used to live, even though they try to show a modest part of his way of life, and i don't think this is accurate as the houses are absolutely amazing.

Understanding modern vietnam. Our tour guide walked us through the sites of the residence area. I especially liked seeing his humble home. It was great to get the history of his life and have a chance to walk around with out fearing the motorcycles.
It's a house on stilts. Unless you are an avid fan of Uncle Ho, I don't see any reason to visit. Of course, if you visit the mausoleum then you are already there and then why not take a look?
Insight to a hiden past. It gave a fascinating glimpse into the Vietnamese leaders life in which he became the people leader and known has uncle chin
Sacred to the VN. Shows the humble surrounds that even the revered head of state Uncle Ho lived in. Some in the west might take note.
Beautiful, serene. Very interesting, beautiful property, very well displayed.

Very ineresting! Looks like he will come home at any minute!. This was pretty cool. It looks just like he left it. You can picture Uncle Ho (as he is called ;) sitting at his desk. He lived such a simple life style. It intrigued me to learn more about him.
Don't forget to go see the man himself in the mausoleum! CRAZY!
Nice gardens. Truthfully, not much to see. Gardens where nice though.

Stunning gardens. Stunning gardens.
Amazing glimpse to a time gone by

Beautiful and unique. This was a highlight of the visit to Ha Noi. Beautiful grounds and the residence was really unique. We had an English speaking guide with us who helped to make the most of this tour.
Great propaganda!. See if you can spot where he really lived! - surely not in a small wooden house with no toilet or running water? - you decide
Impressed with the house in stilts.. The mango street was impressive. The bunket for the bomb shelter was interesting. has an exit 1 mile away!
Very impressive. Impressed that Ho Chi Minh chose to live simply rather than occpuying such an elaborate building.
I honestly don't remember much of it. It was a very humble home, very basic, a contrast to the gardens behind the mausoleum.
Most interesting. Very interesting to see how Uncle Hoi lived. Also interesting to see the respect shown by the locals visiting and paying their respects.

Part of a package. I wouldn't go just to see the residence; it's a very simple wooden house on stilts. Since it's on the same compound as the Presidential Palace, the One Pillar Pagoda, the Ho Chi Minh Museum and Mausoleum, then you may as well stop by and check it out.
So informative and lovely. So interesting to see how humble a president can live. He really seemed to be a man for the people and a true lover of life

French-style building. The palace is situated in the park that has Ho Chi Minh's residence, the One Pillar Pagoda, and the nearby Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum. It is a lovely yellow building in the French Beaux-Arts style. This is where my little story comes in. Be aware that your Vietnamese tour guides know nothing. Ours said that the building is in the gothic style. I thought that I misheard and asked him to repeat what he said. I then informed him that it is in a slightly Napoleon and mostly Beaux-Art style. He proceeded to get into an argument with me about how his book said it was gothic. I finally said to him that I lived in Paris and studied architecture, and that before giving his paid customers misinformation, he should do a little research. It was such hilarity that I couldn't help myself but laugh. "The book said it!" I still get a good laugh out of it now. Besides the point, the building is great for pictures in the winter because all the mist makes everything grey, so the pictures come out well with the yellow background.

Culture on stilts. Very busy attraction, however the tourist lines move very well. Lots of history all well preserved, best to travel with a giude to talk you through it all, a lot to take in if you are interested, the only other time i have seen gaurds this strict was in London. I enjoyed this attraction and would recommend to others.
Ho Chi Minh residence. Interesting to see, a long wait to get into mausoleum area. You just get to walk past the outer buildings, and look into the rooms, but interesting to see.
Worth a Visit. The area provides welcome tranquility from the chaos of Hanoi's streets. The gardens are wonderful, clean and well maintained, as is the mausoleum itself. Worth a visit for sure.
A must see. Uncle Ho is so revered it was actually quite inspiring to see the level of respect being shown from young and old alike. I found this a very moving experience.

Good example of french colonial architecture.. Interesting insight into history of French colonial occupation and Ho Chi Minh's life. The presidential palace is beautiful and a good example of French colonial architecture. The house on stilts that Ho Chi Minh supposedly lived in was also in good condition. The surrounding lakes and gardens are very peaceful.
Moving experience. Go to see the raising of the Vietnamese flag. The soldiers marching past to the sound of the Vietnamese National Anthem is very moving.
Definitely worth it. Well maintained complex, house, gardens. Nice to learn about HCM's life and a little about Vietnam's history.

Worth a quick visit. This is right near the Mausoleum, so if you go there you may as well stroll through the grounds to look at his house. As others have said, it isn't like the palaces of other leaders, but it is still very nice.

No entry allowed. LOGISTICSThe presidential palace is a park of the larger Ho Chi Minh complex. I would recommend you do it as part of a larger walking tour of the city featuring Old quarter sites (Ngoc Son, Memorial house, Bach Ma, St Josephs cathedral) > History museum > Opera house> Hao lo prison museum > Temple of literature.> Ho Chi Minh ComplexREVIEWOn the 30/11/2011 when we visited the presidental palace was closed. You were only allowed to view it from outside the gates. There was a military style ceremony taking place so this probably explains it. However, from other reviews it sounds like you aren't usually allowed in it anyway. The building it nice but you can barely see it from a far through the fence/walls.CONCLUSIONDoesn't cost anything to view so maybe pop over if you are visiting the mausoleum/museum but don't expect anything amazing.
A pleasant garden walk. An interesting part of history. A wander through his garden gives a good sense of how simply he lived (not quite as simple as most Vietnamese)
Part of Vietnam's history. Did it as an add on to the Mausoleum and well worth the small fee charged.

A humble man. Ho Chi Minh's residence is set in the grounds of the old French colonial governor's residence. The imposing French "palace" dominates the site, but from our guide's account, Ho chi Minh only entered this building once.He initially set up house in one of the small outbuildings on the grounds. Later the people of North Vietnam built the house on stilts for him on the banks of a small pond. This house mirrors the man; humble and spartan.The grounds are well kept, and the whole complex is a pleasant place to stroll around for a couple of hours.

Meaningful Place. For me, visiting such a historical place need a great tour guide. I am so lucky as I have a great tour guide -- David. He explained details of the place to us patiently. This made the trip more meaningful and we had a clear mind about President Ho. Thanks David.

Insight into the life of a humble and modest leader of a state. You'll have a glimpse of how a simple life Chairman Ho Chi Minh had while he was the PM and President. Its set in a tranquil landscape. Only disturbance you'll get is the hoard of loud-speaking Chinese, Korean tourists swarming the grounds daily.
Not too bad. It can't beat Sun Yat Sen's Mausoleum in Nanjing but its quite interesting.
interesting. excellent if you are into Vietnam history, thoroughly enjoyed the 'private' tour we had. Highly recommend that you have someone 'guide' you.

must do -quickly. not a lot to see - all from the outside looking in but for history its part of the deification of uncle Ho and the houses sit in nice grounds by the Presidents palace, also near the mausoleum which is a must do photo opportunity, if you like a soviet style tomb!

Nothing to do or see. I can only say; "Boring" But review must be at least 50 characters so we advise people to look for something else to do like wander around "Old Quarter" in the middle of the road between a million motorbikes and experience the crazy but fun traffic in Hanoi.
Do not miss. This gives an insight into how simply the man lived. The house is set in wonderful surroundings. For those interested in history this is not to be missed.
Fascinating. I was fascinated by the elegant simplicity and amazed by the historical impact. The VIetnamese are so forgiving.
Revered man. Lovely grounds. Imaaculate presentation. Start at mausoleum entrance(free) and join 'conveyer belt'. Obviously revered by the vietnamese - not touristy at all
Interesting story. Amazingly of Ho Chi Minh not to use the hugely grand palace and insist on a much more humble residence to live.
Great tour!. You can walk around the complex and visit Ho Chi Minh's stilt house.
Beautiful modern style house.... This was a truly interesting insight into the lifestyle of a monarch, from his house to his cars. I don't know of anything else in Hanoi that I would call beautiful.

Try to avoid the crowd. This was part of an organised tour and interesting from the perspective of Ho Chi Minh's modesty and humble nature. On the day we visited the crowds were large (guide suggested that this is common) and forced us to keep moving so you don't get the opportunity to truly take in the experience. Our observation of the Mausoleum, which is nearby and part of the standard tour trail, over subsequent days was that it appeared much less crowded later in the day than early morning.

interesting. very authentic place, great to see to know Ho Chi Minh's personality a little better. A lot of people in the morning, certainly a nicer place to see in the afternoon, when most of the tourists are out of the place

lifestyles of leaders. Again, very interesting and worthwhile. The buildings and gardens are very nice. one can file up and see his actual house. when one hears about leaders wanting to live simply it is worthwhile to see the actual places....
Interesting. Since most can only be viewed from the outside, the grounds are the big draw - and it's very crowded
Simple yet glorious. Ho Chi Minh's house epitomised the man himself - unostentatious and humble in beautiful surroundings - with a lake and well cared for gardens, flowers and shrubs

To know about a nationalist. Everybody call him Uncle Ho and queue to visit him everyday. Visiting the place will simply give you the ideal of how important he is as the one giving Vietnam everything.
Worth the trip. Lovely grounds and worth the trip. I used Hanoi Kids.org for the tour which I booked in advance and they were wonderful!

Skip it if you have more interesting things to do.... This place was located next to the Mausoleum. For tourists, you need to pay VND 25k per person. (FOC for locals) We don't mind paying but found that nothing much in this place but tourists.This place was about the residences Uncle Ho has stayed before. They showcased things he used - cars, beds, tables, chairs, helmet, etc. Everyone was squeezing themselves in to watch those things. Really nothing much but it was a good walk in the garden as it was full of trees. Nice weather in November.This place is suitable for those who intend to know more about Uncle Ho. However, I find it better to know him by reading the history than watching his cars, beds, tables, chairs with the crowd.
Not much to see. The surrondings are beautiful but there's not much else to see.
Never to miss. No camera allowed when you are inside. So u got to see for yourself to find out how great it is.
Lovely surroundings. The house was very basic, he was trying to impress nobody and lived a very simple life. The surrounding gardens and the lake were wonderful.

Good to Soak Up on History. When you visit the place you'd realize how great Ho Chi Minh was in terms of simplicity of living; reminds you of how Mahatma Gandhi Livid almost the same life. You get to see the simple house in which he lived (though the whole place is spruced up and polished now) the minimalistic things he used and worked with, not difficult to see why people revere him as almost a God. The lake and the landscaping is OK, you get to see the cars he was presented by the Russians, many kinds of trees, only some of them could be identified by our guide, he said they are all presents from foreign countries. If you're going in without a guide, spend some time on the web reading up on the place so you can better understand the stories behind the walk, we wish we had done that before we went in. When we came out, we got to see the army practicing outside a slow motion kind off walk, was a great watch.Your Hanoi tour would not be complete without at least a look see at Ho Chi Minh's Residence.
Interesting. Interesting to see the residence of this great man himself.

A little revelation. Don't expect too much from this small house, which you have to look in at from outside... On the othr hand it gives you a picgture of Ho Chi Minh as modest man with simple requirements, as does the house on stilts next door which he used later.
Beautiful gardens. Very interesting to compare how a man was portrayed in the West, when we were a bit younger, to how he lived.

Simplicity. They told us that Ho Chi Minh was a man who loved simple life so his residence relfected that characteristic. Apart from the colonial parts of the place, the place where he used to sleep is a wooden Vietnamese countryside house. Just love the garden with a peaceful lake and lots of trees. The old time’s atmosphere is still preserved in this place.
Nice French colonial manor. Nice building with gardens but visitors cannot visit the big building but only the smaller one where HCM lived. Nice gardens
Very humbling. Try to get here early and stroll around his residence and gardens. He was very keen not to live in plush accommodation so his rooms are very simple. Quiet and calm though.
Interesting. Am glad we made the effort to see this, while this isn't a huge attraction it does speak to a man's devotion to his country.

Ho Chi Minh - A Man Worth Further Reading. The Presidential Palace and Ho Chi Minh's House is worth a visit. The Palace is grand but what struck me was the gardens and the size and simplicity of the houses that Ho Chi Minh lived in.

Worth a look. Given that Uncle Ho is revered by many Vietnamese particularly from the north I thought this might offer a hint as to why. Though set in gardens the basic house and lifestyle are simple and quite unpretentious. Maybe that says something of him given the extravagant indulgence of many leaders.

Historical memory. Uncle's Ho residence is located near his Mausoleum and near the presidents palace. In a very big garden with a lake is this common house, where he lived and hold the meetings. The house is very small, wooden and stand on some pillars. Inside the house there are the original equipments, which Ho Chi Minh used (old phone, desk ...). To see how he lived and work give a small overview about his personality. To walk around the area, his cars are shown (russian) and certainly a souvenirshop offers some nice things.

Ask for a Guide. This would have been a very boring attraction had we not asked for a guide. As only English speakers, we would have had no idea what we were looking at. Guides are free but a tip is appreciated. The guide gave a detailed tour and made this one of the highlights of our trip. Tour includes the 2 houses Ho Chi Minh lived in as well as viewing of the cars he owned, a bunker and his garden. Very interesting.

Nice gardens. To be honest, I enjoyed this place more than the Mausoleum next. The gardens are superb, and you can get a glimpse of how Ho Chi Minh lived in his stilt house. Be prepared of the crowd, even early in the morning.

Nice, but Only Viewable from the Outside. The Presidential Palace is part of the Ho Chi Minh complex, containing the museum, mausoleum, residences, one-pillar pagoda, etc so you'll see it as you walk past. It's a huge French-style building, looks very nice, but Ho Chi Minh didn't live here, it was too big - so he lived next door. The palace is used now for high level people to stay. You can't go inside or get anywhere near, so it's just to snap a photo and move on.

Part of the Ho Chi Minh Complex, a Nice Walk-Thru. The residence is part of the Ho Chi Minh presidential complex, including the Ho Chi Minh Museum, the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum, and the Presidential Palace, so if you go for one, definitely worth the short time it takes to see all of the above.The residence is mostly interesting because instead of living at the massive Presidential Palace next door, Ho Chi Minh opted to live at this very modest home, with a carp pond, and a garage for his three old cars. It's a nice place to see in context mostly, so you'll want to visit with a guide who can share with you information about what you're seeing (there are not really any signs to help you along, and when there are, the tour groups maul the front so you can't read them anyway). You also see his later residence, which is the house on stilts like the countryside people have. It's a nice walk-thru, only takes about 20 minutes, not really enlightening without a guide, but a nice part of your visit to the complex.
Beautiful. Lovely gardens, a beautiful palace and a more humble building where Ho Chi Minh chose to reside.

Nice architecture. You cannot miss this sight as you would have to walk through the compound on the way to Uncle Ho's house on stilts from the Uncle Ho's Mausoleum. Good for a picture and to appreciate the architecture. You can't go in anyway, so it is worth a couple of minutes.

Uncle Ho's home. Very interesting to see the simple, open air home that Uncle Ho had built instead of living in the opulent Presidential Palace. Great site to see while visiting Ha Noi. Amazing to see how simply he lived during sure a turbulent time. There are still a few remaining artifacts of his on display. Also of interest, his "bunker" and hospital behind the home where he spent most of his final days.

Ho's Home. It is quite an experience to walk through the open air home of Uncle Ho. It is beautifully preserved and amazing to think he survived the war living in this house. You also see the conference room where he met with his cabinet throughout the war.
